subsubtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 TORONTO RIOT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise under provisions of Standing Order 52 to seek leave of the House to adjourn for the purpose of debating an issue of urgent national importance.
Yesterday evening Toronto witnessed an outpouring of violent emotion, partly in response to the shooting death of a man of colour by the Toronto police.
The impact of these events is not limited to Toronto. Men, women and children of all colours but particularly our youth, all across Canada, are concerned and frightened over the implications of this event in a series of events. They need to know how their governments will respond and what is proposed to ameliorate the pressures which may have precipitated this situation.
I submit that a debate in this Parliament with a discussion of the complex surrounding issues is urgently required and is desired by our constituents and is fully appropriate.

subsubtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 TORONTO RIOT
speechtext: The hon. member for Trinity-Spadina has given me notice of this particular application for emergency debate. I would ask the House's indulgence to let me consider it for at least a period of time. I will report back to the House as soon as I can.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (for the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada) moved
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: that Bill C-70, an act to amend the Criminal Code (jury), be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak on Bill C-70 which amends the Criminal Code provisions regarding the jury selection process.
Under the current law the Crown is in all cases entitled to challenge without giving reason or peremptorily up to four prospective jurors and to stand by up to 48 prospective jurors in the course of jury selection.
The accused is not entitled to stand by prospective jurors but is entitled to premptorily challenge 20, 12 or 4 prospective jurors, depending on the seriousness of the charge against the accused.
On January 23, 1992 the Supreme Court of Canada issued a judgment in the case of Regina v. Bain which held that the provisions of the Criminal Code that allow the Crown to stand aside prospective jurors were contrary to the charter.
A majority of the Supreme Court held that the disparity between the rights of the Crown and those of the accused create an apprehension of bias in favour of the Crown because the prosecutor appeared to have a
May 5, 1992

Government Orders
greater ability than the accused to fashion a favourable jury.
I am happy to say that there are only very few reported instances of a Crown prosecutor exercising in an unfair or abusive manner the right to stand by a juror. However, as the Supreme Court has pointed out, it is important that justice be seen to be done in the jury selection process, not only that actual justice be done.
Bill C-70 would enhance the appearance of fairness in the jury selection process and would bring it into line with modem reality.
More specifically the proposed amendments would repeal the right of the Crown to stand by a prospective juror.
The bill would provide the Crown and the accused with an equal number of peremptory challenges and, where there are multiple accused to be tried together, would provide the Crown with a number of challenges equal to the total number available to all the accused.
The bill would require the Crown and the accused to alternate in being first to indicate whether they challenge or are content with a prospective juror.
It would permit the judge to excuse a prospective juror from jury duty if the juror has essentially a conflict of interest or on grounds of personal hardship or, for that matter, any other reasonable cause.
It would permit the judge to stand by a prospective juror on grounds of personal hardship.
It would repeal those sections of the Criminal Code which provide for juries in Yukon and Northwest Territories to be composed of a smaller number of jurors than in the rest of the country.
The bill goes further than responding to the Supreme Court of Canada decision. The alternation between the accused and the Crown prosecutor in being first to indicate whether they challenge or are content with a prospective juror, and the discretion given to the trial judge to stand by or to excuse a prospective juror for reasons listed in the bill, will further ensure that the jury selection process is a balanced one, a fair one, and an impartial one, one that neither favours the Crown nor the accused.
This bill would also repeal some sections of the Criminal Code which provide, as I indicated, for juries in Yukon and Northwest Territories to be composed of six jurors rather than the usual twelve.
The smaller jury was traditionally justified on the basis of the sparseness of the population of the territories and the great distance between isolated communities. Times have changed and these provisions are no longer necessary as an accused in the territories can now readily be provided with a 12-person jury to which an accused in the rest of Canada is entitled.
The jury is one of the most respected and long-standing institutions of our system of criminal justice. Indeed the right to trial by jury for offences carrying a penalty of five years of imprisonment or more is enshrined in section 11(f) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
The jury provides the primary opportunity for many Canadians to participate in our justice system and at first hand to see the criminal justice system at work. Every effort must be made to ensure that the jury selection provisions of the Criminal Code reinforce the confidence that Canadians have in a fair and impartial criminal justice system.
On July 23 the stand aside provisions of the Criminal Code will no longer be in effect. The Supreme Court of Canada has suspended the effect of its decision for six months in order to permit Parliament to amend the Criminal Code. It has not provided for the possibility of an extension of the transitional period.
Failure to enact new jury provisions before July 23 would have the potential to leave the Crown at a distinct disadvantage in the jury selection process once the suspension of the judgment is lifted on that date.
It is important therefore to clarify and establish the rights of the Crown in this regard quickly. For this reason I am seeking the co-operation of the House in ensuring that this bill which deals with the working of an important institution of the criminal justice system is passed expeditiously.

Mr. Speaker, speaking on behalf of my party, we are prepared to co-operate with the government in the so-called expeditious passing of this legislation.

Government Orders
However we do want to study it and go through the regular steps. I can assure the hon. parliamentary secretary that we will not be delaying this bill. We will not be offering a great number of speakers in the hope that this bill can go to committee, be dealt with expeditiously there, and returned to the House to be passed.
I would like to say to the parliamentary committee that it seems that the government with respect to the Criminal Code is placing the House in the position far too often where we have to make these changes because the courts have decreed that certain parts of the Criminal Code are unconstitutional, in this case against section 11(d) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
I think it is unfortunate but what it does say is that the government is continually slipping behind the needs of our society with respect to reform of this very important piece of legislation.
The Criminal Code is the basis of our criminal justice system. It has needed to have an overhaul and change for quite some time now. The committees have been studying it. In fact the Law Reform Commission was in the process of such a study. It completed the first part, but it was not able to complete the second part before it was so cavalierly terminated.
The minister has assured us that what the Law Reform Commission was studying will be finished, but we do not know to what quality or to what extent. I think that is unfortunate. It is veiy unfortunate.
The case the Supreme Court of Canada made in January for turning down the inequity which existed for the accused by giving the prosecutor a decided advantage over the defence lawyer respecting challenges and the standing by of prospective jurors is unquestionably obvious. It is something that really needed to be done and I am pleased it has been done.
I only feel it is unfortunate that it took a decree of the Supreme Court of Canada to do it; not only a decree but a time limit whereby the Supreme Court of Canada has said this has to be done within six months and there will not be any extensions. Unfortunately this is the way this government has to be treated. It has to be talked to a like a bad boy or a bad girl in school: "You are naughty. Will you please look at the work that has to be done on this Criminal Code?"
We are getting this piecemeal. We are getting bits and pieces. As one aspect of the Criminal Code comes before the courts and is studied by the courts it is determined unconstitutional, and in this case rightly so. Then we get legislation dealing with this particular aspect, this small aspect of the Criminal Code, and go through the motions. It is before the House and we deal with it in the House. That goes through and it is changed. Sooner or later if this government were in power-and of course it will not be-I think the whole Criminal Code would be amended by the year 2030. By then we will have continued falling further and further behind.
Instead of studying the problems that face our society and the needs of our society, this government is falling further and further behind, playing catch-up at the request of a decision of the Supreme Court, as a result of a disturbance in a major city in this country, or as the result of something that becomes so painfully obvious to Canadian society that the people of Canada just will not accept inaction. We have seen that in the case of gun control.
I would recommend and hope the parliamentary secretary would do what he could to try to convince the minister to be forthcoming in changes to the Criminal Code before the government is dictated to by the Supreme Court of Canada or before public opinion becomes so overwhelming on a point that the government is left no choice.
As the parliamentary secretary and I have said, this is the result of the Supreme Court decision in January 1992 wherein the Supreme Court of Canada decided the right of the accused to a presumption of innocence and to a fair and public hearing by an independent and partial tribunal was being infringed. It used section 11(d) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms for the basis of that. It has also said that any change to the present legislation must be done within she months if the government is to act at all.
Major points are made in this bill. It repeals provisions which permit the prosecutor to stand by a prospective juror and to provide an equal number of peremptory challenges to the accused and the prosecutor, as the parliamentary secretary has said. If the proposal brought forward to the government is fair, both the prosecutor and the solicitor for the accused will be allowed the same
May 5, 1992

number. If there is more than one accused then the total of the number of the standbys of the lawyer of the accused will equal that of the prosecutor. It also gives the judge certain rights.
The parliamentary secretary is correct in saying the court did not decree certain rights. It did not decree the respective provision dealing with the number of jurors in Yukon and Northwest Territories, that the number of jurors would be increased from six to twelve. Neither did the judge decree this bill would be so many pages or that it would be printed on white paper. The fact is that it is ludicrous that this government does so little that is unrequired by court decision or strong public opinion or so little that is imaginative that anything at all, anything that is any way outside the language of what it is absolutely compelled to do, is a revelation and an example of ingenuity to this government.
Frankly it has reached the preposterous stage. I think that what we are seeing in Canada, what we have created through our charter, our Law Reform Commission and our Court Challenges Program, is going to cause a further erosion because these bodies have been done away with.
The Law Reform Commission has been done away with. The Court Challenges Program has been done away with. Because we do not have those bodies to create the thought processes, to trigger the ideas in this government, frankly we are going to be falling further behind.
Fortunately we are still left with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and hopefully through the constitutional negotiations this vital document will be strengthened. I do not think any member of Parliament would not have that as a fondest hope.
I do want to say once again that the credit that we have received in recent months because of decisions that have come forward from our Supreme Court, once again emphasizing the excellent court system we have in this country. In decisions such as the Butler case on obscenity laws, it has been decided by the Supreme Court that obscenity can be directly related to violence against
Government Orders
women and children. It was a very important decision, one which has been hailed around the world.
Because we have these decisions we are now able to say that our justice system is working well. We had, as we had before Bill C-46, a Law Reform Commission that initiated the thought behind the Contraventions Act in 1976 we now have, 16 years later, the thinking that is presented in Bill C-46. We would not have had the obscenity case. We would not have had the Butler case if we had not had the Court Challenges Program.
We do not have the Court Challenges Program any more. We do not have the Law Reform Commission and we are, as a country, in fact poorer for it.
I do not know where the originality that the government is going to need to keep up to the pace of this community, the new Canada, is going to come from. Frankly, I am very concerned about that having seen as I am seeing now our justice system falling further and further behind. The government has been taken kicking and screaming into the innovations that have been brought forward by the Law Reform Commission, the Court Challenges Program, our courts, and our Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Having lost two of those eight very important organizations, the government is going to slip further and further behind the needs of the criminal justice system in this country.
I would hope that the next piece of legislation that comes before this House on the Criminal Code will be more extensive, will deal with more than what is mandated by the Supreme Court or by public opinion and that the government will do something that whl broaden the justice system in dealing with the concerns and needs of Canada as they exist at the present time.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise and speak in this debate on behalf of the New Democratic Party.
Bill C-70, an act to amend the Criminal Code, deals with juries. The jury is one of the most interesting aspects of our political and legal culture. The jury is the great invention of the anglo law system, the British law system.
It is an old mechanism, and people swear by it. It can bring real justice. It can also result in, as we saw in Los

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
Angeles and outside Los Angeles, a jury making what many believed to be a rather odd decision, given the videotaped evidence that most of us saw on television.
You never know what a jury is going to do. The Morgentaler jury brought access to abortion in this country. At least it started the process when ordinary people on the jury kept rebelling against government laws with respect to abortion. Very interesting. The jury is an old mechanism.
I have had the unique privilege as a Crown counsel and defence counsel before I was a member of Parliament to actually help choose a jury. It was my responsibility as Crown counsel, and I worked on choosing a jury as defence counsel. I myself actually served on a jury.
If you are a lawyer or in various other professions, in other jobs, you are excluded from serving on a jury but I wanted to get a feeling of what a jury was like so when I was a young lawyer, I managed to get on a jury in Vancouver. It was a coroner's jury investigating a fire. I will never forget it.
Five poor old guys in the skid row area of Vancouver were killed in a fire. I went to the coroner and said: "We have had too many of these fires. We have to investigate it". He said: "I am going to investigate it". Glen McDonald was the name of the coroner in Vancouver at the time, and he said: "I want to investigate that".
I said: "Great". He said: "I am going to choose a jury and put you on it". I said: "You cannot put me on the jury. I am a lawyer". He said: "Under the Coroner's Act, you can go on the jury and you should go on the jury".
I remember I went to my partner in the storefront lawyer operation at the time, who is now the premier of British Columbia, and said to him: "What do you think? Should I get on this jury?" He said: "Yes, get on the jury. You might learn something". I got on the jury and I learned a little bit about how juries operate from the inside. It was very interesting.
This bill deals with juries. The problem is: under the present law, the Crown counsel-that is the lawyer representing the Queen or the Crown-the government has, as the parliamentary secretary said in opening this debate, four challenges. Then he or she has a number of stand asides. He or she can say: "No, I do not want that juror. Stand aside. I do not like the colour of his or her
eyes, or whatever. Stand aside". I think it is up to 48 stand asides.
The defence counsel does not have stand asides. The defence counsel can make some challenges. They can make a certain number of challenges, but it is not an equal system.
Basically, as the member from Cape Breton, the Liberal justice critic said, this bill repeals the provisions which permit the prosecutor to stand aside a prospective juror. The stand aside is gone for the prosecution, and then it provides an equal number of peremptory challenges to the accused counsel and to the prosecution.
That is a more equal system, and it follows what the Supreme Court has told this Parliament to do. That is interesting, is it not: The Supreme Court has told Parliament what to do. I will come back to that and speak about it.
I want to put this view out. I had a chance to talk to a distinguished criminal lawyer this weekend in Toronto, Clayton Ruby. Mr. Ruby suggested this, and I put it forward to the House. Why give the Crown any challenges at all? The Crown makes the law. We are making a law now. The Crown, the government, has got control. It is going to make the law. The government makes the law. The government sets out the penalty in the Criminal Code. The government controls the police which go out and apprehend people.
When people are apprehended, put in jail and brought to trial, the government chooses the judges that the accused are going to go before. Then, the judge sits in a court that is set up and administered by the government. The government brings the charges. It puts the charges before the court. At this point the government has done everything. The poor accused is in front of the court.
Under our system we have developed a jury system. We do not have juries in every case, and we are getting less and less juries actually, but in serious cases the accused is entitled to choose a jury trial. Why should the government not just take 12 people from the citizens and say: "You are the jury. Now we are going to bring this accused in front of our courts with our charges in front of you and you the jury decide whether the accused is guilty of those charges".

Then the role of the prosecutor, the Crown counsel, would be the traditional role, and that is to see that justice is done, to bring the person before the court to present the evidence against that accused. That Crown counsel has a different duty than the defence counsel. It is not the Crown counsel's job to get a conviction necessarily. It is the Crown counsel's job to see that justice is done, to present the evidence fairly.
It is when Crown counsel start acting like they are the big Mr. prosecutors, that they are the hard line Crown counsel who are going to get a prosecution come hell or high water that the justice system gets out of whack. I do not have to mention cases like Milgaard or a number of other cases daily in Canadian courts.
One can argue that it is a different duty on defence counsel. The duty on defence counsel is to defend that accused come hell or high water because the state has just so many powers that the defence counsel has to fight within the law, the law of evidence, within the legal ethics and so on, has to fight for the interest of the accused. One therefore can argue that it should be the defence that gets to put challenge to jurists who are seen clearly to the defence to be biased or would not give a fair consideration of the evidence. It should be the defence counsel that challenges and not the Crown at all.
This notion of equality may not be the right principle. I put that out for the House. I will be honest, I know I have got an uphill argument on it.
I think so too, a slight incline.

Nevertheless it is worth considering, is it not?
I will ask my friend, the member for Brant, to consider that there are just so many arrows in the quiver of the Crown compared to the defence. As I said, the government makes the law, sets the penalty, controls the police, chooses the judges, sets out the court system, brings the charges. It was outrageous that the government even with that system had a further leg up by more stand asides.
As I said, this bill equalizes that somewhat. It is in response to the case of Regina v. Bain, the Supreme Court decision which ruled that subsections 634(1) and (2) are inconsistent with section 11(d) of the charter in so
Government Orders
far as they provide the Crown with a combination of peremptory challenges and stand-bys that is more than four times the number permitted the accused. Since I brought in a plain languages bill and will be talking about that all week I had better translate that into plain language.
The court said there cannot be an unequal system between the Crown and the accused. That is against the Charter of Rights. That is the translation in plain language.
That sounds much better.

The Supreme Court noted and I quote: "The observer or the process is bound to conclude that absence on control, the Crown possesses a substantial advantage and can effectively influence the make-up of the jury under partisan considerations".
The court gave Parliament six months to bring forward a reply. I will return to that in a moment because the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys made the point that once again this government and this Parliament is responding to the court rather than enacting legislation before the court has to come in and tell us to do things.
I want to point out to the government and to this House that for the most part these proposals were included in a working paper by the Law Reform Commission. Remember that? That is the body the government is going to abolish. This is the second justice bill in a row we are dealing with that stems from reports of the Law Reform Commission.
It had too many bright ideas.

In other words, a workable commission that was suggesting proposals and now, of course, the government is going to get rid of it.
Looking back at the 1980 report, "The Jury and Criminal Trials," it was also included in a finalized recommendation in the Law Reform report of March 16, 1982. I have copies of that report for the House if any members would like to see it. That working paper notes:
The peremptory challenge is one tool by which the accused can
feel that he or she has some minimal control over the make-up of
the jury, no matter how illogical or irrational.
That is interesting. It ties in with some of the arguments I was making earlier that Mr. Ruby had suggested.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
The proposed legislation calls for four peremptory challenges by both the accused and the prosecutor in lesser charges in keeping with the existing statutes. The Law Reform Commission report recommended a minimum of 12 when one individual has been charged. The legislative committee may want to look at the number. The Law Reform Commission puts forward one argument and there may be others.
The Law Reform Commission recommended in section 9 of its proposal that co-accused persons who are to be jointly tried have fewer peremptory challenges than they would if tried separately. The government seems to have the right idea on this point by maintaining the same number of peremptory challenges whether tried separately or together. The legislative committee may want to look at this matter.
As I said, this is not the first time that Parliament has been forced to look at legislation in haste as a result of a court ruling. The government has been reluctant to pursue its responsibilities or is unable to do so.
The Minister of Justice made a very interesting speech at the occasion of the 10th anniversary of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. She said:
I have begun to note a very disquieting trend among legislators to leave difficult decisions to the courts. There is a great temptation to avoid dealing with contentious issues by saying: "Let us wait until the courts tell us we have to do it".
Here we are in the House responding to what the courts have told us we have to do. Exactly what the Minister of Justice feared is happening. Of course the logical question is: "Why did you not act sooner? You had the Law Reform Commission report since 1980 and 1982".
This abdication of parliamentary responsibility results in increased pressure on the courts and there have been other cases. Look at the Swain decision. We had to react on that this year. That was the case where they threw out the insanity laws. A report from the Law Reform Commission has been around since, I believe, the early 1970s, and Parliament did not act. The courts ruled and suddenly we had a bill in Parliament. That is exactly what is happening here.
Madam Justice Claire LHeureux-Dube said that the quality of justice is suffering because the courts have become buried in an avalanche of important cases involving the charter.
The minister has said: "We must not forget that it is the legislatures not the courts which are in the best position to assess competing demands and to conduct the necessary balancing of interests." I agree with that and many people do. It should be Parliament that should be acting.
Now we have a charter. The courts are there and doing a fine job, but it is ultimately Parliament in our system that is responsible.
There are other examples where we can act now. I want to conclude by saying let us not repeat this situation.
I will give another example and I predict to the government that we are going to run right into it. Six years ago, the government committed itself to take action to ensure "that sexual orientation is a prohibited ground of discrimination in relation to all areas of federal jurisdiction". There are now cases before the courts that specifically refer to this concern and the government keeps ducking it. It keeps refusing to deal with it.
Haig and Birch v. Regina is one example. At the Ontario court level the justice ruled that "the absence of sexual orientation from the list of proscribed grounds of discrimination in-the Canadian Human Rights Act-is discriminatory as being contrary to the guarantee of equal benefit of the law as set out in section 15 of the Constitution."
The minister appealed that decision, even though the government gave a commitment which anticipates the very ruling that it appealed from. Why delay? The government is going to run into this. If it goes to a higher court and the higher court is going to rule the same way, we are going to be told in the House: "Well, you had better get moving. You had better enact a law".
The Canadian Human Rights Commission has backed up this ruling in its yearly report to Parliament. The most recent report stated: "The question of sexual orientation is perhaps the most glaring example of legislation lagging
May 5, 1992

behind social realities and the fundamental premise that all human beings are equal in their rights".
It is that the Canadian Human Rights Act remains conspicuously silent about discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation. This is despite repeated recommendations from this commission and a committee of Parliament that the law be changed and despite half a decade of promises by the government.
The minister, as previous Ministers of Justice, has promised to take action. On April 11, 1991 in this House in response to a question from my friend, the hon. member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys, the Liberal justice critic, the minister said that this and other amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act would be ready within the calendar year. That was April 11, 1991. We are now in May 1992 and that did not happen.
The minister said: "I think realistically, early fall". That did not happen. More recently she said in the House that she would bring forward changes by the time we rise for summer. I encourage her to do so.
I will give the parliamentary secretary for the minister a copy of an editorial from the Vancouver Province. It states:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney does a wonderful job acting appalled by the crackdown on gays in the '60s. Now it's time to do something about it.
Six years ago, Mulroney promised to end discrimination against homosexuals. Now he's acting sincere again, with the news that the RCMP conducted a witch-hunt against homosexual government employees, netting thousands of people who weren't even civil servants.
Mulroney's next move should be obvious. Amend the Human Rights Act to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
Until that happens, spare us the sincerity.
I am not debating that issue today. I am just saying to the government that there is another issue in which we are going to be back in this House responding to the courts.
Let us be ahead of the courts. Let us respond to these issues. Let us take our responsibilities seriously as the minister said. I am prepared to agree on behalf of the New Democratic Party to this bill, although I advanced a new argument that would change it quite differently. That is worth thinking about and worth considering. The
Government Orders
bill will now go to committee and we can look at all these matters. It is overdue.
At the very least, we can have equality between the prosecution and the defence. In the end, I trust it will bring a fair system of justice in Canada. I am proud of the Canadian justice system but there are many changes that have to be made. This is one of the areas that we can look upon in this ancient and honourable tradition of the jury.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, on a point of order, the parliamentary secretary for the government House leader is not in the House at the present time. It was my understanding that the next bill to be called was Bill C-69, the anti-terrorism provisions which would amend the Criminal Code. If I am mistaken, I apologize to the House. However, it is my understanding that was the bill to follow the one we have just completed.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, what my colleague says is absolutely correct. If there is agreement there is no problem within the House. I believe there have been discussions along that line. We would be prepared to proceed with Bill C-69 at this time with the assistance of my hon. friend.

Mr. Speaker, on a point of order, the parliamentary secretary asked whether there was a problem. There is a problem but not one that I am going to hold up the House on.
I want to state that there is a problem. I am here because it was my understanding we were proceeding with Bill C-71 immediately after Bill C-70. I left an important committee meeting with representatives of the police force of my city in order to be here. It is going to be delayed further and while I am not going to make a stink about it, I want the record to show that it is most

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
inconvenient. I wish the government would get its act together.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my information was that there had been discussions with the hon. member's colleagues and that there had been agreement to proceed along the lines just discussed.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (for the Minister of Justice) moved
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: that Bill C-69, an act to amend the Criminal Code (air and maritime safety), be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the spring of 1989 Canada signed three international anti-terrorism agreements dealing with air and maritime safety. We now wish to formally ratify these agreements.
Accordingly it is necessary to amend the Criminal Code. These are the proposed amendments you will find in Bill C-69.
You will recall that in 1985 several terrorist attacks were directed against international civil aviation and maritime shipping targets. These attacks involve the indiscriminate killing of innocent travellers. They also show that regardless of how sophisticated the preventive measures are, unlawful acts against the safety of civil aviation and maritime passengers continue to impede the operations of air and maritime services.
This is what constituted the impetus that led to the signature of these agreements.
Canada played a leading role in the development of the three anti-terrorism agreements we intend to ratify.
The first agreement involves the protocol for the suppression of unlawful acts of violence at airports serving international civil aviation. This was developed under the auspices of the International Civil Aviation Organization known as ICAO, not to be confused with ACOA. The second is the convention for the suppression of unlawful acts against the safety of maritime navigation. This was developed under the auspices of the International Maritime Organization, IMO. Number three is the protocol for the suppression of unlawful acts against the safety of fixed platforms located on the continental shelf.
The purpose of these agreements is to extend the prosecute or extradite principle of international law to cover acts of violence at international airports or directed against maritime targets. The prosecute or extradite principle means that when an offender is found in its territory, a state which is a party to the agreement is required to either prosecute the offender or extradite him to another state which has established its jurisdiction over the offender.
The first agreement is a protocol to supplement the 1971 Montreal convention for the suppression of unlawful acts against the safety of civil aviation, which Canada ratified in 1972. This protocol resulted from a Canadian proposal made to ICAO and was adopted by 81 nations meeting in Montreal in February 1988.
Its adoption reflects a legitimate interest on the part of the international civil aviation community, not only in the security of aircraft in-flight services, which are covered under the existing Montreal convention of 1971 but also in the security of passengers, personnel, aircraft, operating facilities and services at international airports.
The focus of the second and third agreements, the international maritime organization convention and protocol, is terrorism which might take place on ships, at sea, or aboard platforms located on the continental shelf.
Included in the preamble to the convention is a statement of deep concern about acts of terrorism "in all its forms which endanger or take innocent lives, jeopardize fundamental freedoms and seriously impair the dignity of human beings". The government shares that concern.
Like the ICAO protocol, the international maritime organization convention protocols are wide in their scope. They contain broad definitions of ship and fixed
May 5, 1992

platform, which are designed to allow as many types of ships and platforms as possible to be covered.
These measures are intended to extend the principles and mechanisms found in previous anti-terrorism instruments to new situations and represent a further consolidation of these principles.
In addition to the convention and protocol, the international maritime organization adopted guidelines for measures to prevent acts of terrorism at marine terminals and on board ships. These are being implemented on a voluntary basis by port and ship operators in Canada with technical assistance provided by Transport Canada. A strong international consensus in support of these three agreements suggests a general recognition that no state is immune from the threat of terrorist violence.
The ratification of these three international agreements and their implementation will signal that Canada continues to play a leading role in the world-wide fight against terrorism. In order to ratify these agreements we need to amend the Criminal Code in order to extend the jurisdiction of Canadian courts and add new offences. This is what Bill C-69 does.
An essential part of the fight against terrorism is the creation of global jurisdictional networks to ensure that terrorists do not go wherever they may flee. These instruments will help to fill the jurisdictional gaps, which have allowed terrorists to escape justice in the past. The legislation before us today will go a long way in extending the jurisdiction of Canadian courts to help fill the present gap.
Traditionally, the application of Canada's domestic criminal law has been limited to matters occurring within Canada's borders. This is consistent with the territorial principle of jurisdiction derived from the English common law.
Western European countries have generally taken a much broader view and adopted the nationality principle which gives states jurisdiction to control the conduct of their own nationals whether at home or abroad. Jurisdiction can be concurrent with another state or states. In cases of concurrent jurisdiction, each state concerned may have a legitimate basis for jurisdiction over the offence. In practical terms, however, the state with the
Government Orders
greatest interest that has custody of the alleged offender would likely see its own jurisdiction prevail first.
The International Civil Aviation Organization protocol, in addition to recognizing territorial jurisdiction provides a state party with universal jurisdiction when the alleged offender is present in its territory and chooses not to extradite that person.
The International Maritime Organization convention in protocol provides for similar territorial and universal jurisdiction and goes further by allowing signatory states the option of establishing their jurisdiction based on the principles of active and passive nationality.
Notwithstanding its traditional approach to the matter of jurisdiction, Canada has accepted the notion that in order to curtail modem international terrorism, which knows no borders, the active assertion of jurisdiction through a series of multilateral agreements is appropriate. The present instruments follow other anti-terrorism instruments to which Canada is a party.
The application of these earlier agreements necessitated amendments to the Criminal Code to include provisions that would allow Canada to assert extra territorial jurisdiction in several instances. In addition to the extension of Canadian jurisdiction, the present amendments will add new offences to the Criminal Code as a result of these agreements. Essentially the new provisions will address acts of violence against persons, acts involving the destruction of property, attempts to commit such offences, and complicity in the commission of such offences.
The acts encompassed by these agreements are those which endanger or are likely to endanger safety, specifically at an airport serving international civil aviation, a safe navigation of a ship, or the safety of a fixed platform attached to the sea bed on the Continental Shelf.
In order to facilitate the investigation of these offences, the government proposes to include them within the list of offences prescribed in Part VI of the Criminal Code for which courts may authorize the interception of private communications or wiretaps.
Finally, these international agreements may serve as the legal basis for extradition where no extradition treaty exists. That would be particularly useful for Canada

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
because there are countries in the world that have no extradition treaties in existence.
The goal of both the ICAO protocol and the IMO convention and protocol is to create a more effective system of international co-operation in an effort to diminish the intensity of the terrorist threat. Since Canada played a leading role in the development of these three instruments it is appropriate that we move quickly to ratify them and amend our domestic legislation. This legislation would also complement the Canadian Laws Offshore Application Act which extends Canadian criminal jurisdiction to marine installations on the continental shelf and to foreign fishing vessels exploiting the Canadian fishing zones.
The agreements will make it more difficult than it is now for a person suspected of committing acts of violence directed against international airports or maritime shipping to escape prosecution by requiring states which are party to them to prosecute or extradite such persons. They will also confer extra-territorial jurisdiction over these acts on these states. The agreements will eliminate safe havens and ensure that perpetrators of such acts cannot escape punishment by fleeing the country in which the act was committed.
This initiative is consistent with Canada's current international commitments against terrorism. It will contribute to the enhancement of public safety in transportation and provide an opportunity for Canada to support the international community's stand against terrorism.
The legislation is a reasonable and responsible measure that will contribute significantly to the safety of Canadians who travel, either for pleasure or for work, and for those Canadians working on offshore platforms.
The member for Port Moody-Coquitlam said to bring us legislation in the Criminal Code that is not in response to a Supreme Court of Canada decision. As you can see, three minutes later there is another amendment to the Criminal Code that responds to Canada's legitimate concerns about terrorism throughout the world. Canada has been at the forefront of this initiative. I can tell the hon. member if it is justice legislation that he likes to see, he should be very happy throughout this session. I would suggest that other than possibly the
Department of Finance, I do not know of any government department that has come forward with more good legislation to protect Canadians at home and abroad. I know this piece of legislation, like all the others, should put a smile on his face. I look forward to having this legislation, as well as three other justice department pieces of legislation in the committee. I believe this is good law, like all the initiatives that have been taken by this present Minister of Justice and her predecessors. This is the kind of law our constituents want us to pass.
I think it is a responsible move by the members of this House to move this bill into the committee stage so we can have a look at it and pass it. This will protect not only Canadians at home, but those individuals who work or travel abroad. They will be pleased the House has acted in a responsible manner by taking the lead in this international initiative and coming before Parliament with this particular legislation.

I would like to respond to the statement by the hon. parliamentary secretary with respect to Bill C-69, which is another piece of legislation that involves amending the Criminal Code.
This one amends the Criminal Code to enable Canada to implement three international anti-terrorism agreements developed under the auspices of the International Civic Aviation Organization and the International Maritime Organization.
The parliamentary secretary said Canada is at the forefront of the work on the three very important international agreements he has outlined. I do agree with him on that. However, if Canada is to be at the forefront, he is not exactly rushing this piece of legislation into the House of Commons. Terrorism has been here for quite a number of years, and certainly this piece of legislation could have been brought before the House before now. I agree on the importance of the legislation to implement these agreements and for Canada to do its part in ensuring that there is no safe haven for terrorists and that we do have the auspices in which to have extradition, as the hon. member outlined.
We are fortunate in this country that we did not have occasion to need this legislation before now. The government has taken its jolly good time in bringing forward
May 5, 1992

this legislation and this amendment to the Criminal Code.
The parliamentary secretary mentioned that this is a time when there is a lot of legislation from the Department of Justice before the House of Commons and before a committee. I would suggest to him that if we are going to amend the Criminal Code one section at a time with a piece of legislation for each section, certainly we will have a lot of legislation. That does not mean that we are making progress.
The Criminal Code has over 800 sections. I would like to see something from the government, even in a mini-omnibus bill, which took perhaps two different thoughts and put them into a bill so we could have something that we could really sink our teeth into instead of this constant catch-up that we are playing.
As I mentioned earlier this morning when dealing with Bill C-70, we are not catching up. We are dealing with Bills C-70 and C-69, two very important pieces of legislation that must be implemented, but based on very narrow premises. We are dealing with one in Bill C-70 that was required as absolutely being compulsory to pass before the six-month time period imposed by the Supreme Court of Canada. This bill of course deals with three international agreements with respect to marine and aviation concerns which Canada has to implement. They are good pieces of work, frankly, international agreements which the parliamentary secretary stated have been agreed to and worked upon by Canada in conjunction with other countries and certainly should have been brought before the House before now.
The government was not waiting for another piece of legislation. It was not waiting for a new thought before bringing this legislation forward because it is bare bones as to what is needed to inject these three international agreements into our Criminal Code so that we in Canada can have the protection of the international agreements and offer protection to nationals of other countries by being part of this network.
The parliamentary secretary said that this is a piece of legislation that is not ordered by the courts. As I mentioned, in Bill C-70 it is not only the court's decree that is pushing this government, it is public opinion. Certainly terrorism is not a new concept. Public opinion would be very much behind the bringing forward of this
Government Orders
legislation to put these three international agreements in the Criminal Code.
We have two bills this morning that are very much acceptable to everyone. However, there the matter stops. Anything that requires any new conceptual thinking, any planning for the future, anything in dealing with where we are going rather than where we have been and are still going, this government is not prepared to deal with it.
I criticized this government previously on Bill C-12, the Young Offenders Act, because it was only a part of what needed to be done; once again, reacting to the belief of the people that if you punish young offenders more severely, if you try them in adult courts and put them in adult institutions, you are going to safeguard the public. The government was not dealing with the fact that these young offenders are going to come out from those adult institutions, having been psychologically and physically assaulted, without rehabilitation or counselling, are going to be back in our society and are going to be repeat offenders as a result of the experience they have been through. The fact is that is not protecting society. That may be an act of retribution. It may be dealing with punishing those offenders and that for a while may be some comfort to people in society. Certainly it is a requirement for those who have suffered as a result of the offence. There is no question that that has to be part of it, but there is more. We have an integrated society that must deal with the ramifications of what we do.
We saw in Toronto in the last couple of days where the subsidized housing requirements have not been met, where there has been discrimination of visible minorities when they apply for jobs exists, where the integration and working together of federal, provincial and municipal police forces has not been met, where we need to pool the ideas and thinking of federal, provincial and municipal agencies in dealing with urban crime and the needs of society, of young people and the disadvantaged in our society. That is the problem. There are vital areas in our society where the concerns have not been met.
I received a letter from the minister on this question, that Bill C-12 did not deal with the most important aspects of the young offenders bill which really had to be brought forward. She assured me there would be a second part to the Young Offenders Act that would be

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
brought forward by December 1991. This is May and we still do not have it. This very important question is not being dealt with.
The member for Port Moody-Coquitlam had a very important question on the Human Rights Act. The Prime Minister stood in this House a week ago yesterday and condemned the RCMP for the prosecution of gays in this country in the 1960s and stated how his government was above that and how he protected the human rights of Canadians. He felt that that action by the RCMP and the thought at that time was just terrible.
Yet, as the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam said, the Human Rights Act goes unamended. The Human Rights Act, which does not protect sexual orientation from being an abuse and prejudice, is absolutely glaring. What is going to be done?
If we are concerned about having sexual orientation as a means of dealing with a very important question, an open society, then we cannot have sexual orientation as a means of discrimination in this country. It is axiomatic that we cannot be a country of modern 20th century technology, a country that is going into the 21st century, with ideas and laws that relate to the 19th century.
If we are going to have the society that we in Canada feel we must have, that the government mistakenly feels that it does have, we need these fundamental changes to our laws in this country. We must not fear as politicians, and I particularly say this to the government, any advice that will come forward that is contrary to the thinking of the government. It is not an act of sedition and it is something to deal with by cancelling and disbanding the organizations that give that advice as the government is doing with the Science Council of Canada, the Economic Council of Canada and particularly in the legal field with the Law Reform Commission of Canada. These organizations have given advice on changes that needed to be brought forward. The member for Port Moody-Coquitlam said earlier in dealing with the Swain case and the insanity provisions, and with the contraventions bill that is now in committee, that they have been very helpful. The government has taken its own sweet time in bringing these recommendations before the House in legislation.
However, that is not the fault of the Law Reform Commission. It cannot be blamed for bringing forward concepts that the government took years and years to comprehend.
Finally, through some kind of head banging against the wall, the government has realized that some of these principles are now applicable and now contemporary, although society may have moved on to other things which are being debated that the government has not yet caught up with. It has caught up with some of these ideas that the Law Reform Commission brought forward in the mid-1970s and that is laudatory.
The fact is that there are new ideas that need to be developed and discussed and we need the Law Reform Commission to deal with those for the future. Of course, the government has chosen not to allow the Law Reform Commission to continue its work.
With respect to this legislation, I would like to assure the parliamentary secretary that this party will ensure that the bill passes quickly today on second reading. This bill will be dealt with expeditiously in committee and hopefully, if the government's timetable will allow it, we can have this bill passed through the House of Commons very, very quickly indeed.
It is a good piece of legislation, albeit something that could have been brought forward earlier and had a little more associated with it to allow for more discussion on other subjects when we are taking the time of the House to deal with amendments to the Criminal Code. This in itself is important and we acknowledge that and support it.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise on behalf of the New Democratic Party to speak again on this bill, another justice bill.
The parliamentary secretary produced this bill out of his hat in response to our demand. He said this was the world-wide fight against terrorism. I looked in the bill and I cannot find the word terrorism anywhere in it.
That is fraud to say that. This bill creates new offences in the code, it is true, which deal with unlawful acts of violence directed at airports, maritime shipping, plat-
May 5, 1992

forms, such as oil rigs. The bill also extends the jurisdiction to the Canadian courts on these offences.
These are relatively minor amendments and they extend the prosecute or extradite principle of international law in the Criminal Code. They are not, as the government has trumpeted, new measures to curb violent acts of international terrorism.
I just want to take a couple of minutes to tell the government how it can deal with international terrorism. I have a suggestion. My suggestion is that the government support the United Nations International Criminal Court. That is the key to the future and to attack real acts of international terrorism.
Let me give an example of the problem. We now have a United Nations resolution demanding that Libya extradite to the United States or to Britain two Libyans accused of blowing up Pan Am flight 103 in December 1988 over Lockerbee, Scotland. Libya has refused to do that, saying: "National sovereignty-We are not going to extradite them".
Now the U.S. and Britain have persuaded the Security Council to invoke economic sanctions against Libya. We have a very serious international situation that is in the pot now because of this.
It seems to me that this is a perfect case where we could use a world criminal court. The President of Venezuela and the Loreign Minister of Zimbabwe advanced this proposal at the UN Security Council last year and the former German Loreign Minister, Hans-Die-trich Genscher, has more recently made the same proposal.
Libya made noises about turning over the suspects to a neutral court in any neutral country. The Russian foreign minister then called upon the United Nations to take these two Libyans.
What would the United Nations do with them? The King of Morocco, in advocating the creation of an international tribunal against terrorism, summed up the legal situation pretty fairly. I want to quote what he said: "If the accused were judged in Libya, that would not be credible. If they were judged by an American or English court that too might not seem credible".
Government Orders
In other words, if Khadafy put the two alleged terrorists on trial we would not believe it would be a fair trial. However, from the Libyans' point of view, if they were sent to a court in Britain, the United States or Prance, they probably would not think they would get a fair trial. In their mind one can understand that. The answer is to turn them over to an international criminal court.
There are other modem incidents which call for an international solution. Part of this bill responds to one of those incidents and that is the Achilles Lauro case. It was the boat that was hijacked in the Mediterranean. It was a terrible case where a man in a wheelchair was thrown overboard. The bill addresses aircraft hijackings and violence like events we have see at the Rome airport.
The problem with offences like this is that they take place in or over a number of states. There is a problem with extraditing people. The principle of the bill we are debating deals with a principle called prosecutor extradite. The parliamentary secretary mentioned if we wanted to stop people from going to another country or bring them back.
Sometimes countries have trouble extraditing people. Colombia is a perfect example. It has political problems at home to extradite accused drug lords to the United States, because the public says: "Wait a minute. Don't send them to big Uncle Sam up there". It has a problem. However it would be prepared to send these people to a more neutral international court.
Let us look at Saddam Hussein who is called an international war criminal by the United States. It seems to me, whatever the United States called him, he is certainly accountable to the world over the environmental aspects of what happened in the gulf with respect to the gulf war and the Kuwaiti oil wells, setting them on fire.
There is room. One could say that was an act of international terrorism against the environment. Where do we try it? We would try it in an international court. The idea of a world criminal court is not a new one. It surfaced in Versailles after the First World War. It was seriously debated in the 1950s after Nuremberg and Tokyo and the war crimes. Then it disappeared in the cold war. It got lost then.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
International crime did not get lost. It expanded as the parliamentary secretary pointed out: terrorism, drug trafficking, genocide, environmental crimes. UN lawyers called them crimes against the peace and security of mankind. The International Law Commission, a branch of the UN, has gone so far as to draft a model statute for a new criminal court. It drafted a new model international code like our Criminal Code, only on the international scene, to list international crimes.
The world's leading expert in this area is Professor Cherif Bassiouni of Chicago. There is a woman professor in Canada, Professor Sharon Williams at Osgoode Hall who is very knowledgeable in this area. Professor Bassiouni said there was a broad consensus in the world. There are 22 crimes and a number of international conventions and treaties which include these crimes from the convention on slavery through drug conventions, to genocide conventions, through using explosives in the mails, crimes against diplomats and airline hijackings. These specific treaties were mentioned by the government today. The professor said that the international court was a practical and realizable project and all that was lacking was the political will.
This court is different from the World Court of Justice. This is a court that tries individuals, the international criminal court.
Where is Canada? The parliamentary secretary said that Canada is at the forefront of the world. That is nonsense.
I asked our former ambassador to the UN. He openly admitted that he had heard of the debate, but he was not quite sure about the international court. He certainly did not get any instructions on a criminal court.
I asked the Department of External Affairs and ironically it was too preoccupied by the Libyan situation to consider the matter fully, which is exactly the situation that calls out for an international criminal court.
Let me say to the government: Here is a good issue for Canada. Here is something that it really can do if it wants to tackle international terrorism. It can go to the sixth committee of the UN this fall. Canada should take the lead in advocating the establishment of an international criminal court.
The world has changed. Frontiers are smaller. The world is smaller. There can be no real world democracy,
no real freedom without an international rule of law. That which harms democracy and human rights as do all international criminal acts harms peace.
The time, it seems to me, has come for an international criminal court. It is an idea whose time has come. It is a way that the government could really, if it wants to be serious, fight the world-wide fight against terrorism and really put Canada in the forefront of the world, as the parliamentary secretary said. That is what Canada should do.
This bill is fine. It is a minor bill. It is okay if we can find the people in Canada, but if they flee to another jurisdiction we have to ask to extradite them; we have to have an extradition treaty with the country. If it will not extradite them like Libya, what will we do? Are we to go to the UN Security Council and have a war?
There is another solution and that is an international criminal court. I ask the government to look at that. For my party, we are prepared to pass this bill today because as I said it is not a major bill. If it is helpful to protect Canadians on oil rigs, boats and in airports then we want to take any steps that will be helpful in that area.
There is a bigger target and there is a bigger cause. I know the parliamentary secretary is a reasonable person. I would enlist his support and the support of my colleague from the Liberal Party for that cause, that is a world-wide international criminal court to tackle terrorism, an idea, surely, whose time has come.

Mr. Speaker, I want to make a short intervention on Bill C-69, an act to amend the Criminal Code (air and maritime safety).
As my colleague has already stated we support the bill, but I want to say that if the government were serious about improving the safety of people travelling on airlines that leave airports in Canada there is a number of other things it could do. I am not talking about the maintenance side. That is another matter for another day. I am talking about the ability of this government to provide for the screening of passengers and the screening of crews as they board our planes.
Mr. Speaker, as you and the House know, for a number of years now the Government of Canada has turned over the responsibility to the screening of passengers to the airlines. In some airports Air Canada provides that service. In other airports Canadian Airlines
May 5, 1992

provides that service. In turn those airlines contract security firms to provide the personnel and the equipment we see as passengers as we enter the secured area of an airport.
We know from press reports this week that there is not 100 per cent detection of weapons or explosives being transferred or carried into airplanes. The inspectors on a regular basis attempt to beat the system and they do. They are able to smuggle illegal weapons or explosives past security. It is not picked up in the x-rays. It is not picked up in the wand check. It is not picked up in any of the carry on baggage screening that is done. I do not fault the personnel that have been hired by the security companies, but when we recognize the kind of wages paid for this work we have to recognize that we are not putting our money where our mouths have been.
These people should not be contract employees of a security company employed by an airline under instructions from the Government of Canada. If this government were serious about ensuring the safety of people who travel on airplanes, those would be permanent Government of Canada employees who greet us at the security entrances to the lounges at our airports. Permanent personnel have the ability to add experience after experience after experience. They can become expert in spotting illegal activity and they can become expert in identifying shapes seen on the x-ray machine.
I have been amazed the times I have gone through security screening in Ottawa, Toronto, Vancouver, and Halifax by the number of objects that are not even queried. Batteries go through the x-ray and nobody says a word. Canisters that contain a soft drink go through, but that could easily carry something more deadly.
When contract personnel are used at low rates of pay-and we are talking $5, $6, $7 an hour-the chances are that those people will go off to other work because they cannot raise families on $6.50 an hour these days. In some provinces that is no longer minimum wage. Yet it is the level of pay being offered by contractors who have won the bid because of their lower tender and have perhaps put 50 or 60 existing workers out on the street and replaced them with a bunch of new trainees, new
Government Orders
people. We are just not putting the proper value on the lives of people who fly in our airplanes.
If the government really wants to be serious about aviation security, about ensuring that things can do damage to people or planes are not brought through security, then one of the best ways is to invest in permanent personnel who will provide that screening. It should not allow a privatized form of service to be provided or a revolving door kind of service. It should provide permanent employees of the Government of Canada with the training and expertise needed to ensure that airlines are safe.
As I said at the beginning we will support this bill, but let us be realistic. The government can do a lot more to ensure that our airlines are safe.
