speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and other acts in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to open the debate today on Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act.
The government has recognized the need to reform this law in order to make the system for granting pardons more efficient and to reduce delays and costs.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders

Our goal was to find a way to reform the system without disrupting the basic objectives. These include providing fair and timely service to eligible ex-offenders, creating a more efficient criminal record system and most important, ensuring public safety.
The present pardon system is under pressure because of rising numbers of applications and delays caused by a very cumbersome review, investigation and decisionmaking process. As a result there are backlogs, rising costs and delays in processing pardons for eligible offenders.
Because of cutbacks.

No, it is not because of any cutbacks.
As Solicitor General, I have endeavoured on several occasions to assist colleagues from all sides of the House to process what seems to all of us to be very insignificant pardon applications as quickly as possible so that people can get jobs and carry on with their lives long after infractions of the law have been dealt with. I have endeavoured wherever possible to assist my colleagues. The best way I can assist my colleagues is by straightening out this law. That is what we want to do.
The primary aim of a pardon is to remove as much as possible the negative consequences of having a criminal record after an appropriate period of time. In effect, it is designed to give ex-offenders a fresh start and have an opportunity to reintegrate into society. However, we recognize that a pardon should only be granted after offenders have served their sentences and enough time has elapsed to establish that with some degree of certainty they have in fact become law-abiding citizens.
The Criminal Records Act is not new legislation. In 1969 the Ouimet committee recognized the need for legislation that would ease the legal disabilities and social stigma of a criminal record. This was necessary to help ex-offenders who had demonstrated over an appropriate number of years that they could lead lives which were crime free. The committee's recommendations were largely responsible for the enactment of the original Criminal Records Act in 1970.
The Criminal Records Act formally recognizes that an individual who has satisfied the sentence imposed by the
courts and has gone on to become a responsible citizen should be granted a pardon.
A pardon granted through the Criminal Records Act removes the social and legal consequences of a conviction and symbolizes that an individual has successfully rejoined society.
However, it became clear as early as 1980 that there were deficiencies in the pardon system. Aside from a very cumbersome review process, which I have already referred to, law enforcement officers were unhappy with the complicated system of having to apply for access to sealed criminal records of pardoned offenders.
A revised structure for granting pardons was proposed in the form of a records management approach which would have operated in a manner similar to the highway demerit point system. With the passage of specified crime-free periods the ex-offenders' criminal records would have been gradually sealed and in time all records would have been sealed, therefore, preventing any disclosure of a criminal past.
This was a graduated approach which was a marked change from the more traditional concept of pardons where the Crown would grant a pardon based on exceptional circumstances existing in individual cases.
That type of pardon was a one-time exercise of mercy. It was felt that if we shifted away from this traditional concept of a pardon it would be more in keeping with the true intention of the Criminal Records Act which was designed to help as many eligible offenders as possible, not just one.
Another potential benefit of this approach was that administrative and investigative costs could have been cut without jeopardizing public safety.
Further legal changes were proposed in 1988 to deal in a limited way with specific abuses or issues relating to substance abuse.
The government has reviewed all of the various options for reform. We have also had the benefit of the work done by my colleague, the member for Mississauga South, who proposed and debated private member's Bill C-238, which touches on these issues.
May 5, 1992

We have consulted widely with affected organizations such as police groups, victims groups, offender assistance agencies and we have discussed the proposals which are before the House today with provincial government representatives.
We also had the assistance of the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General. The amendments I am proposing today will respond to many of the needs and concerns which were identified during these consultations, especially the need to ensure the safety and security of the Canadian public.
In this regard I am sure that we are all aware that just this morning the chairman of the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General reported back to the House with the amended Bill C-36 which proposes wide-ranging reforms of corrections and parole. We have had considerable assistance from all members of the House in getting that through committee stage rapidly. I am very optimistic that we will have an opportunity this week to send it to the Senate.
This week?

We have had the complete co-operation of my hon. friends and I know that they understand the public demands that are out there to move on this. However, if my hon. friends want to further delay reforms-
It's not delay; it's debate.
-which very much favour the rights of victims, I would regret that, but we are prepared to debate it and I would hope that common sense will prevail.
What pious nonsense.

An underlying principle of this bill however is the need to better distinguish between minor and serious offenders which includes the corresponding need to concentrate our resources on the most serious cases while preserving public protection.
A similar principle is going to apply to the Criminal Records Act. While these amendments would result in a less cumbersome system for all ex-offenders, there is a recognition that more serious offenders should wait a longer period before being pardoned.
Bill C-71 will give the National Parole Board authority under the Criminal Records Act to grant all pardons for all indictable offences. It will also give the National Parole Board authority to issue pardons for lesser offences, that is summary convictions as well. This will
Government Orders
relieve the necessity for a special committee of cabinet to review all pardons and will make the process much more efficient.
The bill proposes that the RCMP purge all discharges from the criminal record and therefore remove them entirely from the pardon process. This will take place after one year for absolute discharges and after three years for conditional discharges. These time intervals will allow the court access to relevant information should the offender continue to contravene the law in the interim.
This provision has long been suggested as a more equitable way to deal with discharges than the current system of an application for pardon when in fact the person has never really been convicted of any offence.
In keeping with the objectives of Bill C-36, we are also proposing the retention of five years of conviction-free good conduct as the criteria for a pardon for serious or indictable offences.
The government is also proposing to increase the waiting period from two to three years for less serious summary offences. However, ex-offenders in this category will not be subject to community investigations to check into what is referred to as "good conduct". At present eligibility for all pardons requires this type of determination. This is a burdensome process which is not always warranted particularly for the less serious offences.
Under this new amendment as long as ex-offenders live in the community with no new convictions during the waiting period, upon application a pardon will be granted and their records will be sealed. This will cut back on the time and money currently spent on investigation and review. It will also streamline the pardon-granting process for this categoiy of ex-offender.
I would like to emphasize that in neither case will the safety of the public be jeopardized. We will be developing additional guidelines identifying offences which will normally be the focus of an extensive investigation of good conduct before a decision is made to grant or deny a pardon. This group of offences would include offences causing personal harm, violence, sexual offences and serious drug offences.
By this approach, the government will be fulfilling its responsibilities for protection of the public. We believe very strongly the purpose of the Criminal Records Act should be to protect the privacy of those ex-offenders who have proven by their actions that they can lead crime-free lives in the community.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
Conversely, the government also believes that the act must never be used as a shield to protect any pardoned offender who is convicted of a new serious crime. For this reason, the bill will allow for the automatic revocation of pardons for offenders who commit further indictable offences. This will ensure easier court access to records for the purpose of sentencing repeat offenders.
The police, as we heard during the consultations that preceded the drafting of the bill, also need better access to the sealed records of pardoned offenders to help with their investigations.
The government has addressed this concern by including a provision to expand police access to identification information which is contained in the sealed records of pardoned offenders, for example, to help police identify fingerprints found at the scene of a crime.
Police requests for the disclosure of pardoned records on occasion have run into procedural delays which have lead to a prolonged investigation and a waste of police resources. In the interests of public safety, we have to ensure this does not happen in the future.
The act will stipulate that certain types of prohibitions or disqualifications such as a ban on owning firearms or disqualification from driving will not be lifted despite the granting of the pardon.
I believe it is imperative that if the courts have determined in the interests of public safety a person should not be allowed to drive a car for a certain period of time or to own a firearm then this prohibition has to remain in effect, regardless of the granting of a pardon for other offences and other purposes.

We propose to concentrate the measures for the investigation and decision-making process on the most serious cases. On the other hand, ex-offenders who are less of a risk to the public will be subject to a less exhaustive process.
Here again public safety is the most important consideration for us. This reform proposal takes a reasonable and balanced approach to issues of criminal justice. It is an approach that the public has been demanding and that my department and the government are committed to.

Finally in conclusion I move:
That Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and
other acts in consequence thereof, be referred to the Standing
Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Will those members who object to the motion please rise in their places?

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am not as familiar with the rules as I once was when I was House leader. Some in the Chamber might suggest I was never familiar with them. I believe the process now is to have somebody from the opposition second the motion to send this to the Standing Committee on Justice and Solicitor General's Affairs rather than two members from the government side.
That is why I specifically referred to the member for Scarborough West in my remarks.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: If an opposition member wishes to second the minister's motion, there is no problem.

Mr. Speaker, I have never been House leader, therefore I have even less experience with the rules than the hon. minister. However, from the Liberal point of view, the logical place for this bill to be examined is at the committee for Justice and the Solicitor General. Of course we would support that motion. In fact we wanted to make sure that occurred, since a reasonable degree of expertise has been developed in that particular committee.

It really does not matter to me who seconds the bill. The fact that it goes to the Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General is most important. If necessary I am prepared to second it.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Am I right in saying that the House unanimously supports the Solicitor General's motion?
Agreed.
Motion agreed to.

Mr. Speaker, I listened carefully to the Solicitor General of Canada in his opening remarks. I want to make it clear the motion I am seconding is the referral of this bill to the Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General.
We think it is important that we have an opportunity to discuss the principles this particular bill espouses.
I would just like to run through those principles and also discuss from my perspective a little bit of the history of this situation.
The proposed amendments to the Criminal Records Act as set out in Bill C-71 are stated to be structured to create a more effective pardons system; to improve service to increasing numbers of eligible ex-offenders; to achieve cost savings and reduce delays in the granting of pardons, and to address anomalies in the current act.
I think it is fair to say that most Canadians are in favour of a system permitting pardons. Most Canadians are in favour of a system that recognizes people do make mistakes and are entitled to get on with their lives after they have paid the appropriate price society has exacted for making those mistakes.
The Criminal Records Act has been around for quite some time as we heard from the hon. minister. There has been some agitation to amend the Criminal Records Act for some time, as well, particularly as it relates to those offences where there is a finding of guilt but no conviction for the purposes of the Criminal Code, and the punishment was an absolute discharge or a conditional discharge.
Government Orders
That was not the only problem with the Criminal Records Act but it was a major problem that had developed over the years.
The hon. member for Mississauga South, among many members, saw there was a problem and was lucky enough to have his private members' bill drawn from the hopper as it were, to be able to debate that bill.
That occurred on October 9, 1991. By sheer coincidence, I just happened to be in the House then. I made some remarks about what the hon. members' bill said, and pointed out what I considered to be potential anomalies. At that time, the hon. member for Crowfoot moved that the hon. member for Mississauga South withdraw his bill, and the subject matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General for study and recommendation to Parliament. That of course occurred. Again I repeat, it was referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General. Therein lies the thread of consistency to bring this bill to the Committee of Justice and the Solicitor General.
After that occurred presumably the wheels of government began to move. Someone began to look at the Criminal Records Act very seriously and decided that if the House said we had better look at this subject matter very seriously, perhaps the government should look at it very seriously.
I am assuming that, because there was no agitation with respect to the Criminal Records Act until after the hon. member had an opportunity to debate his bill in the House and the House made that unanimous recommendation.
It is time the Criminal Records Act was amended. There are a number of difficulties with it and this bill proposes to deal with quite a few of them. I would like to discuss in a general way some of the things the bill is going to do, and point out it is going to be very important for us in committee to examine this bill, short as it may be. It will have great ramifications on those people to whom pardons have been granted, to the types of jobs they are able to apply for, and the types of questions that may or may not be on application forms for employment. At the same time, it is going to affect the safety of the community at large.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
The bill will give authority under the Criminal Records Act to grant pardons to the National Parole Board. Right now it is extremely cumbersome because a special committee of cabinet grants these pardons presumably on the recommendation of the appropriate officials. This has bogged the system down terribly so that people who have applications for pardon are waiting an inordinate length of time beyond the time within which they are entitled to a pardon under the act. It is a veiy good proposal to give the job to the National Parole Board and take it out of the Special Committee of the Cabinet.
The second principle will be to purge, and I use the word advisedly because it is used in the headings of the bill, all discharges from the record. Absolute discharges will be purged after one year and conditional discharges after three years. Therefore they will be removed entirely from the pardons process. This is found in section 6 of the bill. In terms of the purge, we talked about removing discharges from the automated criminal convictions records retrieval system maintained by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. That is it.
The records are going to be removed from that system of the RCMP. We have a little difficulty here because we are really talking about federal legislation impacting on federal agencies. The RCMP is under the direction of the Solicitor General of Canada and this is a perfectly sensible section. However, there will be all sorts of information out there in the public record about absolute and conditional discharges that have been purged from the RCMP retrieval systems. There will be newspaper articles, other information such as notes in files and even the recollections of people as to what offences were committed, as one official said earlier when we were being briefed.
I think the bill will attempt to address that by limiting the uses to which this information can be put. The minister always has the discretion, in an appropriate case, to permit the use of the information.
That was one of the problems I had back in October 1991 when I pointed out that a person may be given an absolute discharge for a particular offence. One of the criteria for an absolute discharge is that the person is a first offender.
If the sentencing court does not know that person has received an absolute discharge before, it automatically
assumes he is a first offender even though he may have received an absolute discharge two, three, four times before for similar or different offences.
I do not know how that is going to be dealt with in the bill, other than within this discretionary application to the minister. That is one of the reasons why we have to study the bill carefully when it gets to the committee. However, I think that section is an attempt to deal with that potential anomaly, while at the same time ensuring the information is not generally available and not required to be disclosed after a specific period of time when it comes to discharges.
It retains five years of conviction-free good conduct as the criteria for pardon for serious offences. We have a problem with the definition of "serious offences". If you ask 295 members of this House of Commons what a serious offence is, you may very well get 295 different answers. What is a serious offence to one may not be quite as serious to another.
There may be a difficulty with respect to what serious offence means, and what is or is not a serious offence. We also have a technical problem with hybrid offences in the Criminal Code, or offences that can be proceeded with by way of summary conviction or indictment.
As I understand it-this remains to be seen-if a so-called serious offence is proceeded with by summary conviction as opposed to indictment, it suddenly becomes a non-serious offence. For example, it may be a hybrid offence if a person is charged with sexually assaulting an 11-year old girl.
Then it is up to the Crown to decide which way to proceed. If the Crown chooses to proceed by summary conviction, then I believe this bill will deem that to be a less serious offence for the purposes of the Criminal Records Act. That could very well be a problem.
It will increase the conviction-free period from two to three years for less serious offences, whatever that means. We will have to study that.
A community investigation of good conduct might be carried out. Of course it is permissive. It is not required. The Parole Board might carry out an investigation of what good conduct is. Will this end up simply being a rubber stamp? Will there be a mechanism to determine whether or not the person applying was in fact of good conduct for the last five years? That question has to be asked.

The bill will, apparently, automatically revoke pardons for offenders who commit further indictable offences. In other words, if you have received a pardon because society has forgiven you and then you go out and commit another indictable offence and are convicted of it, your pardon is revoked.
What about hybrid offences? What about an indictable offence that is treated as a summary conviction offence for the purposes of the Criminal Code and prosecution? Will that occur in this case? That question has to be asked in committee.
The bill will permit an expanded access for police to pardon records for identification purposes for fingerprints at crimes or accident scenes. On the face of it, that seems to be reasonable in helping the police with their investigations. Is it going to be an infringement of the rights of those people who have been pardoned? We will have to look at that very carefully.
It will stipulate in the act certain types of prohibitions or disqualifications, such as a ban on owning firearms or driving that would not be lifted until they expire, despite the granting of a pardon. That means that if someone has been prohibited from driving for 10 years but gets a pardon, presumably that prohibition against driving will not be revoked, even though the person has been pardoned. Is that fair or not? Is it discretionary, or mandatory? We do not know. The minister mentioned peripherally Bill C-36 and his great hopes for that bill. One of the interesting anomalies is that one of the clauses of Bill C-36, clause 109 I believe, gives absolute discretion to the National Parole Board to remove a prohibition against driving any time it wishes, quite apart from whether or not a sentencing court wishes that to be the case.
We have on the one hand this particular act saying; oh, no, just a minute, we do not have to revoke the prohibition against driving even though we give a pardon, and yet another bill in another place permits the National Parole Board, for whatever reasons it sees fit, to overrule whatever a sentencing court did and remove that prohibition against driving, with no appeal to anybody, because the National Parole Board has the final word.
Government Orders
What is the relationship between the Criminal Records Act and its so-called requirement that these prohibitions continue, and Bill C-36 which gives the National Parole Board the absolute jurisdiction to remove these prohibitions? I see some conflict. How is that going to work? Which is going to take precedence?
I would suggest that the permissive section of Bill C-36, which also deals with the National Parole Board, will have precedence or the board will assume that it has precedence under that. That is a potential conflict that we can deal with in committee. The point is that it has to go to committee to deal with these various anomalies that are coming up.
It is important, however, that we do modernize and bring up to date the Criminal Records Act because of the vast numbers of people who are making application. The system has, in fact, bogged down. There is no doubt about that.
The Liberal Party is quite content to have this bill come forward, quite content to have it go to the Standing Committee on Justice and the Solicitor General, and have it studied very, very carefully and then make whatever recommendations the committee may make to Parliament.
Interestingly enough the minister bootlegged a few minutes of his time to talk about Bill C-36 and how he thought it would come before the House. Of course it would be passed lickety-split and there should be no problems. I want to assure the minister that having spent three and a half months of my life working on that bill in the justice and solicitor general committee that we will be taking a very active part in the discussion of Bill C-36 in this House. We in the Liberal Party are as committed as anyone to the protection of society, to the rights of victims, to fairness and equity for inmates and offenders. However, a bill such as Bill C-36 is no mean piece of legislation; it is very complex. We are certainly going to take our time and discuss the bill for the length of time that we think is appropriate to make sure that we do justice to all of the parts of Canada and the peoples of Canada who are affected by that bill. Indeed everybody in Canada either directly or indirectly is affected by that bill.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
There is some overlap between the principles of Bill C-36 and the Criminal Records Act. I do not think that one necessarily follows the other, and the principles that were enunciated by the minister with respect to the Criminal Records Act stand alone. I do not tie support to the Criminal Records Act or Bill C-71, in whatever form it may be after the committee looks at it, to support for Bill C-36.1 think it is quite consistent to be able to look at both bills separately, although there are some crossstreams.
Having said that we in the Liberal Party are content, as I say, to have the bill referred to the committee, to have it studied carefully, and then to make whatever decision we as a committee believe is appropriate.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise in my place today to discuss very briefly at second reading Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
The amendments proposed in this rather slim bill are long overdue. My party and I welcome the streamlining proposed within Bill C-71 that will go into effect when the bill is passed in respect of a person attempting to gain a pardon. I think I speak on behalf of virtually every MP in this House who has acted on behalf of a constituent who was seeking a pardon. The system in seeking that pardon seemed inordinately long, inordinately delayed.
Sometimes a constituent would come to me with a record that dated back 10 or 12 years. A person now in his early thirties committed a crime in his mid or late teens and is prevented either from entering the United States of America or more important, prevented from gainful employment or employment of a different kind if he or she wishes to change his or her job.
It seemed to me that the wheels just got stuck, that somewhere in the system the application for pardon was not lost but it was placed somewhere and it simply did not get through. Then of course I think the system placed a considerable burden on some members of cabinet. Very often the ministers of the past perhaps were not quite fast enough, at least in my opinion as an opposition member, in putting their signatures to these pardon applications and making them valid.
Having said all that, I very briefly want to draw members' attention to an anomaly that is in this bill. I am not faulting the government so much. I think it is almost an insurmountable problem. Really what this bill talks about is a record of convictions. It really does not relate to a record of criminality, a criminal record as such.
The hon. member for Scarborough West, who spoke just before me alluded to this in his remarks. When a crime is committed and a person is charged, no matter how heinous that crime may be or how less serious a crime it might be, the police in first instance begin to acquire a dossier on that person. This is a normal, natural procedure. There are all kinds of written notes made by police investigating officers. There are notes made by lawyers. There are articles in newspapers, et cetera. There is a record of that person's alleged criminal behaviour even prior to the trial.
Then of course there are records of the trial itself and there are records of the conviction. If I understand this bill correctly, what we are really dealing with here today is only the record of conviction and only in so far as that record relates to the federal authority, the Solicitor General's office. We are dealing here principally, if not exclusively, with the RCM Police and its computer on records of conviction.
Unless I stand corrected, I do not want the impression to go outside of this Chamber today to the people who are watching it on television or who might read about it in some obscure article in tomorrow's newspapers that for some reason or other even though they were granted a discharge, there will still be a record of their alleged criminality somewhere, some place in the system or criminal justice systems of this country. Whether it is in an archives, a court library or in a police station, it is there.
I do not know how we can expunge that kind of record quite frankly. I do not know how we can order a cop who investigated a crime five years ago to forget about all the details of that investigation. I do not know whether it would even be appropriate if a legislative body such as ours were to order that police department to destroy the dossier or the records.
It is a troubling matter for me. I do not have a criminal record of any kind. I know people who do. When I say a criminal record, the only criminal record I have maybe is having run for Parliament.
May 5, 1992

The point is that there are people who have been investigated, who have been charged, who have been granted an absolute or conditional discharge for a very relatively minor offence but they still have a criminal record. We know they still have a criminal record. I do not know how we go about getting rid of that criminal record.
This bill will purge a computer of a record of criminal convictions. That is all it will do. I think that that is unfortunate but I do not know how we can solve the problem. Hopefully when it goes to committee some of the experts may be able to shed some light on this. Maybe the problem is in fact unsolveable. I do not know.
There are a lot of people in our country today who are very upset that they still have a record of their alleged criminality when in fact in some cases they were given an absolute discharge. I am not a lawyer but I think that means that there was never really a charge in the first place. There should not be any reference to that police investigation when there was an absolute discharge granted to that person. There was in fact no crime committed. I think that is what it means in law. Yet there is still a record somewhere of that arrest, of that person being charged and of that person having to go to court and so on.
If the committee decides that this bill does not go far enough and that we have the constitutional right and power to force police departments, the offices of Crown prosecutors and the various judicial bodies in the country to get rid of all written records where a conditional or an absolute discharge has been granted, that is another matter and that probably should be introduced at the committee stage.
There is one other point that I want to make here and that is criminal records and their relationship with employment opportunities. On job applications the federal government, its agencies and government contractors can only ask if the candidate "has been convicted of an offence for which a pardon has not yet been granted". Any other organization, company or employer can ask whether or not you have a record, period. They do not even have to say criminal record, it is implied.
A young fellow comes in for a job. The prospective employer says: okay, fine, this is fine and that is fine. "Do you have a record?" We all know what he means by that question. If he has been granted a conditional or an absolute discharge, he should be able to say: "No, I do
Government Orders
not have a record". I do not know whether he is telling the truth there or not because there is a record of some criminal behaviour somewhere, notwithstanding the fact that he has been granted either an absolute discharge or a conditional discharge.
Records of convictions for which a pardon was granted are kept separate and apart from the main computer information banks, but the minister can still release some information if he thinks that it is relevant for some jobs. A very good example of this, and I am not arguing against this, is the Solicitor General might inform a kindergarten or a school board that a job applicant has been convicted and pardoned or is a convicted and pardoned child molester if he concludes that there are reasonable grounds to believe that despite the pardon the individual still poses a threat. I think that part of it is reasonable and acceptable. I think society would support that, I am quite convinced.
On the other hand, as in the examples I used before, I know that there is a lot of frustration out there in the community.
The minister's backgrounder states: "A pardon recognizes that an individual has gone on to become a responsible citizen. A pardon removes the social and legal consequences of a conviction". The above example might be clear-cut, but who is to say that one has not been passed up for a government job or contract because they protested for example a peace demonstration at Goose Bay or were trespassing during the Oka crisis. Ministerial biases and prejudices remain as yet undefined. In other words, we pardon but only to a point. Again, we are all human. I am not singling out any one minister or any one minister of a political party or a particular government, but these things can happen. We are capable of frailty. We are capable of error.
Another point I want to raise at this time has to do with criminal records and international travel. We are very proud to say that we peacefully share a confidence with the world's most powerful nation that there are no guns along the border, no military defence and weaponry along our border which is 5,000 miles long, I have the impression that the world's greatest country, the United States of America, but also the world's most violent country, certainly in the western industrialized world, is aggressively concerned about allowing Canadian citizens into that country who have a criminal record, even though those citizens have probably lived many years

Government Orders
lawfully, in a law-abiding way, causing nobody any problems.
I know that this is a problem and has been for all governments where a person in his teens, an example I mentioned a while ago, commits an indictable offence when he is young, serves his time, comes out, rehabilitates himself, works, achieves a pardon and gets a job as a truck driver. He drives his truck across the border into the United States. He gives his name, ID and so. It is punched up on the computer. Bingo. The pardon is not there, or if it is, it is overlooked, but the criminal record is there.
How many times must a person pay for his crime? This man stands to lose his job in this case. No employer is going to employ a trucker regularly who cannot drive in the United States. How many times must this person pay for his crime?
I know we do not control the American immigration service and we cannot pass laws that are applicable in the United States, but surely while we are discussing this bill the committee should make recommendations that the government try to enter into some kind of international reciprocal agreement with the United States to make certain that every effort is made on its part and on our part that the situation I just mentioned, that the pardon would be sufficient to allow that person to go across the border, whether it is for business or for pleasure.
I have a case right now where a young man in his late twenties, I believe, cannot even visit his parents who have a winter place in Florida. He was convicted. He served his time. He has received a pardon and he still cannot go.
For me, it seems rather ironic. I mentioned a moment ago the United States is a nation that is almost overwhelmed at times with street violence. We saw the example of L.A. It is coming here, unfortunately. I hope we can do something about it. We had riots in Toronto just yesterday. Yet it is so meticulous about keeping out somebody who did his time, paid his debt to society, has been working lawfully for many years, and is still denied access to its country, in this case for business purposes.
I am not going to delay this procedure at second reading. I would hope when the bill goes to committee that some of my concerns and the concerns of the member for Scarborough West will be fully investigated. I want to hear more information from the experts, from the civil servants, or from anybody else who has some input here. I would respectfully submit that this bill, while it certainly is acceptable at this stage, at second reading, needs some fine tuning.
In the spirit in which the minister spoke when he was on his feet a few moments ago with respect to Bill C-36 we have had not a flood, but we have had a series of law bills come before this House in the past several months. We know it is part of a package that the government is presenting. Part of that package is a public relations job, and part of that public relations job is some kind of a message to the people of Canada that this government is going to get tough on criminals. It is going to get tough on crime. It is going to do everything it can to beat the crime problem in this country.
I will be speaking on Bill C-36 later this week but I want to mention here and now that I hope we are not kidding ourselves that by tinkering with legislation, by altering a clause here, by changing a sentence there, by replacing a word somewhere else, that we can somehow honestly argue that these changes will reduce or have a significant impact on the diminishing of crime in our country.
One of the first witnesses to come before us was a representative of one of the police associations in this country, one who gave his expertise to the committee on Bill C-36 but it applies to all of these bills. I asked him if Bill C-36, corrections and conditional releases, goes through will it make our streets safer. His answer was no. One of the last witnesses we heard in Edmonton, another police officer, a rather senior inspector, I put the same question to him and his answer was no.
The first police officer before us, the one I alluded to a moment ago, went on to include in his brief that the major causes of crime in this country were poverty, depravation, lack of education and training, violence in the home, violence in the neighbourhood, cultural depravation, hopelessness and helplessness, mainly among
May 5, 1992

Government Orders

the poor with no skills, no jobs, alcoholism, drug abuse and so on.
I know that we cannot put all of these into one neat little bundle and write it up in one nice, neat little bill and pass it and say: "Okay, fine, we are going to embark upon a program to really get at the solution". It is not one bill. It is an attitude that government has to accept, an attitude we on this side of the House have to accept. There are no quick fixes legislatively. We have to begin to change the fundamental environment of our cities and the way we live and our lifestyles. That is when we really begin to tackle crime.
I hope the government will end its series of introducing law bills by announcing a massive public relations campaign. It does not have to be expensive. It should be a public relations campaign, an honest one, a campaign to instil in the minds and hearts of our citizens that crime is a terrible thing. There are all kinds of things we can do ourselves to begin to reduce the crime rate in our towns and cities across this country from coast to coast.
The other side of the coin is what the Americans have been doing for 25 years and it is not working. They have been building more and bigger prisons and putting more people behind bars and executing more murderers. Yet their crime rate is running out of control. If ever we needed an example, a living model of what not to do, we have it to the south of us.
I am not damning them or condemning them. I just hope that they too will get their thinking turned around and really make the effort that is needed to tackle the main and the major causes of crime in their country as I hope we will in ours.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think you will find unanimous consent to revert to tabling of reports from committees in order to allow the hon. member for Markham-Whitchurch-Stouffville to table the report of Legislative Committee E on Bill C-53.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Members have heard the terms of the request. Is there unanimous consent?
Agreed.

subtopic: BILL C-53 REPORT OF LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE
BILL C-53 REPORT OF LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since there has been unanimous consent of the House to revert to presenting reports from committees, I wish to present the report of the Legislative Committee on Bill C-53, an act to provide for the imposition of special economic measures.
[Editor's Note: See today's Votes and Proceedings.]

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Lewis that Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and other acts in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and Solicitor General.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Monique Tardif (Parliamentary Secretary to Solicitor General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Solicitor General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity today to take part in the debate at second reading on Bill C-71, which proposes to amend the Criminal Records Act.
First I would like to say that the changes proposed by the government are a direct consequence of a number of serious concerns about the pardon granting process. These concerns were raised by members speaking on behalf of their constituents or as individual members, and by representatives of the penal justice system in general. What are these problems and what is the government's response?
As parliamentarians we have all at times been asked by constituents to accelerate the granting of a pardon. Generally a pardon was sought by a person who had been living in the community for many years as a law abiding

Government Orders
citizen and needed a pardon to get a job or for other personal reasons.
We have all felt the frustration caused by a waiting period of up to a year and a half, even in the most straightforward cases where the applicant obviously deserved a pardon.
We were equally frustrated when we saw that a person who had been discharged by the court and consequently was not convicted of an offence had to apply for a pardon later on to have the reference to the discharge erased from the record.
This anomaly was brought to our attention quite recently by the hon. member for Mississauga South in his private Member's Bill C-238.
Why do the inquiry and decision, in the case of a law-abiding citizen with a minor offence on his record that goes back many years, take just as long as for a person previously convicted of serious crimes of violence? This does not make sense.
Furthermore, why should a person who was never convicted of an offence have to spend time and money to obtain a pardon, when he was granted a discharge by the courts? This does not make sense either, especially since the pardon is invariably granted, but only after a process involving considerable delay and inquiry costs for the government.
The government has responded to these concerns and relevant observations with Bill C-71.
Perhaps I may explain briefly how the legislation will correct these problems.
Because of the present unwieldy process, which in each case involves an inquiry and a decision, there is a substantial backlog of applications which is steadily increasing.
A statistical study of the pardon system has shown that between 1989 and 1990, the number of applications increased by 261 per cent, from 7,100 annually to 25,000.
Meanwhile, the system's processing capacity has remained relatively unchanged. The National Parole Board and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police are able to process about 10,000 cases annually.
In the past, before making a recommendation, each applicant was checked for good conduct and whether he
had an indictable offence on his record. Subsequently, the case had to be reviewed by cabinet before a decision could be made.
Consequently, if certain changes are made, we will be able to eliminate the delay caused by cabinet review of all applications, and the Governor in Council will no longer have to review some 10,000 applications annually.
At the present time, a person who has been discharged must submit an application for pardon to make sure his record is sealed, even if he was not convicted of an offence.
Under the present legislation, he can apply for a pardon for a summary conviction one year after being discharged, and after three years for an indictable offence.
After the considerable time required to conduct the inquiry and make a decision, the pardon is invariably granted and the records are sealed.
Subsequently, the records cannot be consulted either by the public or the courts, unless an application is made and disclosure is authorized by the minister.
In the case of a discharge, requests and decisions to unseal the records are very rare, if they occur at all.
The government has decided that records will be automatically sealed either one or three years after the date of discharge, depending on whether it was an absolute or a conditional discharge, thus obviating the need to submit a request or conduct an inquiry.
As a result, about 5,000 applications for pardon will be eliminated every year, which represents about 16 per cent of all pardons currently processed. Resources could then be concentrated on the most serious cases, without jeopardizing public safety.
Some have suggested that this automatic provision apply sooner than the present proposal calls for. The government believes that it is necessary to keep the information on the period in question. The parole can thus be reviewed by the court if the offender immediately commits another offence and continues a life of crime.
The government also examined the case of persons found guilty of a summary offence or one of a less serious nature. Under the present system, a person must have committed no criminal act in the community for a certain period before applying for a pardon. In addition,
May 5, 1992

a community investigation is required to determine the applicant's good conduct.
After the time required to conduct this investigation, the pardon is granted and the basic condition requiring the applicant to have committed no criminal offence and to have received no conviction is considered sufficient for determining his status.
Even though it is unnecessary to conduct in-depth interviews in the community, the delay involved in a discretionary decision complicates the system and delays the process.
The government therefore decided to increase the ineligible period from two to three years for summary offences and to simply require that the applicant was not convicted of any offence in that period to prove that he is law-abiding.
It will no longer be necessary to base the decision on a judgment of good conduct in addition to the condition that the applicant was convicted of no offence during the waiting period.
With this amendment, the government will eliminate 3,500 more applications a year that would be subject to a discretionary decision and will thus speed up the process. Such applications account for about 11 per cent of the cases processed now.
If an ex-offender commits an indictable offence after being pardoned, the pardon will automatically be revoked. If he commits an offence punishable on summary conviction, the minister can open the criminal records for the courts for the purposes of sentencing.
Note that fewer than a hundred applications a year are refused at present. Refusals related to an investigation of good conduct all apply to persons with more serious crimes on their record.
These are the crimes that particularly concern Canadians and the government decided to concentrate its investigative and decision-making resources on this aspect.
Once again, investigating an applicant's reputation on the basis of vague information has proven to be an extra requirement that is not needed to ensure that an ex-offender has not been convicted.
Government Orders
Here are some statistics illustrating this point.
Although some 1,700 community investigations are conducted each year, only 71 applications for pardon are refused on the basis of these investigations. That is a rate of 4 per cent.
The government believes that Canadians would be better protected if the resources for community investigations were used for ex-offenders with more serious crimes or offences on their record.
In particular, the government will provide for investigations if the board believes that it needs more information before making a decision on a crime.
Thorough investigations will be required for all pardon applicants who have committed violent crimes, sex offences and serious drug-related offences.
Before I conclude, let me add that I think the changes are clearly a happy medium between the various proposals discussed before.
These changes will be discussed further in committee and perhaps improved, but I believe that they are an effective response to the various problems of the present system that have become obvious for us all.
I think that after they take a close look at the changes we propose to make to the Criminal Records Act, all hon. members will conclude that these changes are meant to make the pardon granting system more efficient, to improve the service given to a growing number of ex-offenders eligible for a pardon, to save money and to reduce delays in granting these pardons.
With these amendments the government can achieve these objectives and still protect the integrity of the system and continue to protect Canadians from offenders who have chosen to pursue their criminal activities.
This is what the government had in mind when it drew up these changes. I believe that adopting them will make it possible for all of us to reach the goal we have set.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise to debate further the issues contained in Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and other acts in consequence thereof.

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
I want to say right off the bat that my colleagues on this side of the House and I accept as good and prudent the matters that are contained in the bill.
The bill addresses a problem that had developed over the years and was made apparent by interventions of a number of members of the House of Commons. My only minor criticism is that it took so long to effect such a minor change.
Having said that, there was another issue which became apparent to many of us in this House. That was the delay that was developing in the granting of pardons under the Criminal Records Act.
There were many people who were prima facie entitled to the pardons. They deserved them under the terms of the legislation, but it was taking a long time, in many cases upwards or in excess of one year to deal with the pardon, thereby preventing the applicant from getting on with aspects of his or her life that would have required the pardon. This bill attempts to deal with that.
This area of criminal records and the amendments here, the approach taken by the government, is a little bit like putting a foot into a worn-out shoe and patching it. I have had an opportunity to read this bill several times since being elected three years ago.
I am of the view that the bill is extremely weak. I think that the bill had its roots in a previous Liberal government, but this bill does not do the job. It is extremely weak. I want to point that out for the record. Hopefully the committee that takes this bill will be able to address some of these problems. I know the Solicitor General has been listening of late. Not quite a death bed repentance but the new Solicitor General has been listening to the justice committee and listening to Canadians. I do not want to give too much credit, sitting in opposition here, but I certainly want to give credit where credit is due.
The bill does, in band-aid fashion, address the problem of conditional discharges where individuals who were discharged at trial following conviction, either absolutely or conditionally, were still required under the existing legislation to go back and get a pardon for an offence which the Criminal Code says was deemed never to have been committed. That is a little bit like catch-22
in 1984. This bill does address that. Now those who have been discharged subject to a waiting period which will expire automatically will not have a criminal record, as was originally intended by the discharge sections of the Criminal Code. Well, good for them.
The other thing it will do is it will revoke automatically a pardon which was given under the statute where the individual involved subsequently commits an indictable offence. If you have been a good guy, good for you; if you commit an indictable offence after a pardon has been given, back to square one, your conviction is reinstated. That is quite fair and appropriate.
On a procedural basis, the National Parole Board has been given jurisdiction and authority to administer and grant the pardons. That will obviate the need to send all of those pieces of paper to cabinet to get the signatures of ministers and all of the procedure that is involved in there. That is appropriate. It is a good fit.
However, here is what is missing. I want to start with the title of this bill because the title does not even fit. The name of the bill is the Criminal Records Act. I want to say that the bill does not deal with the management of criminal records. It never did. It never had the intention to.
It is a bill to get rid of the criminal record, to use layman's parlance. That is what the bill is for. It should have been called the pardons act or the pardon of a criminal act or a record of conviction, something along those lines. The title was not a fit from that perspective.
There is another problem. As I stand here, I do not understand why the bill-keep in mind, we are dealing with what the bill calls criminal records-does not define what a criminal record is. That is of absolutely no help to those who administer the act. In fact, it is a hindrance and, as I hope to point out, a serious fatal flaw in achieving under the bill what I think everyone wanted to achieve many years ago. The bill does not contain a definition.
In addition to not having a definition of what a criminal record is, a bill dealing with criminal records, the bill also deals with pardons. What else does the bill not have? It does not have a definition of what a pardon is.
May 5, 1992

Not only does the bill fail to address precisely what it is dealing with in terms of criminal records but it also does not even define what it is dealing with when it talks about a pardon. These are serious fatal flaws.
In fact if we go back to the title, we used the term criminal records in questioning the officials about this bill last week. It became apparent that what we were really talking about under this bill were not criminal records. We were talking about what is called a record of conviction. Keep in mind that when somebody gets implicated under the Criminal Code there are all kinds of records of the criminality. There are the charges laid, the disposition of the court, police reports, recommendations to the prosecutor, the sentencing decision. There are a whole lot of criminal records.
That is not what this bill is dealing with. This bill is trying to deal with what we call the record of conviction. This bill does not even mention record of conviction. It never comes up, never, even though the term record of conviction in a specific, simple one-page form in the Criminal Code is sitting right in there, that is the record of conviction.
It is a bit of an absurdity that the act we call the Criminal Records Act does not define pardon, does not define criminal record, and does not even deal with criminal records. It deals with records of conviction. I let that stand and hopefully the committee can deal with that.
What happens under this bill when an undefined pardon is given? The expectation of the citizen is that the record of conviction, not the criminal records, but the record of conviction will be purged from the system. It is a fact that records of conviction and copies of records of conviction are contained all over Canada in court houses, in municipal police force offices and with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, which maintains a registry for that purpose.
The registry is called CPIC and is a record keeping system that the RCMP retains. It keeps a record of all the convictions that it manages to get its hands on across the country. It also keeps track of all the other criminal records, records of the criminal procedure, not just records of conviction.
It is a fact that not all records of conviction are given to the RCMP.
I see, Mr. Speaker, you might like to interrupt at this point. We can continue the debate later.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
It being one o'clock, I do now leave the chair until two o'clock this afternoon, pursuant to Standing Order 24(2).
The House took recess at 1 p.m.

AFTER RECESS

The House resumed at 2 p.m.

Mr. Speaker, the tragic events in Toronto should not distract us from the root causes of what ails our large cities: namely, the sense of despair and aimlessness that results from inadequate social and economic support measures for the poor, the young, and the uneducated.
Intensive measures are needed on rehabilitation from drug addiction, on the dangers posed by drugs, on education, on youth training, on apprenticeship and employment, on social housing. Race relations must be the object of an intensive educational campaign. The government must create an appropriate social and economic climate to ensure that social turmoil and unrest do not occur in Canada. We in the opposition call on the government to address these problems as a matter of urgency and to take all the necessary measures with great speed.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to take the opportunity provided by National Trees and Forests Week to mention a new program put forward by Forestry Canada as part of Canada's green plan. Tree Plant Canada is an innovative tree planting initiative. A dozen Canadian cities will launch the program regionally throughout National Trees and Forests Week. The planned activities will bring together Canadians and the public and private sectors to make a

May 5, 1992
direct contribution to improving environmental quality by planting trees in communities across Canada.

Mr. Speaker, water levels in the northwest part of Saskatchewan are disturbingly low. Community water resources, agricultural production, fish stocks, wildlife habitats, and tourism initiatives are all in jeopardy because of low water levels downstream from Cold Lake in the Pierce-land and Goodsoil areas of my province.
Officials from Alberta Environment and the Saskatchewan Water Corporation confirmed that the winter snowfall this past year was not sufficient to compensate for the evaporation expected off the surface water this summer.
Water has been withdrawn from Cold Lake and the underground aquifers which flow into and under Cold Lake to accommodate a heavy oil extraction plant on the Alberta side of the border. Many people are now blaming this withdrawal for the lower than usual water levels on the Saskatchewan side.
In light of the serious nature of this situation on fish, wildlife, and people I today call on the Minister of Fisheries to launch a full review of this intra-provincial water conflict to ensure the causes are determined and solutions are found and enacted.

Mr. Speaker, today fire-fighters from across Canada are meeting with their members of Parliament to discuss important issues relating to their profession. They have come to Ottawa to voice their concerns and offer suggestions regarding pension and compensation benefits as well as ways of controlling risks to fire-fighters associated with infectious diseases and hazardous materials.
Fire-fighters risk their lives daily in their efforts to save the lives and property of their fellow citizens. Fire-fighting is one of the nation's most dangerous occupations and men and women who enter this profession do so in service to Canada.
I encourage all members of Parliament to return the care and compassion shown by our fire-fighters by giving them the time and attention they need to share their views and concerns with us on these important issues. Let us all salute and thank the fire-fighters of Canada for their work on behalf of their fellow citizens.

Mr. Speaker, the regrettable incidents in Los Angeles and Toronto remind us how fortunate we are to live in such a magnificent city.
Thke for example the Ottawa Police Force in my riding. The Ottawa police are sensitive to the needs of local minority groups. They have developed a number of programs to promote race relations. For example, the force celebrates March 21, the United Nations International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discord, with a police community multicultural reception.
Aboriginal and visible minority youths interested in pursuing a police career are encouraged under the Police Minority Youth Program and with a scholarship from the Ottawa Police Services Board.
Thanks to the leadership of Chief Tom Flanagan and his officers, the force will be participating in a symposium on Parliament Hill this weekend entitled Strengthening the Dialogue. The conference will bring together representatives from ethnic minority groups and members of the Ottawa-Carleton area Police Community Council.
Congratulations and keep up the good work.

Mr. Speaker, several days ago, the Conservative Minister of National Defence and member for Frontenac awarded a billion dollar contract for the purchase of military helicopters in the greater Montreal region.
Many federal Liberal and NDP members complained about what the Conservative minister did. No one complained when the Conservative government announced last year that a billion dollar communications
May 5, 1992

system for the armed forces would be built in Western Canada.
Today Quebec is still perceived by many as Ottawa's favorite in awarding the most lucrative military contracts. Alex Morrison, director of the Canadian Institute of Strategic Studies, an independent organization of experts in Toronto, believes that is a false perception. Apparently to the member for Frontenac a job is a job and a dollar is a dollar, says the retired colonel. In the past few years, I have not seen many people fight for their province in such a way.
By his action the Conservative minister and member for Frontenac is helping Montreal, Quebec and Canada.
A Canadian is a Canadian!

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Petro-Canada chairman Bill Hopper, affectionately known as "Two Limousine Bill", has just announced the layoff of yet another 1,200 people at Petro-Canada by the end of the year.
Not only does Petro-Canada contribute to tin-pot dictators in Myanmar, it appears that this company now seems to be practising Burmese-style labour relations on its own employees. While chairman Bill Hopper and his cronies are enjoying the good life, Petro-Canada workers are sent out to pasture.
This sounds an awful lot like Tory justice.

Mr. Speaker, in the Indian world the naming ceremony is one of the highest honours one can receive. On the weekend, George Saddleback performed the ceremony in Jasper, Alberta for the Samson Crees of the Four Nations in Hobbema.
The constitutional affairs minister, was given a chief's head-dress and the Cree name "Mikisu", Chief Bald Eagle. I welcome Mikisu to the Cree tribe and ask this
House to join me in congratulating the minister for his well deserved honour.
The naming ceremony was in part thanks for his 20 years of outstanding service to Canada. May the Bald Eagle spirit give him vision, wisdom, courage and strength as he continues to work for Canada. It is because of men like him that we are number one in the world.

This year, 1992, the city of Nepean, Ontario, is celebrating its 200th anniversary. Nepean's history began in 1792 when land was granted to an Irish veteran of the American revolutionary war, George Hamilton.
Historian Dr. Bruce Elliot describes how Nepean's past generations moulded the nation's capital. Much of present-day Ottawa was once part of Nepean which is older than Ottawa itself.
The construction of the Parliament Buildings began in 1859. Much of the sandstone used to construct the Parliament Buildings was quarried near Bells Comers in Nepean. The growth of the timber trade, the importance of milk production, its survival of the great fire of 1870, the birth of the streetcar suburbs, speculative land booms are all a part of Nepean's past.
Today it is a city of 108,000 residents and over 2,100 businesses.
I along with the city fathers, its businesses and residents am happy to join in the celebration of Nepean's 200th anniversary and Canada's 125th birthday.

Mr. Speaker, one of the most troubling events in recent Canadian history happened last night. Hundreds of people rioted in Toronto in what police officers described as sheer anarchy. The crowd smashed windows, looted stores along Yonge Street and clashed with police.
In some ways, it was a reaction to what some members of the black community feel is a systemic bias against them by the legal and justice system. In other ways it was a crass copycat demonstration after media saturation of

May 5, 1992
the Los Angeles violence last weekend. In still other ways it was merely the hooligan action of a disruptive gang of young thugs.
Whatever the reason, the results are the same: Just like in L.A., there are no winners out of an action like this, only losers. People get hurt, stores get robbed, relations with the police deteriorate, an ethnic community gets stereotyped and nothing gets resolved.
I urge that the violence not be repeated; that community leaders show responsibility and that everybody respect the streets of Toronto, one of the greatest cities in the world.

Last week a Nova Scotia woman who fled with her baby from her abusive partner was murdered by him. She had called the police. She had laid charges. He broke her bones. He received probation, and later, only a month in jail for a subsequent charge. She stated publicly: "I'm scared for my life". She, like too many other women was not taken seriously.
Last November the Ontario NDP government launched the first ever wife assault education campaign to focus attention on men's and community responsibility for ending violence. Seventy-two per cent of the men surveyed said they were influenced to take responsibility for their actions as a result of these ads.
Today the Ontario government has launched a media campaign on sexual assault to sensitize the public, police and professionals that every sexual assault is serious, that every sexual assault is a crime.
I call upon the Minister of Justice to implement mandatory gender sensitivity training for the judiciary so that the public, the police and professionals understand that violence against women cannot be tolerated and must be stopped before more women die.

Mr. Speaker, it is not all bad news out there. In fact there is some rather good news that has to be told.
There are signs that our policies of fighting inflation and deficit reduction are producing positive results, particularly for Atlantic Canada. Statistics Canada reports that Atlantic Canada had an over-all growth rate of 1.8 per cent, outperforming the entire country last year, with New Brunswick experiencing remarkable growth, posting a 2.1 per cent increase, the best in the country.
When it comes to having money left over after paying your taxes, that is the growth of disposable income, New Brunswick was second best at 4.9 per cent, exceeded only by British Columbia at 5.2 per cent. The Royal Bank is predicting even stronger growth this year. That is good news for Canada and that is good news for New Brunswick. That is proof that our policies are working.

Mr. Speaker, all of us watched with horror the events in Los Angeles and in Toronto, but unfortunately institutionalized sexism and racism are all too rampant even today. Consider the case of Professor Gordon Freeman who, in a study that was published by the Canadian Journal of Physics, funded by the National Research Council, states:
Working mothers are the root of most evils facing society today- from drug abuse to family violence and culminating in Marc Lepine's massacre of 14 women at the Universite de Montreal's Ecole Polytechnique.
This same professor claims that the absence of fulltime mothering is leading to day care children who "have very little chance of becoming normal productive adults".
This is not a flake, this is a professor at a respected Canadian university and a professor whose works have actually been published in a Canadian journal. It is little wonder that my daughter and other young boys and girls are growing up facing the kinds of statements that lead them to wonder what is their role in an equal Canadian society.
May 5, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the Canadian Association of Elizabeth Fry Societies is a federation of autonomous, community based organizations. They work on behalf of women in conflict with the law.
These quiet organizations are dedicated to offering services and programs to women in need while presenting the public a forum with which to advocate reforms of the justice system as it affects Canadian women.
The work of the Elizabeth Fry Society can be thankless. I want to take this opportunity to commend this association for their tremendous contribution to Canadian society.

Mr. Speaker, Monday's riot in Toronto partly expressed the anger of young people, especially young people of colour, who feel shut out of Canadian society and Canadian justice. They have reason to feel shut out not only in Canada but in the whole world.
Studies in Canada show that young people have extra high unemployment and that people of colour do not have a fair chance at good jobs.
Recent changes of immigration rules by North Atlantic countries mainly restrict people of colour from entering Europe or North America. Twenty per cent of the world's people, mostly white, consume over 82 per cent of the world's goods leaving the big majority of the world to go hungry.
In four decades, millions of persons of colour were killed in wars fought mainly with weapons sold by white people.
I ask my fellow members of Parliament, mostly white males like me, if these numbers were reversed what would we do.
Oral Questions TORONTO RIOT

Mr. Speaker, the violence that occurred in Toronto yesterday proves that these things do not just happen in Los Angeles.
The looting, the assaults, the vandalism were senseless. They appear to have grown out of but to be unrelated to the peaceful demonstration that preceded them.
Unfortunately, they undermined and detracted from the real message of the original peaceful demonstration. That message, the message of Los Angeles is the need for all of us to ensure, not just pay lip service, to the principle of equal treatment for everyone and also the need to narrow the gap between the more and the less advantaged in our society. If we do not heed that message everyone will be a loser.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Last night Canadians were shocked and horrified to see a small group of vandals take advantage of a peaceful demonstration to go on a rampage in downtown Toronto. There is no excuse for vandalism, but there is an explanation for the terrible situation in Toronto and in other big cities of Canada.
Violent crime has gone up 40 per cent since 1984. The UN report, the report the government uses so often lately, said that Canada has the highest rate of drug related crime in the industrialized world.
In Toronto 213,000 people are unemployed, and 18.8 per cent of the young people in Ontario do not have jobs. Therefore, for seven years the policy of this government has been turning its back on the problems in the big cities of Canada.
When will the government realize that its policies are making the situation worse, not better in the big cities of Canada?

May 5, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, of course we all deplore the acts of violence that took place in Toronto. Those will be dealt with by the courts in an appropriate manner. Therefore, I cannot comment on that.
We can, of course, deplore social situations, situations of unfairness which give rise to discrimination of any kind which in turn gives rise to frustration and acts that one would hope not to see in a country like Canada.
The government has tried through its employment policies. My hon. friend is quite wrong. In point of fact when the Hon. David Peterson was premier of Ontario his government and ours managed to bring unemployment in Ontario and in Toronto down to record lows, in the neighbourhood of 3.5 per cent or 4 per cent.
There have been very important social programs and social initiatives taken to curb violence, to integrate immigrants into the metropolitan Toronto area. Appointments have been made to signal the importance of ethnic communities to the multicultural fabric of Canada. Some people use the term multiculturalism as a way of dividing Canadians, to suggest that immigration is of no value. Immigration is vital to the well-being of Canada.
For example, the appointment of Line Alexander as the first black Lieutenant-Governor of Ontario, the appointment of the new Chief Justice of the Federal Court, the first black in Canadian history to be Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Canada were important because it is important that minorities be in positions of fundamental importance in the decision-making process.
All of these help in dealing with difficult social pressures that exist in great metropolitan areas. I know that I can count on the support of my hon. friend in bringing forward policies that will alleviate tensions and improve the situation in Toronto and elsewhere.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened very carefully to the Prime Minister, but he did not answer my question. Since this government came to power, the number of violent crimes in Canada has increased 40 per cent. I told the Prime Minister that the UN report the Prime Minister keeps quoting all the time says that Canada has the highest
level of drug related crime of any country in the Western world.
I wish the Prime Minister would realize that his government's policies have created a bad situation, not only in Toronto but also in Montreal, which has more than 200,000 unemployed, and in Quebec generally, where 19.8 per cent of young people have no jobs. That is the real problem. If the government does not change its economic policies and does not take all necessary steps to find jobs for young people who are really desperate, this country will be faced with even more violence than we saw yesterday.

Mr. Speaker, if a mediocre economy generates violence, if that is the case, then perhaps the Leader of the Opposition would care to explain 1981-82 when the economy was in far worse shape than it is today. Yes, worse than today: higher interest rates, higher unemployment, higher inflation, worse across the board.
I would ask the hon. member for Ville-Emard, in Montreal, to look at the facts. Ten years ago, the inflation rate was 12.9 per cent, and now it is 1.6 per cent. The unemployment rate is lower, and interest rates are lower as well. Do not tell me today that the economy is to blame.
There is of course an economic dimension. There is the problem of drugs and violence associated with drugs. There is the problem of poverty in our large urban centres. There is the lack of economic opportunies. However, we are working closely with the provincial governments, the Liberal government and the NPD government, to alleviate these problems. I think it would be helpful if the Leader of the Opposition would be more specific in his recommendations, instead of trying to cloud the issue.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
I am
not the one who went back to the past. It was the Prime Minister who went back to the past. When we had some difficulties some years ago we made sure it was not to be on the social fabric of Canada.

Hear, hear.
May 5, 1992
Rather than always talking about the interests of big business we cared about the people who were unemployed. They had some hope then that they do not have today.
Hear, hear.

I can tell the Prime Minister one thing today. I would like to make sure that he understands that this is a wake-up call. I would like to urge the Prime Minister to face that reality. Is he ready to face the reality that these problems need action now, not cuts in programs relating to race relations and job creation and opportunities for everybody. We must make sure that pride and confidence will return to Canadian society.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, just by way of correction, my hon. friend said that he is not the one who went back to the past. That statement is of course false. He was the one who raised it in his first question when he referred to all of the social ills in Toronto beginning in 1984. That is exactly the way he began his question.
