I think my hon. friend is right about facing reality. That is exactly what we ought to be doing rather than seeking to ascribe blame to events that occurred 5, 10, or 20 years ago. We are dealing with a social problem today.
It is very complex and very difficult to tie it in to all kinds of realities that are neither Conservative, NDP, or Liberal. They are human realities. They deal with discrimination. They deal with racism. They deal with unfairness. They deal with all of the problems that exist in a great pluralistic society.
At the base of all this is tolerance. What we must seek to do through our economic policies, our social policies and our attitudes coming from this House of Commons, is a degree of civility and tolerance that will persuade Canadians of that of which the rest of the world is assured, that Canada is indeed with its imperfections, the best place in the world in which to live.
We must be more vigilant. We must be ready to convey more resources to that problem.
Oral Questions
However, my hon. friend will not solve the problem with slogans. He will not solve the problem with anything other than dedication and co-operation with the provincial and municipal governments.

Mr. Speaker, this is not a forum for debating tricks. This is reality.

Relations between the police and minority groups are tense, employment equity is only a dream, the Court Challenges Program has been cut and the Canadian Race Relations Foundation has been put on hold.
How can this government claim to address the problems of race relations when it takes no concrete action whatsoever to respond to the real needs of all Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have made a great deal of progress in police relations. After a day of consultations held here in Ottawa with the minority community, the police institute and the government, we set up a five-part national action plan. Last Monday we opened an information centre here at the police college, a training and recruitment centre for inter-police relations.
Just imagine: this year, Quebec's Black Community Council in Montreal voted Roland Bourget as man of the year. That means something. Do you think this could happen anywhere else? That is what we have achieved in terms of relations between the community and the police.

Mr. Speaker, the problems we are experiencing today are not a matter of white against black but of haves versus have-nots.

Canadians are fed up with this government's mixed-up priorities. The bureaucratic cost of multiculturalism has gone up by over $36 million while the funding for programs has been axed by $28 million.

May 5, 1992
Oral Questions
When will this government deliver on its promise to fight racism with action instead of empty rhetoric?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, our record over the past four years in helping establish partnerships and advancing the issue is quite well established and quite well known.
I thought the member might want to raise some of the particular initiatives, like March 21 which was the International Day for the Elimination of Racism, and how effectively that was carried out from coast to coast and the initiative of the Canadian Association of Broadcasters. It has contributed $10 million of free advertising. That has helped improve attitudes from coast to coast.
I recognize there is a disease in this country. It is called racism. It is an evil that affects the victim and the perpetrator equally. I have said that we have to do far more in terms of asking all of the institutions of this community to reflect on their attitudes and allow for the full participation of our diversity. That is the benefit we have of being citizens: one equal citizen. All we want to do is participate fully and that will be given as a highest priority at all times by this government.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
First of all let me say this. I share the view and I think the view is shared on all sides of the House that the violent outrage we saw in Toronto was neither an appropriate nor acceptable means of expressing a grievance.
Hear, hear.

The television pictures revealed to us who was involved. It involved youth, alienated, powerless, jobless youth, and that is a question that I think we must address.
I would like to address the specific issue that is being raised here today and that is the question of racism in Canada. I do so within the context that we understand your commitment to the principle of equality in this country.
Therefore, given the importance of the issues that have arisen, I would like to ask the Prime Minister, on behalf of the black and visible minority communities of this country, if he would agree to have a private meeting
with the leadership of those groups so that we can discuss in an effective way a specific response to the situation that our country faces today.

Mr. Speaker, while I accept the description, the seriousness of the problem of racism anywhere in our society, racism, anti-Semitism, these are the banes of a civilized society. They have to be dealt with vigorously and firmly by governments and Parliaments any time they show or raise their ugly heads.
I think my hon. friend would want to be careful and to generalize from a most regrettable incident in Toronto, I know that he has not been doing this. Canadians ought to refrain from the suggestion that all of a sudden, Canada is engulfed with very grave and overriding problems of racism.
There are instances of racism that are most troubling. There are classic illustrations where, for example, visible minorities, blacks, the Jewish community have been assaulted. They have been criminally assaulted in their human rights.
Each one of those is a stain on our citizenship, but by and large there is general agreement, general recognition, that Canada has been to the extent that a pluralistic society is, free from much of this.
I would be happy to meet with my hon. friend and any other representatives of multicultural or visible minority groups across the country to see how we can not only deal with this serious problem but also improve on the good record that Canada has.
I thank my hon. friend for that suggestion. I would be happy to sit down with him or any others in trying to build a better society.

Mr. Speaker, I hope you will be tolerant because I think you understand the sensitivity of the situation with respect to this member as well as the country.
I would like to emphasize that I have not characterized this nation as a racist nation nor have I said that the problem of racism is overwhelming. I have been very careful to say that broader social and economic issues are at the root of much that we have seen.
May 5, 1992

It should not be missed that there is a great deal of concern evolving within the visible minority communities of this country. I think most fundamental to all of this is the absolute recognition that there are going to be no Canadians who are distinguished from others in terms of their basic rights.
Yet the fact of the matter is that the Constitution of Canada, and the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, specifically set apart certain minorities by virtue of section 15(1) of the notwithstanding clause. I think people should examine that. It is a separation and it is a specification of difference.
Therefore, I ask the Prime Minister if he would respond to that plea and controvert the decision of his party, as well as that of the opposition to reject an amendment to section 27 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms which would have imposed upon governments an obligation to preserve and promote racial and ethnic equality in this country.
That would be a most powerful message to ensure that all of us feel that we are operating in this political context as equals recognized as such.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am happy to answer that question on behalf of my colleague, the right hon. Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
As the hon. member knows, Canada enjoys very strong legal prohibitions of racial, ethnic or gender based discrimination. I am aware of the suggestion made by my hon. friend's party in the Beaudoin-Dobbie report.
If a good case can be made that the current constitutional wording is inadequate, we will consider any constructive suggestions. Any changes, of course, would require the support of the provinces as well.
I encourage my hon. friend to make the same representations to the premier of his province and to encourage the kind of support around the table that would make the consideration of that suggestion possible.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice.
Oral Questions
Last March 19,1 received a letter from the Minister of Justice stating: "A due share of responsibility for the breakdown of law and order lies with the provinces".
Yesterday the premier of Ontario did meet in an emergency meeting with his cabinet and leaders of the black community to address the serious crisis developing in Toronto.
Canadians want to know what the federal government did over the weekend to address this crisis in Toronto. What is the federal government intending to do to avoid future demonstrations and violence in view of the fact that we learned just an hour ago there is another demonstration being planned for Thursday of this week?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would caution the hon. member on his rhetoric in talking about a breakdown in law and order.
We have had a very unfortunate incident in Toronto. It is very worrisome and points to some social problems that all members of this House are concerned about and wish to address. In fact those issues have been dealt with by law enforcement authorities. We do not have a breakdown of law and order.
It is important to understand that it is not simply at times of crisis that we try to address these concerns. As I indicated in the House yesterday, one of the priorities of this government and certainly my priority as Minister of Justice, has been the question of inclusive justice and the effort of trying to make the justice system in all of its aspects, policing, the courts, corrections, more responsive to all Canadians so that they will feel confident in it.
I have been meeting over the past few weeks with the mayors of the big cities, including two meetings with the mayor of Toronto, to work toward the development of a process for creating a strategy on urban crime and urban safety in Canada. This involves the particular community relations characteristic of our larger cities and certainly characteristic of my own city of Vancouver which faces many of the same tensions.
We are working on the issue. I have been working co-operatively with those people who have the leadership at the community level. I have been meeting with police commissions. This is an ongoing commitment for

May 5, 1992
Oral Questions
us and not simply one that arises after a particularly regrettable incident.

Mr. Speaker, the minister cautions me to watch the words I use. I quoted from her letter to me of March 19.
My supplementary question is for the Prime Minister. The last budget presented by this government announced a series of spending cuts which eliminates the access of Canadians to affordable housing, to jobs and to job training.
The source of the unrest that we have witnessed in the last 24 hours in Toronto is a direct result of lacking opportunities for the jobless and the working poor.
Why is the government spending $20 million on a dog and pony show called the prosperity initiative, instead of dealing with the unrest brewing in our Canadian cities?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the dog and pony show stopped in 1984 when the government decided to stop throwing money at the problem and buying the illusion of prosperity.
The hon. member just stood up in the House in front of all Canadians and said that we had cut training funds for Canadian workers. That is false. The training funds for unemployed Canadians have gone up by $300 million.
No wonder that some people in this country are desperate when all they hear are deformations of reality. He talks about the prosperity initiative where private sector Canadians from coast to coast to coast gather together and try to challenge the future of Canada in a positive way, a thing the Liberals cannot do.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Solicitor General.
Drug trafficking and drug use are at an all-time high across the country. Local neighbourhoods are losing the battle, including metropolitan Toronto.
I ask the minister that given this reality, why has the government steadily refused to amend the Narcotics Control Act so that assets coming from drug seizures will not only flow to the general revenue accounts of this
government but also will be shared urgently and fairly with local police forces and community organizations so that the front-line groups may have the tools with which to win the battle against drugs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my friend makes a good point. The government has been involved in a sustained effort on the drug question through the national drug strategy.
Approximately six weeks ago I was in metropolitan Toronto and announced the formation of three drug units in Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver that will be specifically dedicated with funds out of the renewal of the drugs strategy to attack the problems in those centres and to effectively make use of the proceeds of crime legislation. I am on record publicly as supporting a change which would repay the expenditures to the jurisdictions involved through the provinces from the proceeds of crime.
I know that the Minister of Justice is working on this particular matter. We would expect to have legislation in the very near future. I would welcome my hon. friend's comments on that legislation and his support and that of his party when we try to pass it.

Mr. Speaker, unfortunately, drug abuse is one of the root causes of the unfolding circumstances we have been witnessing in metropolitan Toronto.
But the forces who are battling the drugs on the streets and in the alleyways of Toronto and other centres across the country are losing because they are underequipped and underfinanced. They have heard this commitment of pending legislation or legislation in the near future for a number of years now.
Therefore I ask the minister again, why the procrastination despite the hundreds of representations and hundreds of petitions to change the Narcotics Control Act? Rather than giving us "the near future", when can we specifically expect action on an issue that has unfortunately reached crisis proportions?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if my hon. friend had had time in the process of his allegations, he would have wanted to give the government credit for bringing in the legislation in the first place.
May 5, 1992

In other words, the legislation has been brought in by this government. I make no apologies for this. We put a great emphasis when the proceeds of crime legislation was brought in on protecting the rights of people and personal property. This is not at issue between my hon. friend and myself.
It has come to our attention that the legislation would be much more effective if instead of the various administrations and police forces scooping, shall we say, assets for the federal government, they were able to get their expenditures out of that particular seizure.
We are fully in favour of that. That is why we have the drug units under way. The legislative changes take longer, but I can assure my hon. friend that we will be proceeding on that type of legislation.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. Racism is largely a symptom of the fundamental problems affecting society. One of these problems is definitely a lack of jobs. The unemployment rate is more than 11 per cent across Canada, but the youth unemployment rate is 17 per cent, and in Quebec 19 per cent. People without hope are the real crisis in this country.
Is the government prepared to take serioulsy the warning it has just received? Will the goverment finally launch a series of specific programs to reduce the unemployment rate among young people?

Mr. Speaker, I do not understand how the hon. member can talk about receiving a warning. I do not accept that. I just told her member that racism is a dreadful problem that we must eliminate in this country, but we should not generalize and conclude that we have a racist society. We do not have a racist society in Canada.
We must not conclude from the events in Toronto that all this is due to the problems mentioned by the hon. member. Of course there are economic problems but as the International Monetary Fund said last week, in 1992 and 1993 Canada will rank first on job creation among all major countries belonging to the G-7. That is pretty
Oral Questions
good news. It is encouraging because we are talking about the industrialized world. It is excellent news.
Furthermore, this morning Ruth Getter of the Toron-to-Dominion Bank said the following, and I quote:

It means that we are climbing out of this long and deep recession.
The indicators are becoming more and more positive as we get new
numbers. I think that in the second half of the year we are going to see
a very strong recovery. Afterwards we are going to see a fairly strong
pick-up.
This is encouraging news for those who believe that economic growth and the proper sharing of economic growth will allay fears and tensions in communities, and I think we share that view.
The signals are important and encouraging for a durable-
I think we do have to move on.

I have a supplementary question, Mr. Speaker.
No one on this side of the House, and certainly not myself, has said that Canada is a racist society. I must say that I resent the Prime Minister's implications that we are saying that on this side of the House.
What we are pointing out is that there are many structural problems in the country that can lead to the kind of incidents that we have seen. Any country will ignore, at its peril, poverty and unemployment.
Why have the Prime Minister and his government decided that it is more important to advertise across this country in newspapers the United Nations statement that Canada is No. 1 than to deal with some of these problems and to answer some of these questions?
Why has his government reduced money for low cost housing by 46 per cent? Why has his government taken $100 million out of job training? Why has his government reduced the CAP payments to three provinces by almost $4 billion and instead tries to tell us that a $500 million program for children will address poverty? The Canadian public will not buy it-

I think we have to tighten things up a little bit.

May 5, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I could not deal with the inaccuracies in the figures rattled off by my hon. friend except, for example, I will point out that she indicated that we had cut back on job training. In fact there has been an increase in job training dollars by $400 million, not a decrease.
My hon. friend says that there are many structural problems which give rise to some of these difficulties. I agree with her. The structural problems are the debt, deficit, trade liberalization, tax reform, and problems of children in poverty. We have been trying to deal with each one of these. Each one of these structural problems defies slogans and easy solutions.
We have been taking tough decisions. My hon. friend is at least partly right. The problem deals with the structural difficulties in Canada. We have been solving those structural problems and taking the heat for all of the political problems that ensue. But that is the way to go. We are solving these structural problems and-
The hon. member for Yukon.

Mr. Speaker, they created the structural problems by doubling the debt, by signing a trade deal and now a Mexican trade deal that has created over 400,000 unemployed. This is a government that has cut out the Co-Operative Housing Program, cut back on social housing-
I would ask the hon. member to put her question, please.

I would ask the Prime Minister simply this: Is the government prepared to look at some of the human problems that people face every day in Canada like lack of housing and lack of food and do something about it now?

Mr. Speaker, the human problems. What could be a more important human problem than children at risk, poverty as it affects children?
Yesterday in Toronto the Minister of National Health and Welfare announced a new program of $500 million to invest in children to make sure that they have better lives. Some people say that it is not enough. They are probably right. It is $500 million more today than the children had yesterday.
We are in the process of taking steps like this throughout our society while continuing to deal with the deep structural problems to which my hon. friend referred: namely the deficit, the debt, trade liberalization and tax reform.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The government says that the best way to tackle poverty is by getting its financial structure in order. That structure includes -the accounting fiction of passing welfare costs to the provinces and municipalities by imposing limits on the Canada Assistance Plan. Tens of thousands of Canadian children whose families were forced on to welfare during the recession are now disowned by the finance minister.
I ask the Prime Minister how making new promises while shifting old costs to other governments is going to create brighter futures for Canada's impoverished children and overburdened taxpayers.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am sure the hon. member is aware-if she read the budget she will have noted this-that in this particular fiscal year of 1992-93 some $38.9 billion will be transferred to the provinces. In her own province of Ontario she will note that since 1984 transfers to the province of Ontario have risen at the rate of 6.2 per cent per year. As a matter of fact the Ontario budget noted that between 1985-86 and 1990-91-1 believe those were the years that were used-that transfer payments to the province of Ontario rose during that period of time by 8.4 per cent per year.
I tell the hon. member-and I have said in the House before-that transfer payments to the province of Ontario have grown at a faster annual rate than the transfers to Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, Prince Edward Island, Alberta and British Columbia.

Mr. Speaker, when this government promised a national child care program many parents believed that finally they would be able to go out and get jobs so their children would not
May 5, 1992

be among the one million who are living in poverty today.
When the minister cancelled national child care he may well have realized that his high unemployment policies would leave few jobs for single parents any way.
I ask the minister why Canada's children have been written off government books but remain front and centre on its press releases.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is a most unfair allegation. The truth of the matter is the child package this government brought in, in the last Parliament, was destroyed and killed by the Liberal senators in the other place prior to the last election, and she knows that.
We as a government know the constraints we have and we must face. My colleague, the Minister of National Health and Welfare, has announced a number of programs. I think something in the order of $2 billion is provided toward child care.
The announcement made yesterday, the initiative in the budget and the ways and means motion I will be tabling today to reform the family allowance system are clearly parts of a program that will direct the resources to those people most in need. I think the hon. member would applaud that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
It is quite clear now that this government does not know what it is doing with the Child Action Program. It has not consulted with any stakeholders. It has not had serious consultation with the provinces. It has not had any involvement from the social policy groups. It has no plans on the books right now to have any consultations with those doing the real work at the street level.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I just want to remind the House that the child development initiative announced by my colleague yesterday is the latest in a long line of initiatives this government has implemented since 1984.
Oral Questions
The problems are national in scope. That is why, as the federal government, we must find national solutions. My colleague has had consultations with the provinces and agencies, and all programs will be jointly managed. That is why one important aspect of this particular program is called Partnership.
We on this side of the House, are prepared to rely on community groups, the private sector and municipal and provincial governments. We intend to use this $200 million in funding to work together to ensure that our future will be in good hands.
How can the government announce a $200 million community action program when the government's own documents show there is not one single project on the books?

Mr. Speaker, if the minister claims that the country has been consulted, why would neither one provincial government nor one social group in the last 24 hours admit to being consulted?
I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister. Cutbacks in the core area initiative, in child-parent centres, in training for aboriginal youth, in child care, and in social and co-operative housing have all caused Manitobans to lose faith in their federal government.
Why should Manitobans now believe that yesterday's announcement by the minister will make any difference in the lives of their children when the government is not even putting back what it has taken out over the last five years?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, could the House perhaps be persuaded to rise above day-to-day concerns and try to see what is happening to our families and children from a national perspective?
Since 1984 we have introduced a number of measures, and yesterday we announced another measure in addition to the $15 billion now available to children and families. Yes, we consulted with community agencies. Yes, we talked to the provinces. I was there with my

May 5, 1992
Oral Questions
colleague, the minister responsible, when we discussed these matters. We will continue to form partnerships for prevention and promotion and encourage families to be associated with what we call an improved quality of life.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Transport. Further to my question of March 31 this year about the Abitibi-Temiscamingue road network, could the minister confirm, for the benefit of the people of Abitibi-Temiscamingue, that Highway 117 from Louvi-court via Val-d'Or, Malartic, Riviere-Heva, Cadillac and Rouyn-Noranda to the Quebec and Ontario border, is now part of the Trans-Canada Highway and that this section will be one of the government's priorities at its upcoming discussions with the province of Quebec so that this road will be repaired to provide safe conditions for users?

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member for Abitibi is no doubt aware that the conference of transport ministers has been discussing the Trans-Canada network for the past four years. Yes, Highway 117 is part of the Trans-Canada Highway and will be considered when the subject comes up for discussion again.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. Today in Montreal, the Minister of National Health and Welfare repeated his announcement of the government's new child development initiative. In this program, the government stresses the crucial importance of nutrition, education and child care. However, at the same time, the government has reduced its financial commitments to health and post-secondary education, set a cap on funding for the Canada Assistance Plan and turned down a national day care system. Does the Prime Minister not realize there is a contradiction between what he says and what he does, between his policies and this action plan?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
No,
Mr. Speaker, there is no contradiction between what we
say and what we do. Earlier I referred to the $15 billion we have invested in our families. We could of course refer to all kinds of programs that exist today, whether we are talking about family violence, dropouts, the national drug strategy or the disabled. We have in place a number of measures to support the families that need assistance. I maintain that the government's role is to support families in need, and when we support families we support the children who are at risk.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the same minister on the government's action plan for children.
The government says that it will now require specific warnings on prescription and non-prescription drugs to prevent injury to children.
Will the government also insist on similar specific warnings on alcoholic beverages to warn women against drinking during pregnancy in order to prevent foetal alcohol syndrome, mental retardation, and other birth defects?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Through our actions, Mr. Speaker, we will continue to put in place mechanisms that will prove an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. In his annual report tabled today in the House, the Commissioner of Official Languages pointed out that Canadians are not informed about linguistic duality and suggested that governments and leaders in society dare to talk about the role, importance and influence of the official languages in national unity.
I would like to ask the government whether it intends to show leadership by launching a vast nation-wide information campaign to explain the nature of our
May 5, 1992

country and the importance and value of its linguistic duality to Canadians.

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, linguistic duality obviously includes the specifically linguistic aspect. In that regard we are now in the process of completing agreements with British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Ontario to increase access to both official languages throughout the country and also to native languages in certain cases. I hope to be able to report to the House within a few weeks to announce, for the hon. member's information, that these agreements have been concluded.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the government leader, the Prime Minister. The commissioner says that the resources of the Secretary of State are, in his words, inadequate for the task of promoting official languages in society. It is one thing to provide a department with a mandate, but quite another to deprive it of the resources needed to fulfil its mandate.
Why is the government refusing to give the Secretary of State the resources required to provide leadership and support in promotion of official languages?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, given the mandate that I have and given the co-operation of the provinces that I have received to date, I am fully willing to assert that I feel that the resources that are available right now are sufficient. Should they not be, I would be the first to go back to cabinet and obtain additional funds.

I wish to draw to the attention of members the presence in the gallery of parliamentary delegations from Bulgaria, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russian Federation and Ukraine.

Hear, hear.
Point of Order WAYS AND MEANS

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 83(1), I wish to table a notice of a ways and means motion to amend the Income Tax Act. I ask that an order of the day be designated for consideration of the motion.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I had heard that the hon. member for Spadina had asked for an emergency debate dealing with the matter related to the incident in Toronto. Looking at Standing Order 52, which provides for such debates on an important matter requiring urgent consideration, I am not sure that that really applies in this case.
I did want to indicate to the hon. member, and I hope that we will have agreement in the House, that certainly the government would be supportive of any consent motion to have a debate in accordance with the provisions set out in Standing Order 52, namely starting at eight o'clock and carrying on with the conditions listed in that Standing Order, if that was agreeable to the Official Opposition. It is certainly agreeable to the government.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, there have been some consultations and I wish to indicate to the House quite clearly that the Official Opposition would agree with the suggestion of the government House leader in terms of having this debate this evening, if all other hon. members would agree with the substance of the motion, as put forward by our colleague, the hon. member for Trinity-Spadina.

Mr. Speaker, I want to say that I certainly appreciate the very generous comments by the government House leader and the official opposition House leader. I think this is an excellent way to proceed and it leaves us with a good example on political issues of the future.

Privilege
We recognize the request went to you and we now await your decision.

Mr. Speaker, I can tell you that there were no consultations; as usual the government often fails to consult. Given the seriousness of the events and the consequences that might follow for all the provinces in this country, I am sure that it would be worth discussing.

In view of the suggestion made that the hon. member for Trinity-Spadina's application this morning be agreed to unanimously then that is so ordered and debate will begin at eight o'clock and will follow the usual terms of an emergency debate.

subsubtopic: AVAILABILITY OF ANNUAL REPORT OF COMMISSIONER OF OFFICIAL LANGUAGES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hesitate to rise on this question of privilege, but I believe that we must absolutely make the general public and this House aware of something that took place today. I am of course talking about the tabling of the annual report of the Commissioner of Official Languages in this House.
When I entered my office at eight o'clock this morning, I found in my correspondence a notice to the media in which journalists were told that they could obtain a copy of the annual report, as well as a press book and other releases and related documents.
I contacted the Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages to obtain a copy of the annual report, recognizing, as usual, the embargo imposed in such circumstances when members of Parliament have an opportunity to familiarize themselves with a rather bulky and interesting document.
They refused to provide me with a copy of the report. I asked for some explanation and was told that they would phone me back in the next 15 to 20 minutes. However, half an hour later, I received a telephone call from a lady, whose name I will not mention. That person, who is the secretary of the Deputy Commissioner, told me:
"No, you will not get a copy; copies are not distributed to members of Parliament. Tliis is an order that was given to us by the Commissioner of Official Languages. That is the way it is going to be". I pointed out to her that this was an unusual situation that was totally unacceptable to me as a parliamentarian.
Mr. Speaker, you are very well aware of what this is all about. It has long been established that members of Parliament have the privilege of familiarizing themselves with documents tabled in the House. There are briefing sessions and in camera meetings during which the document is explained to us. That is done for eveiy report.
But in this case, it seems to me that the media were deemed able to keep the report secret until it would be tabled, but not members of Parliament. That, is neither right nor acceptable in my opinion. If the media were given access to the document, I believe that members of this House for whom the Commissioner of Official Languages works after all, since he is an officer of this House, should also have the right to familiarize themselves with the report, and not only the members of the media.
The press release is as follows:
In addition to the annual report, members of the media will be able
to obtain a press book from any office of the Commissioner as early as
8 a.m., but cannot release its contents before 11 a.m..
I would like to raise the question of privilege and give appropriate notice. I might not make a motion, because I believe that the commissioner is well intentioned and that maybe he was not aware of the current practices whereby members of Parliament are given the same opportunity as the media to familiarize themselves with the report. However, I thought that I should raise this issue today because I believe that the privilege that we have to be informed and to have the same information as the media is an important one.

subsubtopic: AVAILABILITY OF ANNUAL REPORT OF COMMISSIONER OF OFFICIAL LANGUAGES
speechtext:
This question of privilege is news to me, Mr. Speaker.
Everyone knows the devotion and concern of the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier for this important issue of official languages. This is a major report and it seems totally unacceptable-I am weighing my words carefully here-unacceptable, incredible and arrogant that it
May 5, 1992

would be made available to the media, not that I am against the media being informed, but not when the hon. member who is our official opposition critic is told that he will have to wait until the crucial moment, that is to say 11 a.m., to get a copy. How can the hon. member be expected to fulfil his duty as member of Parliament and his official duties as critic for the opposition? That is absolutely incredible.
It is not the first time that something like this happens. Often, in their haste perhaps, ministers do not file certain statements in time, but for a senior officer of this House, to do so was indeed to deny us access to a report in due course. I know the interest you take in this issue and I know that the Speaker will give it due consideration.

I am sure Your Honour will give great consideration to the point put forward by our colleague. I thank him for not pushing it today. He- is raising it at the first opportunity. He is asking Your Honour to look into the matter and to report as Your Honour will see fit at the first opportunity.
I would like Your Honour to understand, and we know that you understand, that he is not the only one. We really take seriously this matter and we will be expecting your reply at an intelligent time, as always.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subsubtopic: AVAILABILITY OF ANNUAL REPORT OF COMMISSIONER OF OFFICIAL LANGUAGES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, very briefly, my two colleagues who have just spoken have focused on the particular issue.
I hope this matter, which I see you are taking quite seriously, can be dealt with expeditiously because here we have a situation of an official of Parliament denying the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier a copy of a veiy important document until a particular time is reached, while on the other hand, copies of the said document have been made available to members of the media.
There seems to be a real demarcation of what is correct and what is not correct. I would suggest to the Chair-I seek the guidance of the Chair-that this is an inexcusable mistake. It is an inexcusable discourtesy to members of this House and particularly the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier.
Privilege
I would hope that the Chair would take under active consideration and move on this in a most expeditious manner so that we can have this resolved forthwith.

subsubtopic: AVAILABILITY OF ANNUAL REPORT OF COMMISSIONER OF OFFICIAL LANGUAGES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to support the points placed forward by my hon. friend from Ottawa-Vanier particularly.
His voice represents the concerns of a number of members who presumably experienced something similar to himself this morning. Knowing that the Commissioner of Official Languages is an officer of this House and that he reports to the Parliament of Canada, not to the media of Canada, he ought to know very clearly in what order this reporting process ought to occur.
I think we were all somewhat taken aback this morning to learn of these events. What is very important is that the Commissioner of Official Languages is not a representative of the government. He represents the House of Commons. He is an officer of this House.
We all make special efforts to keep the matters surrounding official languages as non-partisan as possible. I think in that same spirit that the Commissioner ought to acknowledge the importance of tabling his report in the House of Commons, and at that point releasing it to others. The members of the House of Commons and yourself, Mr. Speaker, ought to be the first people informed of any report tabled in this Parliament.

speakeroldname: Hon. Lloyd Axworthy (Winnipeg South Centre) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-53 be amended in clause 4 by adding immediately after
line 12 at page 4 the following:
(4)	No order or regulation made pursuant to subsection (l)(a) or
(b)	shall,
(a)	apply to a Canadian that conducts a regulated financial services business outside Canada with respect to any transaction or activity, if the transaction or activity is carried on outside Canada and not for the purpose of evading the order or similar orders in another country or countries; or
(b)	preclude a Canadian that conducts a regulated financial services business from carrying out a financial transaction necessary to give effect to a commitment that became binding against the Canadian prior to the making of the order under subsection (1), but this shall not affect any provision of such an order or regulation that required proceeds of the financial transaction to be placed in a blocked account or imposes other requirements with similar effect.
(5)	In determining whether a particular transaction or activity by a Canadian outside Canada constitutes evasion for the purposes of subsection (4), a court shall consider, as evidence of evasion:
(a)	whether the Canadian has transferred assets or liabilities in large amounts to a jurisdiction that is not enforcing the sanctions to which an order or regulation under this act refers;
(b)	whether the jurisdiction referred to in (a) is one where the Canadian normally did not carry on business of the kind or scope that it is observed to carry on subsequent to the order or regulation;
(c)	whether the occurrence of the activities referred to in (a) and (b) coincides approximately with the issuance of an order or regulation under this act;
(d)	such other factors as the court deems appropriate under the circumstances.
(6.) For the purposes of subsection (4), a regulated financial services business is the business of a bank, trust company, securities dealer or other financial business the activities of which are of a nature that is subject to regulation when carried on in Canada.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I bring forward this amendment in response to representations we received during the committee from representatives of the Canadian Bankers' Association.
They drew to the attention of the committee what they consider to be a serious problem that would be faced by
Government Orders
the banking community through the application of the special economic measures.
In many cases, it would put those working in financial services outside the country in a position where they would be forced to choose oftentimes between a law or set of regulations asked for by their host country and those by Canada itself.
There was real concern that this would substantially impair the positioning of these financial services, these banking institutions, because of this extra-territorial application of the law.
The amendment is drawn on the basis that we certainly want to ensure that financial institutions obey the spirit and letter of the law. That is why, in the amendment itself, we make clear that the sanctions measures or the special emergency measures would be imposed for those who are directly trying to evade the impact of the law itself.
To meet some of the concerns that were expressed in the committee, we have added a subclause (5) which sets out what the nature of those evasive actions might be, whether the Canadian transfers assets or whether their jurisdiction is one where the Canadian normally did not carry on business or the currency activities referred to in A and B coincide with the issuance of orders or regulations under the act.
The case I am making is that this amendment would not undermine, change or alter in any way the ability of the Government of Canada, through Parliament, to ensure at a time of international crisis when the decision was to impose a wide-ranging effect of economic measures, that our financial institutions would be subject to the law and where it does apply outside the boundaries of Canada, it would only be done when it was clear that some form of evasive action was being taken according to the criteria set out in this amendment. I bring this forward in the spirit and hope that while it is very important that we continue to administer a law in a broad-brushed way, there are circumstances where the law must be somewhat flexible. We have to understand that institutions doing business outside the country

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
should not be penalized for those actions in the normal course of business. At the same time we should be able to capture anybody who is attempting to use those financial institutions to evade or escape the dictates or requirements of the law.
I recommend this particular amendment to the House and especially to the government members. I hope they will understand it is an attempt to respond to what we all recognize as a very clear concern raised by the banking community.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I take seriously the representation and the amendment which have been tabled by my friend from Winnipeg South Centre.
We had some very good discussion in committee on this very subject when the bankers' association appeared before us. As the member from Winnipeg has already pointed out, there is in a sense this is generic legislation. It is broad enough to give the government latitude to apply the sanctions, yet tight enough to prevent the loopholes we all fear would be in this kind of legislation.
As we discussed in committee, the financial world has become ever more complex in the last generation or two, and financial transactions are now done electronically. They are done by satellite and it is very difficult to even track them the way it was possible when everything was done with paper transactions not too long ago. First of all there is the difficulty of dealing with this. However, that is not the major problem.
I would point out, as the member has already suggested, that clause 4 begins with the term may. The Governor in Council may for the purpose of implementing a decision, so there is a judgment call already by the Governor in Council.
I would also point out that the amendment, as proposed, is really quite loose in its definitions. For example, 4(a) applies to a Canadian that conducts a regulated financial services business outside Canada. That is a fairly loose definition in itself. It goes on, and I would point out just for one other example: "For the purposes of subsection (4), a regulated financial Securities business is the business of a bank, trust company, security dealer or other financial business". It does not define
whether they are federally regulated or provincially regulated. It is a very loosely drafted amendment.
I think it would be a mistake to proceed through the debate without pointing out the concept of extraterritoriality to those who are concerned about this legislation. We think of that term usually by means of the definition the Americans have given to it, and as it has affected Canada when the Americans have implemented their definition. Their definition affects not only Americans living outside the United States or American companies operating outside the United States. It also affects other nationals in that host country working for an American company, such American corporations operating in Canada. Their definition of extraterritoriality makes Canadians obey American foreign policy in the way they apply that law.
This bill does not do that. I think we should make that clear. Our definition of the term extraterritoriality simply defines the behaviour of Canadians living in other countries and our country wants to circumscribe their behaviour as it relates to a belligerent country. We want to make that distinction very clear. Our use of the term is not in the American sense but is certainly a very narrow sense of the word in Canadian application.
The amendment is too loosely defined and drafted in our opinion. I think financial institutions have to accept the same parameters of other Canadian businesses. I feel the government cannot accept this amendment.
Mr. Speaker, I have a point of order. I have a question I want to raise with the parliamentary secretary if he would accept such a question.

The government has said it does not intend to support the amendment. I would ask the parliamentary secretary if the Government of Canada would undertake to raise this matter at the international and multilateral level, for example, the Bank of International Settlement, to see if certain international and multilateral rules could be applied as to how such sanctions would be applied to
May 5, 1992

financial institutions during this period. If we can get some international agreement on it, then it may be able to have further amendments down the line.

speakeroldname: Hon. Lloyd Axworthy (Winnipeg South Centre) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-53 be amended in clause 4 by striking out lines 14 to
38 at page 2 and substituting the following therefor:
"4.(1) The Governor in Council may make an order or regulation under subsection (1.1)
(a) for the purpose of implementing a decision, resolution or recommendation of an international organization or association of states, ofwhich Canada is a member, that calls on it members to take economic measures against a foreign state,
Government Orders
(b)	where the Governor in Council is of the opinion that a grave breach of international peace and security has occurred that has resulted or is likely to result in a serious international crisis,
(c)	where the Governor in Council is of the opinion that grave violations of human rights have occurred in a foreign state and continue or are likely to continue, or
(d)	where the actions of foreign states, or of persons outside Canada acting under the protection of the laws or actions of a foreign state, present a significant threat to the global environment or the environment of Canada.
(1.1) In any of the circumstances described in subsection (1), the
Governor in Council may
(a)	make such orders or regulations with respect to the restriction or prohibition of any of the activities referred to in subsection (2) in relation to a foreign state as the Governor in Council considers necessary,
and
(b)	by order, cause to be seized, frozen or sequestrated in the manner set out in the order any property situated in Canada that is held by or on behalf of
(i) a foreign state, (ii) any person in that foreign state, or (iii) a
national of that foreign state who does not ordinarily reside in
Canada".
He said: Mr. Speaker, the purpose of proposing these amendments is to broaden the application of the act. As it presently reads the implementation would be based upon recommendations of international organizations, on threats of peace and security.
As we well know, the definition of peace and security has been substantially broadened in the last months or year or so. One issue that is increasingly becoming a matter of life and death security is the matter of environmental spoilage, pollution and total destruction of species. We have a major battle on our east coast with other countries at the present time about the dwindling cod stocks.
It is our belief as a party that eventually this must be subject to some form of international regulation and control so this valuable asset to Canada and the rest of the world will not be destroyed and disappear. It is one of the real cases of sustainable development in its clear and pristine form.
If such actions are to be taken internationally there must also be the ability to enforce such actions. It cannot be simply good wishes. When it comes to the question of peace and security, the application of sanctions is an

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
important instrument to use to prevent actual military conflict.
Equally, as we have seen tragically, the issue of human rights has also been a matter of international responsibility. Once again we have seen with the actions of the Kurds in Iraq and the plight of minorities in the fragmenting republics of what used to be called Yugoslavia, that the issue of human rights is increasingly becoming a matter that extends beyond one's boundaries as a matter of principle and as a matter of action.
It is important that as a country we have the ability to implement economic measures in a comprehensive way to deal with them. I can only point to the problems we ran into in the case of Haiti. There was an attempt to impose economic sanctions because of the serious human rights and democratic violations there. They did not work very well, partly because other countries, including our own, did not apply them very effectively. They were not subject to the kinds of measures that would otherwise be put into this act.
We seem to be attempting, through this legislation, to bring together in one statute the powers of the Government of Canada to respond and react to other forms of international transgressions and conflicts, whether they be in the environmental area or human rights area. If that is the case, it is important to add those definitions to this act so we can clearly say that in these evolving areas of international development, the Emergency Economic Measures Act would be in a position to be applied. It would be subject to some of the same, very useful rules about recalling Parliament, making sure there is a debate and an opportunity for a clear public airing of these matters, as opposed to the real confusion that surrounds them at the present time.
We include these amendments to ensure we do not simply look at the past and what occurred then. We must also look to the future and the kinds of emerging issues we as a country will be dealing with. I think it would substantially strengthen this bill if the amendment was adopted.

Mr. Speaker, I rise in support of the amendment that has been proposed by my colleague from Winnipeg South Centre.
I proposed similar amendments in the legislative committee on Bill C-53. Unfortunately the committee
did not see fit to adopt them. I hope the wisdom of the amendments will be more apparent now in this debate in the House.
These are very important amendments. We are talking about what can trigger a decision by the Governor in Council, or cabinet, to take the steps which are set out in this legislation to impose economic sanctions or something short of full economic sanctions. It might be a variety of economic pressure points to encourage countries, foreign states, to respect international law and end grave violations of fundamental human rights.
The bill as it is now worded would only allow the cabinet to impose these sanctions or apply this pressure where it is of the opinion, and I quote now from the legislation:
That a grave breach of international peace and security has
occurred that has resulted or is likely to result in a serious
international crisis.
Clearly there may very well be circumstances in which actions of a foreign state do not meet that particular threshold of a grave breach of international peace and security and yet the community of nations or indeed Canada will wish to impose economic sanctions or to apply economic pressure.
My colleague from Winnipeg South Centre has set out a couple of the circumstances in which this may take place. Grave violations of human rights may not be a breach of international peace and security, but is Canada to stand by, are other nations to stand by, while innocent people are being slaughtered, while people are disappearing, or in the case of global threats to the environment, whether it is the Canadian environment or the environment elsewhere? Surely Canada should have the flexibility to be in a position to take the kind of tough action which this bill would allow.
That is not possible at the present time. Under the United Nations Act which now governs the provisions with respect to economic sanctions certainly we cannot meet that threshold.
I would hope that as the world increasingly re-examines the notion of sovereignty and national sovereignty which has been used too often as a means of avoiding and evading responsibility for profound abuses of human rights, for very serious threats to the environment that as Canadians we might in this legislation demonstrate that we are prepared to take economic steps to respond to some of those crises.
May 5, 1992

Government Orders
It is for that reason I support the amendment which broadens the potential threshold which may give rise to the application of the measures set out in this legislation.
I would certainly hope that the government would see fit as well to support this amendment.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I guess one of the difficulties of this legislation is that all of us in the House support the same aspirations and the same goals when it comes to bringing about better human rights records around the world in every way.
Where we differ is not on goals or attitudes or values but on strategies. That is certainly true in this case.
I guess my problem with this is that while we have the same views regarding our apprehensions of human rights and degradation of the environment, we must still, as a country, as a government, apply the discipline of procedure in the way that we deal with those kinds of problems.
Let me give the House two examples that I see as problem areas. Human rights is a very loosely used term nowadays. I can suggest to members that if we went to numbers of areas in the world, social mores, in fact religious mores of those countries, if they were transplanted into Canada, would be considered human rights violations, but in those countries they are considered quite acceptable.
In the same case, to use a home-grown example, we now hear of people calling British Columbia the Amazon of the north. Anybody in British Columbia knows what a terrible accusation that is because it is untrue to the highest degree, but that does not stop people from suggesting it.
These are emotional slogans used against countries and therefore, because of these loosely termed phrases and sometimes loosely termed standards, we need to, as I said, apply the discipline of procedure. That is why Canada is proposing to work very closely in conjunction with other countries, other multilateral organizations, to bring about that kind of discipline.
When there is a consensus among the nations of the world that we should take action, then we would have that kind of a green light to do it, but under this legislation it would become a very subjective term and therefore we cannot support it.

Act.
(4)	The Governor in Council shall assess claims for compensation only in accordance with criteria approved by the House of Commons Standing Committee charged with External Affairs.
(5)	For purposes of subsection (4), the House of Commons Standing Committee may provide criteria of its own to the Minister designated under subsection (3).
He said: Mr. Speaker, under this bill there is a right to claim compensation, which is only proper and fair under the circumstances when people are hurt by a government action which is due to no consequence of their own.
However, as was made clear during several representations during committee, there is no opportunity for an independent review of compensation claims, so that those who feel injured would know that their request is based upon some judgment that is transparent, that is available for clear questioning and to establish their right to appeal it.
We had several quite lengthy discussions during the committee on the matter, and in view of those and in view of the fact the government again was concerned about establishing a complicated system of review, the amendment I propose is a simpler one. It does accomplish one important and, I believe, fair requirement, that the standing committee of the House which would be dealing with the over-all sanctions would set criteria under which compensation would be paid. That does not

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
mean that the actual award of compensation would be done by the members of the committee, but they would have a right to hear representations as to what criteria may be applied, particularly in cases where there are disputes as to whether the injury was caused by these actions or not.
I believe that in parliamentary democracy, one of the fundamental rights is the right to be heard, the right to have open access to express your concerns, and there is no better place in my mind than in front of a committee, in front of the elected representatives of the people who are held accountable. That is the difference between us and everybody else; we can be held accountable. I think it gives a sense of confidence to ordinary citizens in making a case of injury that they will be heard by a court of elected members who, if their judgment is wrong, can certainly be held accountable at the next election.
This amendment is designed to improve the procedures under which compensation can be awarded under this particular bill where a large amount of government power is imposed. It is an emergency situation wherein individuals can get caught up in the machinery and can often find themselves or their businesses in a precarious situation.
Again I recommend the amendment to government members, not because it alters in any substantial way the impact or the intent of the act, but I believe it makes it work better and fairer.

Mr. Speaker, I want to support this amendment and to point out briefly that the legislation as it is currently worded does not even require that the Governor in Council designate a minister of the Crown as the minister having the duty to assess claims for compensation.
There was an attempt made at the committee to change the legislation to make it clear that where the government has decided, pursuant to this legislation, to move forward on sanctions, there must be a mechanism so that individuals and businesses and organizations which are adversely affected by the legislation have an opportunity to make their claim for compensation.
As the legislation is now worded, that is not even required. I would certainly hope that if the government is not prepared to make it mandatory, make it essential, that that kind of mechanism be established, at the very least they would be prepared to support this amendment which does involve the House of Commons Standing Committee on External Affairs in establishing criteria for that compensation. I think Canadians who are affected by this legislation and indeed other innocent third parties who were adversely affected must be given an opportunity to have their day in court, if you will, pursuant to transparent criteria. That is the purpose of the amendment and certainly I support it.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I point out, as I think the hon. member for Winnipeg South Centre did, that every person has a right to claim. That is always a right and we need to protect that right.
The effect of the amendment, however, is to make it mandatory upon the government and as I pointed out in committee as we discussed this, the trigger for it is an allegation in this clause. "Anyone who alleges to have suffered" and if we combine a mandatory settlement with an allegation of a claim we put two conditions together which make it very difficult to satisfy justice. It also removes the onus on the person who is affected by this and we should not do that.
Finally I believe that it is ushering the standing committee into an area where it has not historically been functioning. There is nothing wrong with starting something new but I think that this is an inappropriate way for the committee to function and therefore we cannot support it.

speakeroldname: Hon. Lloyd Axworthy (Winnipeg South Centre) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-53 be amended in clause 7 by striking out line 40 at
page 5 and substituting the following therefor:
"made
(1.1) For purposes of subsection (1), where a House of Parliament stands adjourned on the day on order or regulation is made under section 4 and the House is not scheduled to meet within five days thereafter, the member of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada having responsibility under subsection (1) shall request the Speaker of the adjourned House to give notice to the members of the House that the House, for purposes of this section, shall meet on a date specified that is not more than ten days following the day on which the order or regulation is made and the Speaker shall immediately issue the notice.
He said: Mr. Speaker, this amendment meets two very important objectives. First, it only makes common sense that under the bill the government, to its credit, has indicated that when an order is to be given under the requirements of the statute that it be referred to Parliament.
However, there is a problem. It does not take into account what happens when Parliament does not happen to be sitting. It does not take into account circumstances where there is a summer recess, Christmas adjournment, or whatever it may be. Therefore it could happen, as it did during the gulf crisis when Parliament was basically out of action for over six or seven weeks. Very important decisions on behalf of the national security and interest of Canada would be taken under the measures of this bill with Parliament not being informed or the measures under the bill being triggered as the government wants them to be.
This leads me to the second principle and it is that all parliamentarians on whatever side of the House have a fundamental interest in ensuring that the forum from which Canadians can voice their interests be fully engaged and involved in the making of literally life and death decisions.
As we were properly reminded during the committee hearings, while sanctions are not as drastic as going to war, it can still impact very violently upon people. It takes an enormous amount of will for Canadians to make it work. It calls upon incredible resources. In effect they
Government Orders
are saying that we are closing off relations of all kinds, personal, family, commercial, economic, with another country because it is a transgressor of some kind. Is it right for decisions of that magnitude and momentous impact to be taken without Parliament being involved? I think we would all have to answer, of course not. That is why we are here.
It does not mean the government's will is to be thwarted. I should say on the record that in proposing an amendment earlier in committee, the government was prepared to accept a modifying amendment to ensure that when Parliament is seized of an issue, it does not have to be seen just in a negative way, but in a way that can amend the motion. I think it shows there was a will there to ensure that parliamentary involvement is taken seriously and considered seriously.
Unless this amendment is accepted, all the good provisions of the bill will be held in abeyance until the Speaker, under the orders of the House, brings us back.
The government moved quickly on August 6 to respond to the invasion of Kuwait, as it should have. It was supportive, but Parliament was not able to get around to looking at it until after September 15. It was close to seven weeks before there was any opportunity for debate, dialogue, exchange, consensus, or even for Parliament to express its collective will in support of that particular measure, if that had been the will of Parliament at the time.
This amendment goes to the issue of parliamentary involvement as a partner in making this decision and ensure that on those occasions when Parliament is adjourned for good and logical reasons, that it can be brought back on a motion of the minister responsible to the Speaker.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
I just want to make one comment regarding the details of the August 6 date. I know the member was accurate. It may have misled some people watching. He was speaking of the Kuwaiti invasion and the Canadian action was simply to begin the process toward embargo. The ships were steaming toward Kuwait, but there was no active war or anything like that at that point. I just want to make sure we all understand those circumstances.

Government Orders
The member is asking for a perfectly democratic proposition. I guess the only point I make is that he has already suggested we modify it to make sure the House controls its own destiny in one of the other amendments. We did that in a second amendment that he did not mention. In this case the Standing Orders of the House already provide that the House can be recalled. Therefore we see no reason to include it in the legislation itself.
