speakeroldname: Hon. Lloyd Axworthy (Winnipeg South Centre) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-53 be amended by adding immediately after line 14 at
page 7 the following new clause:
"7.1(1) Where an order for regulation made under section 4 is approved under section 7, the Secretary of State for External Affairs shall, at least every three months following the day on which the order or regulation is made, lay before each House of Parliament a report providing detailed information.
(a)	On the commercial and economic impact of the order or regulation, expressed in dollar values, and
(b)	On the impact of the order or regulation on the lives and living conditions of the civilian population of the foreign state to which the order or regulation applies.
(2) In addition to the information provided under subsection (1), the Secretary of State for External Affairs shall provide such further information as the House of Commons Standing Committee charged with external affairs may require."
He said: Mr. Speaker, in the previous amendment I cited the right of Parliament to be involved in making important decisions. Another important function of Parliament is to monitor and review those decisions to ensure that the conditions which gave rise to the original act of sanctions still pertain. If there is any lesson to be learned it is how volatile and changeable international conditions can be. Therefore it is important that Parliament be in a position to have a clear and accurate assessment from the responsible minister and officials as to the impact of these economic sanction programs.
Again I would like to refer to testimony before the committee. We were treated to some very wrenching descriptions of what is happening presently in Iraq to civilians, children and women, as a consequence of the sanctions program. That testimony was provided by individuals who have been there. Some veiy valued and courageous Canadians have gone to the area and come back. In fact members of all three parties in this House are now trying to jointly move a motion that would allow the thawing of certain assets so those people can be helped.
It made a very important point. Why should we have to rely on the testimony of a private citizen who happened to visit that country, and not have similar information deposited in the House by our own government? Surely if we accept as we do that these sanctions will have a very tough and serious impact, then we should know what that is. Every three months Parliament should assess whether the intent of this sanctions program is being met, whether revisions should be looked at, whether exceptions should be made or whether it is time for the sanctions program to come to an end. I do not know.
I do not know how many Canadians fully appreciate what is in this bill. This is one tough set of requirements. It puts members of the private sector under government mandate. It tells them who they can do business with. It prohibits the non-governmental humanitarian sector, private citizens, from a whole series of actions they would normally be free and have the opportunity as Canadians to exercise. That is tough. We accept it on the grounds that if it is not tough it is not going to work.
There should be a requirement that we assess periodically whether it is time to change, modify, alter or maybe toughen up. Nevertheless, if such enormous powers are being exercised in an unexamined way, it can lead to abuse and to people being unduly injured and victimized.

The point of the amendment is very simple. Every three months the minister is required to table a report on the impact of the sanctions in Parliament. Then if Parliament wants to pursue that through its committee structure or whatever, it is free to do it. If not, at least the information is there.
Therefore I go back to my original point. I think it is very important that we engage Canadians, through their parliamentary forum, in making these important foreign policy decisions. This would be another way to ensure it is done in a proper, open and transparent way.

Mr. Speaker, I think this is a very important amendment. When we look at the practice of the United Nations in regard to sanctions and the review of sanctions, we see how important this is. The United Nations currently requires that every 60 days the sanctions committee of the UN determines whether there should be any changes to the implementation of sanctions, whether there should be a lifting of sanctions and what the impact of those sanctions are. In fact there must be a renewal of sanctions effectively every two months.
It is particularly important that this amendment be given serious consideration, because one of the things we learned from the tragedy of the war in the Gulf is that Canadians and parliamentarians cannot rely on the media to provide us with accurate information with respect to the impact of decisions made by our government with respect to sanctions. We simply cannot rely on an objective evaluation of the impact of this. We know this was the most heavily censored war in the history of this planet. Canadian journalists were not allowed anywhere near the front lines, let alone given an opportunity to look at the impact of decisions that were made here in Canada.
This amendment would require our government to provide fundamental information to Parliament, which is essential if we are to determine whether or not sanctions are having the desired impact. Are they pressuring the decision makers or are they simply hurting the innocent in that country?
We cannot rely on the media to give us that information. That is one of the reasons why I think this is such a terribly important amendment that Parliament make an evaluation every three months. It is not an unreasonable
Government Orders
requirement. As I said, the United Nations has a review every 60 days.
I would point out as well that the government accepted an amendment which I proposed in committee that required a full evaluation of the effective sanctions after the sanctions have been lifted. I welcome the acceptance of that amendment, but it is just as important that there be an ongoing review of the impact of sanctions. It may be even more important to review the impact once the sanctions are finished.
A number of witnesses including Dr. Eric Hoskins appeared before the committee. They suggested the primary concern they had with the legislation as it is now drafted is that it does not do nearly enough to ensure the protection of the most vulnerable in the country subjected to economic sanctions. It provides no guarantees whatsoever that there will be that kind of review of the impact.
This amendment would require the government to provide information with respect to the impact of sanctions. It would also give the House of Commons Standing Committee on External Affairs the opportunity to seek further information.
If this legislation is to be effective, if Canadians are to have the opportunity, through their elected representatives, to monitor the impact of economic sanctions, this amendment must receive the support of the House.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in our desire to discuss this openly, and in the desire of the member for Burnaby to win appeal for his amendment, we must be careful how we state the case.
In speaking of the gulf war he said: "It was the most heavily censored war in the history of this planet". I think the member, upon reflection, would maybe want to retract that statement. He has not looked at many wars and the censorship policies of those wars. If he thinks that war, with television cameras and printed and radio media everywhere was the most heavily censored war, it is a little bit difficult to take. I understand his desire to sell the amendment, but we still have to do it on the basis of accuracy.
I would like to point out what this amendment really talks about. First of all, I think there is a possibly unintended but nevertheless crucial inaccuracy in the opening clause which says: "where an order or regulation made under section 4 is approved under section 7, the

May 5, 1992
Government Orders
Secretary of State for External Affairs shall", and it goes on.
I just want to point out to the member for Winnipeg South Centre, who submitted the amendment, that the document or Order in Council the secretary of state tables does not require approval. It is tabled in the House for information. I just point out that there is an inaccuracy in the procedure he has drafted in his amendment.
That aside, in section (a) it goes on to read-this is a report-"on the commercial and economic impact of the order or regulation, expressed in dollar values, and (b) on the impact of the order or regulation on the lives and living conditions of the civilian population of the foreign state to which the order or regulation applies" and so on and so forth.
That is a very tall order for the department to undertake at the time we are discussing this. If it is necessary, things that are necessary need to be done.
Under the present House rules these kinds of reports are already available. As members recall, during the Gulf war a special House order was passed which convened the standing committee in a special session when the House was not sitting. It could call witnesses according to its own determination.
The Standing Orders already provide for this kind of information, possibly not in the statutory detail that this amendment asks for, but nevertheless it is available. I feel that we cannot support this amendment.

speakeroldname: Hon. Lloyd Axworthy (Winnipeg South Centre) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-53 be amended in Clause 7 by striking out line 14 at page 7 and substituting the following therefor:
"related shall remain unaffected.
7.1(1) An order or regulation made under section 4 that is approved by both houses of Parliament, whether or not amended, is subject to review by both houses of Parliament every six months following its approval.
(2)	Subject to subsection (3), a review under subsection (1) shall be commenced by motion and shall proceed in accordance with subsections 7(2) to (8).
(3)	On a review under subsection (1) the motion under subsection 7(2) may provide that the order or regulation under review, whether or not amended on the review, shall continue in effect for a specified period not exceeding six months."
He said: Mr. Speaker, considering the reaction of the government representative to the last amendment, it may appear that this amendment which is in the same spirit will not have a high level of success either.
I want to rise because it is important to point something out to the parliamentary secretary and to the Canadian public about what did happen and why this amendment is so important.
He is attempting to make the case that during the gulf war, during the period of economic sanctions, the government was forthcoming, was prepared to give all the information and it supplied people to go before the special standing committee. That was not the case.
I know time is short but let me comment just for a moment and I would ask for confirmation from my colleague for Burnaby-Kingsway. It is not a laughing matter. We, for reasons known to the House, were in Iraq for a period of two and one-half weeks to deal with the hostage problem. At that time, in late November, we had access probably unlike most Canadians, to the impact that sanctions were having on that country. One of the reasons I felt so strongly upon my return that sanctions were a preferred method to achieving our goal as opposed to undertaking a war was because we could see sanctions were working.
During that time when the then Secretary of State for External Affairs attended the standing committee and we debated the issue, he would make the statement constantly that he did not think sanctions were working.
May 5, 1992

When we asked him for evidence he did not have any or if he did, he did not give it to the standing committee. He never once produced any serious review or assessment of the workings of the sanctions program.
As a result, this country went to war without ever knowing whether or not sanctions would have worked. In fact, it betrayed a fundamental requirement of the UN charter under article 6 which said that you have to assess the impact of sanctions before you make a decision to engage in military conflict. Never once did this government, that minister, or this Parliament ever have in front of it any assessment as to the impact of sanctions.
Parliament was denied its right and we made the most crucial decision of any country at any time which was to go to war, to put its own people at risk, without ever knowing whether or not it was the right decision.
The parliamentary secretary says: "Hey, trust in us". I cannot trust in him because I went through a period where we asked the government to do exactly as these amendments asked and it refused. It would not do it and Parliament was denied the knowledge and information. That is the fact. That is the truth. That is the reason for these amendments, simply to say we should not trifle with the rights of Parliament or the rights of Canadians in the most fundamental issue, the right to know.
When there is such an important program of initiatives such as sanctions which can affect so many people in so many ways, surely to goodness while it may not be convenient for the minister and it certainly would not be convenient for the officials to have to put the material together, convenience is not the requirement of democracy; knowledge is.

Mr. Speaker, I just wanted to add once again that this amendment is important. Certainly, as the member for Winnipeg South Centre has indicated, given the response of the parliamentary secretary to earlier amendments the likelihood of passage of this one is perhaps not great.
It is important that we underscore the fact that what is being sought here is an opportunity for Parliament to make an informed decision based on facts.
As my colleague from Winnipeg South Centre indicated certainly that is not the position Parliament was in
Government Orders
when we were called in the middle of January, 1991 to vote on whether or not to go to war and whether or not to participate in offensive military action.
I must say I am proud of the decision my leader and my colleagues made in that vote. For the reasons, among others, that the member for Winnipeg South Centre has stated very eloquently we voted against Canada's participation in that war. A number of the colleagues of the hon. member for Winnipeg South Centre also voted against that, presumably for the very reasons he has outlined so eloquently.
We must learn the lessons of that experience. We cannot reverse the decisions that were made, but surely we must learn the lessons of that experience and make it clear in this legislation that there must be a full, open, informed review process before sanctions are continued. That is the purpose of this amendment and we will be supporting the amendment.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, who
would deny that all of us are entitled to information and that the lifeblood of a good working democracy is accurate information.
I would simply point out during that entire debate it was not just the standing committee that was debating whether or not sanctions were working. He may be quoting the Secretary of State for External Affairs at that time accurately as to whether or not the sanctions were working. There was debate around the world as to whether or not they were working. There was not simply disagreement here; there was disagreement everywhere on whether or not sanctions were working. They say they were working because they visited and I accept their word.
The fact is the standing orders apply to this amendment as they did to the others. The Standing Orders provide that the standing committee is entitled to hear officials, to have reports from officials, and to hear cabinet ministers. The provisions they are asking for here are already in place.

Is the House ready
for the question?

That Bill C-53 be amended in clause 4 by striking out line 16 at
page 3 and substituting the following therefor:
'Any person in that foreign state, provided that this paragraph may not apply to medical supplies or food intended solely for humanitarian purposes".
He said: Mr. Speaker, the purpose of this amendment is to ensure that the very strong voices of those who appeared before the legislative committee studying this bill urging that it be amended to require that humanitarian aid, whether it be food or medicine, not be restricted during the imposition of economic sanctions.
The import of this amendment would be to ensure that those who are most vulnerable, those who are innocent victims of sanctions, not be further victimized as a result in many cases of the repressive and brutal policies of their own governments. Canada must not be a party to that.
Once again I must remind the House of the impact of economic sanctions on the most weak and vulnerable, for example, the children in Iraq.
We heard very powerful and eloquent evidence from Dr. Eric Hoskins, who was the co-ordinator of the Harvard study team, whose 90 researchers visited Iraq in September last year. They produced a 300-page report which detailed the human impact of the gulf crisis. This followed the report of the United Nations Undersecretary General who talked about the near apocalyptic conditions facing the people of Iraq following that war.
We learned from Dr. Hoskins that Iraqi children are dying at a rate of nearly 300 excess deaths per day, that more than 50,000 Iraqi children have already died because of the war, its aftermath and economic sanctions.
I would hope that no one in this House would argue that Canada, in imposing strong and effective economic sanctions against countries which have breached international law, against countries which have in some cases terrorized their own citizens, would want to further add to the pain and suffering of those citizens.
That is why this amendment explicitly provides that the sanctions which may be imposed pursuant to this legislation shall not apply to medical supplies or food intended solely for humanitarian purposes.
It has been suggested that the exemption provisions of the legislation allowing an applicant who wishes to ensure the provision of humanitarian aid to apply for an exemption or exclusion may be adequate. Again we have to listen to the evidence of Dr. Hoskins. He states very emphatically: "It is simply not adequate let alone feasible to provide a mechanism through which individuals and organizations providing humanitarian assistance in sanctioned countries must first obtain a permit for exemption".
He goes on to explain why this mechanism which is now set out in the bill is not workable. For that reason, it is essential that the sections of the bill in clause 4 which give the government power to impose sanctions must be restricted to ensure that that power does not include the power to stop the flow of humanitarian goods or services to people in the countries which are affected by those sanctions.
I hope that this amendment meets with the approval of the House. It is certainly very much in keeping with the spirit of the legislation. It responds to the very strong representations made by a number of witnesses, including Dr. Hoskins, the Mennonite-

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order, please. On a point of order the hon. parliamentary secretary.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we are nearing the end of the debate on these amendments to the bill. I see it is five o'clock and it is time for the move to Private Members' Business.
I wonder if we could find unanimous agreement among members that we not see the clock for a few minutes so that we can finish this. I think it would suit all of us if we could do that. Would there be agreement for that?
May 5, 1992

Mr. Speaker,
I rise on the point of order. Do the parliamentary secretary and the Chair have a time in mind? There are still about four amendments, some of which are quite crucial and I think will result in debate.
We are certainly open to continuing but we do not want to do it simply to try to steamroller things through as long as we can be allowed proper opportunity to express our point of view.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it certainly would not be my intention to try to cut off debate. The difficulty we have is that we started later than we intended due to the vote and the fact that it took longer than we anticipated. We had planned to begin this soon after three o'clock, in which case we would have been done.
I give you my word. I do not want to shorten the speeches that each of the members may want to give to the amendments but it would be nice if we could finish this afternoon because all of our schedules are tied in with it.

Mr. Speaker, I wonder if we might get clarification with respect to Private Members' Business.
Is the member who was to proceed with Private Members' Business in the House and is that member prepared to agree to our proceeding at this time? This is the hour for Private Members' Business and unless there has been consultation with the member in question I am afraid it may be somewhat difficult to proceed with the bill at this point.
I seek some guidance from the House and, more important from the member who would normally be proceeding with Private Members' Business at this point.

Mr. Speaker, I really would not mind if the debate were to continue except that sometimes it is hard to predict schedules and I have timed myself to present my private motion today.
If I could get the assurance from those who are seeking unanimous consent to extend this debate for no more than 15 minutes then I would add my approval to the request of the member for Winnipeg South Centre.

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to complicate things. The only problem is that it is not only report stage. We also have to do third reading and I think there is need for some debate. It may
Government Orders
be that we will have to find some other time to reschedule. I do not want to hold this up. Unless you want to complete report stage and then we can reschedule third reading at another time.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Is there unanimous consent to extend for 15 minutes the report stage study of the bill?
Agreed.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Agreed. The hon. member for Burnaby-Kingsway.

Mr. Speaker, because there are a number of outstanding amendments and because we have very limited time remaining at report stage I want to conclude my remarks with respect to this amendment.
I also want to point out that the Canadian Friends Service Committee which appeared before the committee indicated that the Canadian Department of External Affairs has informed them that spare parts for ambulances do not necessarily comply with the provisions for exemptions which have been set up.
I would hope that legislation would be flexible enough to ensure that this kind of thing, whether it be spare parts for ambulances, whether it be essential food stuffs, whether it be medication, would in fact be provided under the terms of the legislation.
The exemption provisions certainly are ambiguous, in emergency situations unworkable, and for that reason I would hope that the amendment might meet with the support of the House.

Mr. Speaker, I want to make it clear that we support the amendment for the reasons which the hon. member for Burnaby-Kingsway outlined. We do think it would make an important representation. I would say that it would also show that having committee hearings is of some use, that you do listen to them and you do respond to them.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would simply point out that the member said he hoped the legislation would be flexible enough for such things as spare parts and so forth. I assure him that it is because the clause begins with "may order" and therefore it does have some flexibility.

Government Orders
I would like to point out that the history of this kind of flexibility has been so widely abused because we are dealing with despots and despotism always makes the disadvantaged and the unprotected suffer the most. They always protect themselves. It was General Patton, I believe, who said: "War is hell". The next thing to war which is hell are sanctions. Sanctions hurt people and they hurt the most vulnerable.
When the United Nations first introduced its sanctions, it exempted medical supplies and food under resolution 661. It then had to amend that, because when it found out that food and medical supplies were exempted from the sanctions, the aggressor nation, in this case Saddam Hussein, abused it and used those supplies for military purposes. The Security Council adopted resolution 666 to determine whether humanitarian circumstances existed that would warrant the sale of medical supplies or food to Iraq.
The history of despots is that they will take the humanitarianism we extend to them and abuse it and use it to the furtherance of their military cause. Therefore, I say that the bill is already flexible enough to give judgment to Canada and all the other members of the multilateral organization to exercise the flexibility that the member asked for and that all of us want.
None of us want to see the disadvantaged suffer, the children with napalm bums and every other kind of tragic aspect of war which they experience. We want to minimize that in every way we can. The bill allows that kind of flexibility already.
I rise on a point of order, Mr. Speaker. I wonder, with leave, if I might just raise a brief question with the parliamentary secretary on this point?

I want to take this opportunity at report stage, in light of what the parliamentary secretary has stated, to ask him specifically, in order to apply the principle that he has enunciated with respect to protection of vulnerable children, particularly in the case of food stuffs and medicines, if he could indicate what the response is of the Ministry of External Affairs to the specific proposal which has been put forward by Dr. Eric
Hoskins with respect to the release of $2 million in Iraqi assets. It would permit the direct acquisition of food and medicines that would be channelled through humanitarian agencies which would ensure that it goes directly to those children, to those people who are the most vulnerable in these circumstances and would, in no way, as the parliamentary secretary knows, benefit the regime in power at this time?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the circumstances now are different from the time when we were "in a state of war". It was a legitimate request on the part of the doctor. As I pointed out in committee, Canada has already dedicated, I think, $23 million for food and medical supplies to the aid of the vulnerable in Iraq. The request is for $2 million. I believe the doctor is in discussions with the officials at external affairs, but I do not think it has been finally determined yet what they plan to do.

speakeroldname: Hon. Lloyd Axworthy (Winnipeg South Centre) moved:
speechtext:
That Bill C-53 be amended in clause 4 by adding immediately after line 38 at page 2, the following:
(2) For greater certainty, nothing in this Act shall be interpreted as preventing a person who is awaiting final determination under the Immigration Act as to whether the person is a refugee within the meaning of the United Nations Convention relating to the status of refugees, from being considered ordinarily resident in Canada for the purpose of this Act.
He said: Mr. Speaker, this amendment deals with the very crucial question of refugees. It is a matter that we examined quite thoroughly during the committee stage, where representation was made that there are a number of individuals who come into Canada and apply for
May 5, 1992

refugee status who could be affected by the blanket provisions of this bill if they were nationals of the country in which sanctions were being imposed. They could immediately have their own meagre or not so meagre properties frozen or, in fact, taken over. The wording of the motion itself says "only those ordinarily resident in Canada".
We proposed amendments which would exempt those who were in the refugee stream. Concern was expressed at the time that this could give rise to abuse, that for those who wanted to exploit the situation they could immediately rush off to their local office and claim to be a refugee and, therefore, find themselves in a position to evade the conditions of the bill.
What this clause does is answer that concern. We have looked at the wording very carefully and I think it is important to read it out. It says: "For greater certainty, nothing in this act shall be interpreted as preventing a person who is awaiting final determination under the Immigration Act as to whether the person is a refugee within the meaning of the United Nations Convention relating to the status of refugees, from being considered ordinarily resident in Canada". That would clearly prohibit or restrict instant refugee claimants. The wording says "is awaiting final determination under the Immigration Act". Therefore it would be impossible for anyone to abuse the system by rushing into line.
I trust that this would be sufficient wording to satisfy the government's expressed concern on the committee that it would not be a loophole for abuse, but in fact would protect the rights of refugee claimants.
I point out that we are obliged under the refugee convention to protect those rights, including the rights of property. I believe sincerely that this amendment would meet both those objectives. It would ensure that those rights are protected and at the same time it would prevent any abuse of the system.

Mr. Speaker, this is an extremely important amendment. It does not in any way require that those who are seeking refugee status must, in fact, be considered as ordinarily resident under the provisions of clause 4. All it does is give effect to an undertaking which was made by the
Government Orders
parliamentary secretary already, which is that in fact the legislation would be left open to judicial interpretation to in fact permit the possibility that in circumstances, particularly in which a refugee claimant has been resident in Canada for in some cases months or years and where the courts might interpret that that person is in fact ordinarily resident in Canada, that they should not be subject to the provisions with respect to the search and seizure of their assets in Canada.
We have been told that that is the intent of the bill. I recognize that this amendment was not before the committee, but I believe that what it does do is give effect to the intent both as stated by the parliamentary secretary and, as the parliamentary secretary will recall, as stated by the witnesses from the department who appeared before the committee.
I think it is important to make it clear that the wording simply states that nothing in the act will prevent a refugee claimant waiting final determination from being considered ordinarily resident. I think it is very important that this be adopted. It in no way diminishes the jurisdiction or the discretion of the courts in making that final determination.
It simply makes it clear that as the Canadian Council on Refugees eloquently argued in their submission to the committee, we should not close the door in all circumstances to those genuine refugee claimants who may wish to in fact be protected from the provisions with respect to sanctions.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me get this straight. The government proposed wording that said: "a national of that foreign state who does not ordinarily reside in Canada". The members of the committee objected to that, that it was far too restrictive and that they would like to have an opportunity for refugee claimants and convention refugees to be considered as an exception. We were prepared to go along with that and therefore drafted an amendment something like this to satisfy that kind of request.
This morning when we met there was discussion about this provision which said that probably is more restrictive than the government's original wording. It was not only government members saying that, I might add.

May 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
I thought that there was a general understanding at this morning's committee that the original wording of the government amendment was probably more generous than this kind of amendment. That was the conclusion that I came to, as to what both sides of the committee had come to agree upon. Therefore, it is not unusual that I would prefer the original government wording. If it is as we understood this morning in committee, that the original government wording was more generous than the one that creates the exception of the convention refugee, then I would opt for the original government wording since that has the intent of what this amendment is supposed to do already.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
It being 5.20 p.m., pursuant to Standing Order 30(6), the House will now proceed to consideration of Private Members' Business as listed on today's Order Paper.
I may remind hon. members that this debate will last for one hour, until 6.20 p.m.

That this House demonstrate its desire to see Canada as a world leader in the field of medical and pharmaceutical technology by urging the Minister of National Health and Welfare to reinstate funding to the Health Protection Branch test facilities for new drugs and medical devices.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that my private motion has been selected for debate today. Its timeliness is evident as we hear and read the stories of patients dying while waiting for new drugs that wait and wait for approval. It is timely as well as we hear of Canadian pharmaceutical industries struggling to compete globally-
May 5, 1992

This motion is aimed at prompting this government to put more staff and money into the testing of devices and drugs, getting them on to the market more quickly and into the hands of patients.
Let me begin with the Health Protection Branch drug approval process. According to the Auditor General in his 1987 report:
There is growing evidence that Canada's system of drug submission review is not performing in an efficient and timely manner. The response time for new drug submission significantly exceeds the 120-day limit prescribed in the regulations.
The review time for new drug submissions is increasing at a significant rate. The review times for other types of submissions are also increasing. Coincident with the increase in the length of time for review, there has been a sharp increase in the accumulated backlog. In 1982, there were 243 drug submissions awaiting HPB review. In 1986, there were 1,112.
In 19921 do not know because no information could be provided by the office of the minister of health.
The audit summarized that the cost of HPB inefficiency was huge. Canadians did not have timely access to new drugs. There was bad blood between industry and government, and Canada suffered in the global economy because we could not get our drugs to market quickly.
It is now May 1992, five years later. What has changed? Nothing. Industry and government are still duelling. Drugs, devices and vaccines wait indefinitely for approval. Our economy sits in the comer waiting to be asked to dance by the pharmaceutical industry.
Something is very wrong at the Health Protection Branch. It is a directorate with a siege mentality, fearful and paranoid, and with good reason. The directorate has few friends in this country. It must continually watch its back as those inside try to protect their jobs and their ministers. It is not a healthy environment. It is not an environment that we can afford to maintain.
The paranoia at HPB is so high that I was refused a briefing on its activities recently. Initially there was a promise but apparently when the request was formally considered at the highest bureaucratic level, permission was denied. One wonders why. Was the Health Production Branch afraid to be probed? Fortunately I have been
Private Members' Business
able to access other sources, including critics of the system, of which there are many.
I thank the HPB personnel who spoke off the record, the companies that co-operated and the journalists who also get no co-operation from health and welfare for their insight.
The picture they paint of the drug approval process is one coloured by bad policy and lack of leadership. This becomes apparent in any dealings with the bureau, even for something as innocent as gaining information for my debate today.
My staff was given the runaround for many days by health protection officials, leaving them angiy and frustrated, not unlike the companies that have submissions gathering dust in HPB offices.
My staff found every avenue blocked, every access to information denied. Then finally late last week came the final slap in the face. An assistant to the director general of the drugs directorate said the reason my office could not be given a briefing was because HPB officials and staff were too busy working on today's response for the minister. No doubt the response will be a glorious picture of the HPB drug approval process.
HPB is a directorate with fortress mentality, focused on protectionism. Protecting the ministers and saving their own jobs is key, not reform of the system and efficiency. While my staff was stalled for days, Canadian drug companies had been stalled for years. Canadian consumers are being prevented from getting access to new medications as quickly as possible. In some cases, only strong public pressure has been able to light a fire under reviewers, getting important drugs to very ill people.
The minister knows this and so did his predecessor, and his predecessor's predecessor. Allow me to quote from a new release of the present Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, then minister of health on July 14, 1988. I quote:
Health and Welfare Minister Jake Epp today announced plans to
streamline the approval of new drugs and improve management of
the government's drug review process. An additional 50 person-

May 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
years and $13.6 million have been allocated to the drug review program for the current fiscal year.
We have set a target of 20 per cent increase in efficiency over the next three years, and I expect that the current backlog of some 1,000 new drug submissions now in the system will be eliminated in that time.
Well, the minister was wrong. The backlog was not eliminated. The drug approval process is jammed with submissions. Now, with the crisis over breast implants, approval of medical devices is also being delayed. Vaccines too are not immune to the slowdown at HPB.
The situation is further complicated by protectionism. Reviewers are suspected of delaying approvals in hopes that drugs will come on the market in other countries first. Being a follower may well be the safer position to play, especially if your job depends on protecting your boss, but that is lack of leadership.
HPB has a mandate to protect the safety of Canadians. In fact, the drug review process was bom out of the thalidomide tragedy of the 1960s.
I believe public safety is paramount in drug approval. I believe safety first should be demanded of the HPB, but I do not believe public safety should be used as a screen to hide inefficiency or cowardice on the part of HPB leaders.
Reviewers are hired to make a decision based on the data available. They should be tops in their field, well versed in clinical practice and research. They should be an authority on drugs, devices, and biologies. That is why they have been hired. They do a very important job and the onus is on them to do it well and without delay. Delays cost lives, jobs, and money.
Reviewers do not run HPB. They are not responsible for the lack of leadership in the directorate over the past decade. They do not hold the party strings either. Let me continue from Mr. Epp's press release of 1988: "For a number of years Canada like most other countries in the western world has had difficulties keeping up with the increasing number of new drug submissions within regulatory timeframes". This was recognized by the Eastman commission of 1984, the ministerial task force on program review, and in the 1987 Auditor General's report I earlier alluded to.
In January 1987 a government, industry, private working group headed by Mr. Kenneth Stein was formed to
find ways of clearing the backlog of new drugs awaiting review and recommend ways to promote timely access to drugs without lowering Canada's high standards for drug assessment.
Allow me at this juncture to tell my colleagues in this House of the death of a cystic fibrosis patient in Winnipeg just last February while awaiting notice of compliance for a new drug that has been shown in the United States to be beneficial. Just a week ago I got another call again from a patient with cystic fibrosis now severely ill in the hospital asking why this same drug has not yet been released.
The Stein report sat on the shelf unnoticed by government until the Auditor General's report jolted the minister into action. It is my feeling that these studies are placebos for the pharmaceutical industry, shortcir-cuting criticism.
Recently the government commissioned yet another study, this time by the very well respected Dr. Denis Gagnon, vice-rector of research at the University of Laval. The mandate of Dr. Gagnon is to provide recommendations that will "continue to ensure the safety, efficacy and quality of drugs, while at the same time ensuring the timely availability to Canadians and minimizing the regulatory burden".
I look forward to this report which will be completed in June. Yet still I remain skeptical. What assurances do we have that the minister will breathe life into the recommendations? What assurances do we have the HPB approval process will become more than a Canadian centre for risk avoidance?
I hope the minister will give his word today, here in the House of Commons, that the Gagnon report will not die in obscurity when presented. I hope the minister will not rely solely on a carefully prepared text from his apprehensive personnel at HPB. I want to hear him say he will clean out the cobwebs at the Health Protection Branch.
The cobwebs loom large. Over three years have passed since Mr. Epp leased the 50 additional person-years. Yet today the backlog is reputedly three years deep, worse than ever before. Granted, the HPB receives more submissions, but there was not an adequate reworking of the system to make it more efficient. It is the business of companies to turn out products. It is HPB's business to approve them, or to disapprove them, but not to hold them in limbo.
May 5, 1992

I have heard it takes HPB researchers a year and a half to open a file on a new applicant and begin review. Full product approval often takes three years. Some drag on longer. Some, still, are caught in the system indefinitely. Not good news for companies that may have invested $150 million in a new drug.
Recently our Prime Minister visited the opening of a Merrick Frostt research facility in Montreal, no doubt happy for the photo opportunity. Meanwhile, the company's drug submissions may be gathering dust along with hundreds of others in offices of health and welfare.
At the same time an ocean away, in England, this same approval process takes place in six months to a year. I put this question through you Mr. Speaker. If you were a pharmaceutical company chief executive officer, where would you take your drugs for approval? I hope the HPB is watching the United Kingdom. The rest of the world surely is.
Detractors might argue that the Canadian drug approval model guarantees safety. I believe efficiency and safety can go hand in hand. Britain is proof. There is no proof that the safety of British citizens is being jeopardized because of quick approval.
Safety and efficacy are independent criteria in drug approval, yet both can be accommodated. With improved efficiency will come quicker approval without sacrificing safety. Hopefully we will be better able to help Canadians and the people of the world suffering from life-threatening illnesses and diseases.
One of the key problems at HPB is that there are too many pockets of air in the review process, too much down time, too few reviewers. Hire the people you need. Contract out when necessary. Hire a panel of clinical experts to give the final nod. Seek international collaboration, but please clean up the review process.
My contacts have painted a rather unflattering portrait of the health and welfare drug review process. I was told reviewers work very, very hard, to the detriment of safety. On the other hand, I was told they take time away from files to pursue some other courses.
I was told they are underpaid and terrified of screw-ups that could embarrass the minister. I was told they are underskilled and stuck in a 1960s review process. I was
Private Members' Business
told better researchers and more of them are needed. I was even told that the drug approval process is intentionally bogged down by staff who need to justify their existence, that for them the backlog is like a government sponsored Registered Retirement Savings Plan.
I do not think it is fair, however, to blame the backlog at HPB on the reviewers. The blame should lie squarely on the shoulders of the ministers and the directors who have the power to make changes.
I believe there can be a balance between business and safety, yet health and welfare has tipped that balance so far that it has become protectionism. There is a mountain of difference between safety and protectionism.
It is protectionism of the department and the department's ministers more than protection of the Canadian public. This slowness of approval is hurting Canada and it is handicapping our pharmaceutical industry.
One health protection employee said he fields calls from irate company executives who say: "We came here from the States because your government promised things would be better. Then why has our product been in the system for two and a half years?"
Another company spokesperson, whose work involves life-saving vaccines, said: "What has happened at HPB is that over time resources have been allowed to dwindle. We have no problem with the level of expertise that is there, but we need more. We need more experts and more capabilities".
I have heard industry say: "How can we compete when we cannot even get our own products licensed? This is a cut-throat business. If we cannot get approval in the country that developed the vaccine or drug, it does not look good when we try to market it internationally".
Global Tek Company of Vancouver is an example of trying to develop a diagnostic test kit for meningitis. Until now, that has not come to full fruition because of problems with the HPB. The minister should be held responsible for this.
Other companies say: "It is frustrating when regulating organizations cannot keep pace with development". They point to an almost anti-drug, anti-industry feeling at health and welfare. I quote from one source: "Just because there is a whole host of drugs on the market does not mean they are the best drugs. We need new and

May 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
better drugs, drugs with fewer side effects, drugs that work more quickly.
I will end by again calling on the minister to clean up the regulatory review process and the Health Protection Branch. Put more money into the system and make it more efficient. Help Canada to pull ahead on the world stage, a country that cleverly can do more with less. How many studies do you need to tell you what you already know? The system needs a complete overhaul. Can you do what your predecessors did not do before you, I ask the minister? Can the minister bring the Health Protection Branch into the 21st century?
I hope this motion will prompt this government, this minister, to do what has to be done for Canada to lead in the biotechnology field in the world.
