Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise in my place today and to respond to the hon. member's motion.
I am certain that all members of the House want to see Canada become a world leader in the field of medical and pharmaceutical technology. I think it is important to emphasize that the laboratories of the bureau of drug research do not have any direct responsibility for the development of new drugs. Responsibilities for the pharmaceutical and medical device development lie with the industries and the government is taking the necessary steps to encourage research and development in Canada.
Research conducted in the Health Protection Branch is designed to support the scientific basis for the regulatory decision-making. Authorization for the marketing of new drugs and medical devices is contingent upon the branch receiving acceptable evidence of product safety, quality and efficacy.
The branch itself is not responsible for generating the data but is charged with the responsibility of having sufficient expertise available to make sound judgments on the submissions which it receives.
If the branch judges the new drug to be safe and effective then the manufacturer is authorized to market it. Accordingly the branch's research is limited to studies on the safety of medical devices and investigations needed to ensure that the medicines available to Canadians are safe and effective. In other words, the research provides the background knowledge needed to support the review process.
The department continues to evaluate the safety, quality and efficacy of pharmaceuticals. No manufacturer can market a new product without obtaining a notice of compliance or a drug identification number from the drugs directorate. A priority of the branch is in fact to eliminate the backlog in the review of submissions from manufacturers who wish to market new products.
The department also has vigorous inspection, enforcement and adverse reaction reporting programs in place. It is also conducting studies into the best means of identifying adverse reactions and making their proper attribution based on epidemiology and appropriate laboratory work. These programs are meant to ensure the continuing quality of drug products and medical devices
May 5, 1992

and to protect the public against problems that may only surface once the product is marketed and used by more patients than could possibly be included in the pre-marketing clinical tests.
The Bureau of Drug Research has a team of chemists, toxicologists, pharmacologists and pharmacists able to tackle virtually any problem pertaining to pharmaceutical quality.
It is also important to remember the government has introduced a number of measures designed to encourage the development of Canada's research-based communities including the health care industry. Among these are the Medical Research Council's University-Industry Program, a similar program established by the Natural Science and Engineering Research Council, the National Research Council Industrial Research Assistance Program, the establishment of a number of networks among the national Centres of Excellence and special funding provided through the National Biotechnology Strategy.
Government research laboratories are eligible to receive funding through the National Biotechnology Strategy and the department has received support targeted toward enhancing its laboratory capability, that is commensurate with the developing biotechnology industrial capacity. Government laboratories may also be associated with the research expertise resident in the academic-industrial networks of excellence and branch laboratories are participating in certain networks.
Further, the matching funds policy of the Medical Research Council provides for the generation of funds for research that match the funds derived from the industry. The funding available under this policy has been integrated into the base budget of the council. Similar action has been taken with respect to the Natural Science and Engineering Research Council. The matching funds university-industry programs are under review led by the Medical Research Council. These policies have done much to promote pharmaceutical research and development in Canada.
The government has endorsed multilateral trade proposals to strengthen patent protection for pharmaceuticals. Stronger patent protection greatly improves the
Private Members' Business
climate for investing in pharmaceutical research and development and the atmosphere in which innovation can take place.
Canada's international competitiveness in attracting new investment to the health care industry will be enhanced. Changes to the current patent protection regime reflect three very important objectives. They are as follows: First, the availability of more and better medicines and treatments for the diseases that affect Canadians; second, more research and development to occur in Canada; and third, the provision of medicines at reasonable prices for Canadians.
In conclusion, the scientific staff of the Health Protection Branch serves on various committees of the granting councils such as the MRC and the NSERC and support the NRC's IRAP program. There are numerous liaisons with the academic community and various joint projects with universities. The branch is able to maintain a high level of the research expertise through these contacts and its in-house programs.
Laboratory programs of the Health Protection Branch are continuously reviewed to ensure that they are resilient and adaptable to the challenges of a rapidly advancing health care frontier. The capacity of the Bureau of Drug Research continues to be strong and broadly based. High-class laboratory support continues to be provided to the Health Protection Branch in priority areas.
In conclusion, while the intent of the motion is a good one and one can understand that, the means are not acceptable at this time.

Mr. Speaker, the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands and myself will be splitting our 10-minute time.
Motion 538 is being debated just as the external review of the Canadian drug approval system or process is scheduled for completion in June. Therefore this debate is very timely. Dr. Gagnon of Laval has been asked to report on the key issues respecting drug approval with special emphasis on resources required in testing for Canada, the possible international harmonization of testing rules and the privatization of the process.

May 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
The House should be aware that the review is really being prompted by cuts in budget to Health and Welfare. Despite the government's continual insistence that safety will not be compromised, the present situation dictates that risks will increase as the government attempts to pass off privatization as the answer to a situation that is created through budget cuts.
Let us look at the budget for the Health Protection Branch in the last three years. In 1990-91 it was $65.6 million and had 734 person-years. This year it has been reduced to $64.4 million and 715 person-years, a reduction of 19 person-years. In effect, the branch has gone backwards with regard to funding and personnel for dealing with drug approvals for the past three years. No wonder such antagonists as the generic drug manufacturers and the brand name manufacturers agree that a quicker method for approval must be found.
There is little doubt that Professor Gagnon is expected to arrive at the obviously preferred solution of privatization. Even if he does not, the present fiscal climate will dictate it. Indeed outside persons are playing a role already in drug approval and it certainly will be expanded by this government.
Before we privatize the testing system, should we not be aware of the risks? In making inquiries about the testing of pharmaceuticals I have learned there is a simple equation. If clinical tests of drug effectiveness are performed in faster time, less data will result. That means if tests are conducted with hundreds of humans, the effects that occur in one in one thousand will not be detected and there are going to be difficulties.
Perhaps the best known case is thalidomide. Thalidomide was a typical modem minor therapeutic drug produced by major drug manufacturers, which was approved in some countries but not in others. Once these tragedies occur they are irreversible. Given the differences in liability law, it has meant a very unequal life for the children who have been affected.
There are other much more recent cases where we have had controversial drags. In the last few months concerns about Prozac and Halcion have been raised. We have also had medical devices with continued problems, such as the Meme breast implant. These situations still exist. The question is whether we want more or less of
them. The answer is that we will get more if we privatize the approval process.
There are other risks in the privatized system. In Canada we have seen the scandals of testing done in the 1980s by Industrial Bio-Test, a U.S. firm. In seeking approval for products it had been commissioned to test, IBT simply falsified test results. These tests were for agricultural chemicals and Agriculture Canada had to spend much valuable time and effort to confirm whether the material it received was true.
The same commercial pressure will apply to a privatized system for drugs. Each additional month of marketing time means millions in sales, given the kind of high-priced drug promotion that goes on in Canada today. Without professionally disinterested public servants being central to the process, the pressure for cheating could be enormous, particularly when a rival drug in a similar stage is seeking approval.
The drug testing changes can be seen in the same light as the changes we have seen in the drug protection patent laws. The U.S. government and U.S. multinationals have unilaterally forced us to change our generic drug laws. Already the government has said it will change the patent protection for brand drugs from 10 to 17 years. It is quite clear that is not what Canadians either want or deserve as a public policy from this government. It is what the multinational drug companies want, and that is what we will get from this government.

Mr. Speaker, I just want to begin by thanking my colleague from Surrey North for graciously allowing me to share his time, as he is the person in the New Democratic Party responsible for health issues.
The purpose of my intervention tonight is to talk about a case that really highlights what the Health Protection Branch does for Canadians.
I would like to speak to one aspect of this bill, namely the importance of access to new drugs and the continued protection for people relying on these drugs for their very survival.
Until last summer I was unaware of the Emergency Drug Release Program, which is part of the Health Protection Branch. Since that time I have on several occasions made use of the excellent service it provides in
May 5, 1992

the release of new drugs or those drugs only available in other countries.
The case of one of my constituents drew my attention to this. He was a grand mal epileptic who had finally found a drug to control his seizures with the assistance of his physician. When he was faced with the devastating withdrawal of this drug, it was brought to my attention. Without this drug he would be unable to work. He would be forced into some form of dependency, and would experience a serious loss of personal freedom and dignity most of us would find hard to accept.
The company that produced the drug had withdrawn the drug from the market for unknown financial reasons. The personal devastation their decision would have on this young man demanded a response. This case introduced me to the Emergency Drug Release Program.
In partnership with one of the program doctors, I was able to secure a year's supply of the drug my constituent required. A year bought him the time to gradually switch to another combination of drugs with the same essential ingredients. Unfortunately these drugs must be imported as they are currently unavailable in Canada.
Since then, on subsequent occasions I have again made use of this excellent program to secure new experimental drugs for cancer patients.
However, the fact that we must use these sorts of programs at all worries me. What is holding back our own approval process, preventing Canadian companies from producing drugs so urgently needed by our own people?
I would like to join my colleagues in this House and support their call against the privatization of testing facilities and to reinstate adequate funding to one of Canada's outstanding federal government departments, the Health Protection Branch of National Health and Welfare.
As I know from personal experience, its work is vital. Canadians would only benefit from their expertise in drug approval.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to participate in this debate.
Private Members' Business
It is a very special occasion for me because it marks the first anniversary of the new addition to the Corbett family, a grandson, my first grandchild today. He was bom in Montreal, Quebec, and he is the Corbetts' newest Canadian.
The motion that we are concerned with today is the decision to close the drugs directorate's laboratory activities in the Natural Products Section and Drug Residue Section of the Bureau of Drug Research, Health Protection Branch.
A stringent review of the priorities within the drugs program was conducted immediately following the budget of February 1991 in reaching the decision. I can tell you that the reduction in laboratory work is a reflection of limited available resources and not of the quality or intrinsic importance of the studies that have been conducted in these areas.
It is the responsibility of pharmaceutical manufacturers and the medical device industry to invent new products for the Canadian market and the government encourages industrial R and D. The Health Protection Branch's role is to review the information provided by the industry.
The government took action in 1987 in support of enhanced pharmaceutical research and development in Canada when changes were made to the Patent Act. Bill C-22 granted drug patent holders a period of market exclusivity of seven years against manufacturing in Canada and 10 years against importation. In response, the innovative pharmaceutical industry made a public commitment to increase its R and D expenditures as a percentage of sales to 8 per cent by 1991 and to 10 per cent by the end of 1996 from the then existing level of 4.9 per cent. This commitment represented new spending on pharmaceutical R and D totalling $1.4 billion over the 10 year period.
I think it also appropriate at this point to mention that not only do the pharmaceutical companies that are represented by this group represent a commitment to Canada's R and D research, but as well, the generic industry that is well represented in this country and contributes handsomely to the pharmaceutical industry in the nation contributes significantly to employment levels and to the pharmaceutical prestige that this country has in the international community. We should

Private Members' Business
make every reference and opportunity to encourage those people as well.
As reported by the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, total R and D expenditures by pharmaceutical patent holders increased from $165.7 million in 1988 to $281.3 million in 1990. The R and D to sales ratio rose from approximately 6 per cent to approximately 9 per cent in this period. According to data from the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association, basic research increased to a total of $70.1 million in 1990 from $30.3 million in 1988. Government policies to enhance intellectual property rights in this area have resulted in the pharmaceutical industry becoming a major source of total research funding in the health field.
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association of Canada established its Health Research Foundation which broadly covers the various disciplines involved in research in pharmaceutical therapy in the late 1980s. Most of the foundation's awards are matched by the Medical Research Council through the university-industry program.
The government took steps in 1988 to enhance health research in Canada with the introduction of the Medical Research Council University-Industry Program. Since the inception of the program, a total of $44.4 million has been provided, of which industry provided 58 per cent and the government, through the MRC, 42 per cent. The average value of the awards has been about $400,000. More than 90 per cent of the industrial participants in these programs are pharmaceutical companies, with the remainder mostly medical device companies and a few computer companies.
Government initiatives toward enhancing health research in Canada have been successful and productive. The mandate of the Health Protection Branch, while encouraging the development of a first class industry and academic research community in Canada, is primarily directed toward the review of information provided by manufacturers who wish to introduce products on to the market. To this end it conducts in-house research in support of product review in those areas perceived to be of the greatest urgency and priority.
The drug review program is under external assessment at the present time and a report is expected in the next
few months. Matters under consideration include the nature of product review and how reviews can be more expeditiously conducted while maintaining assurance of the protection of the Canadian public. Comparisons will be made of the review and supporting research infrastructure as it exists in Canada with the counterpart systems in place in comparable jurisdictions in the EEC and the U.S.A.
The issues being deliberated by the committee also include various regulatory options and program resourcing. The department will await the tabling of the final reports before embarking on any strategic planning of resources for the medical devices program and drug review program.
The department's approach continues to be to maintain a strong and adaptable component of laboratoiy research in support of health protection programs in Canada. The scientific capacity of the Bureau of Drug Research continues to be strong and flexible. There is a broad base of expertise with built-in adaptable laboratory capability.

Mr. Speaker, at the outset I would like to congratulate the member for Winnipeg North who has raised this important issue in the House of Commons. I think it demonstrates how members who have knowledge of a subject and who are hard working can press this system in an important way to make changes that are beneficial for all Canadians.
The essence of this bill is that without sacrificing one iota of safety, and safety must be paramount, drugs can and must be brought to the benefit of Canadian consumers much more quickly than at present.
The bureaucracy is bogging down the process and denying to patients in Canada in many cases, as cited by my hon. colleague from Winnipeg North, the benefit of those new drugs. It is worth the investment he has asked for.
I wish to touch on a related issue. It deals with another way in which Canadians are impeded from getting the type of medical treatment they deserve. I bring to this House once again the example of Global Tek, a Vancouver corporation which in 1990 entered into a contract with the National Research Council. It was an IRAP contract
May 5, 1992

which involved the sharing of costs for the development of a new medical test for meningitis.
Under this contract it was specified by the National Research Council that the government's representative would be a Dr. Brodeur who works in the Health and Welfare laboratories here in Ottawa. Dr. Brodeur is a well recognized authority in the world of medicine for having developed certain types of antibodies in related areas.
The company, Global Tek, spent $250,000 and the government under its IRAP put up matching funds of $250,000. It would have paid even more but the taxpayer was able to keep these expenses down. Three Global Tek employees worked for considerable time in this Health and Welfare laboratory and developed a type of antibody which was going to be effective for the test they had in mind.
During the period that they worked together, the three employees in the Health and Welfare laboratory, Dr. Brodeur was the over-all person in charge, but he had very few contacts with those three employees.
The advice of another person, Dr. Hamel from Health and Welfare, was sought occasionally on procedures in the laboratory. Where is this? Where is that? In essence, these three individuals were the ones responsible for the research and for all of the work.
The dispute is as follows. A discovery was made of an antibody. Global Tek wants to go into commercial production of a test. The government is saying that it owns the antibody.
Let us look at the facts. Everyone agrees that Dr. Brodeur discovered some five years ago an antibody against Hemothilis meningitis. That is true, this is accepted by Global Tek.
During the time these three employees worked under the loose supervision of Dr. Brodeur, they developed two other antibodies. The one in question is a Neisseria meningitis antibody. It was developed by those three people.
The government is saying it owns that Neisseria meningitis antibody. It will not give it to the private sector firm, unless it is under licence and the private sector firm admits that the government owns it.
Private Members' Business
This was a project that was brought to the public sector by a private sector firm. They were the people who matched the funds. Just because it was carried out in a government laboratory does not mean in law or in fact the government owns it.
What a terrible precedent to set if our top medical researchers go to the government to get matching funds under IRAP, an excellent program which incidentally is being gutted by this government. They go to the government and say that they want to carry out this research in a fundamental area. They do it. They live up to their obligations. Something is discovered and the government keeps it. Are any other firms going to spend their money and their time going into joint public sector private sector programs, be it in medical research or any other area of endeavour if the government gives the slightest indication that it is going to steal the results of that research?
Does this mean every joint program undertaken belongs to the government laboratory in which it was done even when NRC specified it had to be done in that particular facility under the direction of Dr. Brodeur? It sets a terrible precedent for the co-operative types of efforts we need between the private and public sectors in Canada to bring new inventions to market.
I for one am incredulous that the government would not say yes it is yours, it is specified in section 6, appendix B of the contract with the NRC that every discovery belongs to Global Tek. It is clear in law that the results of that research are to be carried out and be the property and benefit of the private sector corporation.
The government's published guidelines on this issue state it wants to encourage transfer of the ownership from the government to the private sector firms. Why? It is because the government is not in a position to commercially exploit these goods.
It is the private sector initiatives which come forward and I welcome the help of the public sector in these areas. We have been calling for more of it. It is the private sector firm which has the initiative, which has the idea, which brings its own expertise tapped on to by the government that is going to then be able to build the test out of these antibodies and commercialize this test for Neisseria meningitis around the world.
Unfortunately we felt that we had to raise this issue in the public forum. It should never have come to this. The government should have followed its guidelines. It should have followed the clear contractual obligations

May 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
that it had undertaken to ensure that the results of all these discoveries that took place belonged to the company. This matter has been discussed for some time now with the minister for science and technology. He made
inquiries.
National Health and Welfare is saying: "Yes, it was discovered in our laboratory and yes, there is a contract. Yes, it was under this contract that the work was done, but really the invention is ours because it was done in our laboratory and because the nominal head of the project, who only offered consultation advice on a very limited basis was not there all the time doing the work. It was not his idea to do it, originally. It was a government official".
That is not right. It is not proper. It is wrong in law. It sets a terrible precedent. It is the type of precedent that is retarding the bringing to market of this test for meningitis. Why should this company go ahead and license its own discovery from the government when it owns it in law and in fact?
We encourage the minister of health to look into this immediately, to work to ensure that this is commercially exploited. We encourage him as well to accept the recommendations of my learned friend and colleague from Winnipeg North who has put before this House a bill which is designed to do nothing but enhance the health opportunities for all Canadians, for which we all commend him.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first I would like to say that the health protection branch is certainly not afraid of being probed. In fact it is having certain areas reviewed today. That of course is absolutely right and should be ongoing.
I want to say that the hon. member for Winnipeg North has made some very strong statements here in the House tonight. I believe that some, if not all, of these allegations are unfounded and really have to be addressed.
The first item I noted is that the member said he had been refused a briefing, he had been refused information from the Department of National Health and Welfare.
This just is not so.
In fact, I went right out and spoke to officials from the department while my colleague was speaking. They have no knowledge whatsoever of a refusal to provide information or to provide briefings from the department. I really have to challenge my colleague on that particular statement he made in the House.
I am certainly going to get in touch with him and I am going to ask him-

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The parliamentary secretary is trying to impugn my integrity. I will produce evidence and witnesses to support the statements I made in this House.
The parliamentary secretary cannot hide and protect the minister and his department and in so doing impugn my integrity. If she is prepared to do that, she can rise on a question of privilege and then we will debate the question of privilege.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was going to continue and say that I will be in touch with the member for Winnipeg North to get the pertinent facts as he revealed them. I want to say to him that the department makes every effort to accommodate MPs on their requests and briefings. I will look into everything that he has said tonight.
With regard to another thing I think I heard him say, he was quoting from a speech that the hon. Jake Epp made when he was Minister of National Health and Welfare. We do have a publication entitled: "Three Years Progress" which points out that we have markedly reduced the backlog for new drugs.
We approved the anti-AIDS drug, the DDI, in a record seven months. We did that in a joint review with the United States FDA. Also we have had 140 contracts for outside review. That is called contracting out. I think the member was also advocating this and I commend him. We are doing that.
We have published over 20 guidelines to make our processes for drug approval very understandable and very open. Indeed they should be. We have pushed international harmonization of our regulatory requirements.
May 5, 1992

I would be pleased to provide this information by noon tomorrow to the hon. member. As I said, I will be in touch with him to make sure that I get the specific details so I can look into the matter. No member of Parliament should be refused a briefing by any department.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The time provided for the consideration of private members' business has now expired. Pursuant to Standing Order 96(1) the order is dropped from the Order Paper.
A motion to adjourn the House under Standing Order 38 is deemed to have been moved.

Mr. Speaker, on March 16, 1992,1 asked the President of the Treasury Board whether he intended to withdraw clauses of Bill C-55 that allowed the government not to pay premiums by refusing to pay the employer's contributions to match the employee's or to change and even reduce the interest rate on pension funds without consultation.
According to some interpretations of Bill C-55, the government could deindex a pension, reduce pension benefits and radically alter pension funding through regulation instead of legislation.
The minister answered me in the House that his government had no intention of doing so and he even went so far as to say that Bill C-55 contained no such measure. Nevertheless, when the Comptroller General of Canada appeared before the Legislative Committee on Bill C-55 the next day, he himself admitted that it would be possible to change pension plans without passing or amending a law. He then promised to seek a legal opinion on it.
On April 15, 1992, one month later, the President of the Treasury Board issued a press release in which he said that he was sorry that statements by the Federal Superannuates National Association on the security of
Adjournment
pensions, which were later supported by the Public Service Alliance of Canada, could have aroused unnecessary fears among some Public Service and Canadian Forces pensioners. He added that a thorough review showed that the powers in section 71 of the proposed law would not allow changing or abolishing acquired rights, including pension indexation.
He continued, and this is the interesting part, by saying that nevertheless, in order to reassure federal retirees and active public servants, he had written to the chairman of the parliamentary committee studying Bill C-55 to inform it that the government intended to propose an amendment that would explicitly limit the scope of the regulatory powers in that respect.
In a letter that he sent to the chairman of the legislative committee on Bill C-55, the President of the Treasury Board himself said that the proposed amendment would specify that only the changes affecting pension indexing would be set forth in legislation.
That is what we were asking, that is what we wanted, that is what we were promised and that is what we wanted to see in Bill C-55. You will agree with me that it is quite curious that even though he pleads not guilty, the President of the Treasury Board says that he is prepared to carry out the sentence and correct the wording of the bill.
At the same time, I am glad to see this change in position as a result of the many concerns expressed by the various groups that appeared before the parliamentary committee, the unions and members of this House who care about the well-being of past and present employees of the Government of Canada.
I am also pleased that the President of the Treasury Board has made a commitment to consult all concerned before making any decision whatever on pension indexing and pension plan management.
This experience shows us that a careful review in committee can be constructive. The government, perhaps inadvertently, had submitted a bill that we thought contained an interpretation that was not so clear. To prevent unclear legislation from being passed in this Parliament, we did what the opposition is supposed to do and asked the government to explain. Now that the government has done so, I think Hansard will show that we were right.

Adjournment

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to respond to the three issues which have been raised.
The first issue concerns the possibility that Bill C-55 would give the government the power to change the indexing provisions of the Public Service pension plans by regulation.
As the President of the Treasury Board previously explained to the House, the government has never had any intention of changing inflation protection for Public Service pensions in such a way.
A thorough review of Bill C-55 has confirmed that the authority in the proposed new section 71 of the Public Service Superannuation Act could not be used to modify or abolish acquired rights, including indexing.
Nevertheless, to reassure federal pensioners and employees, the proposed amendment to Bill C-55 has been drafted and given to members of the committee studying the bill. The proposal would specifically limit the scope of the government's regulation-making powers in this regard.
Regarding the government's contributions to the Public Service Superannuation Act, I would like to assure members that Bill C-55 does not provide for premium holidays by the government.
It does require the government to contribute an amount each year that is sufficient to fund benefits as they are earned by plan members regardless of whether there is an existing surplus for past service. We expect the contributions to the pension account will increase, not decrease.
Finally, setting the interest rates credited to the pension accounts by regulation is simply a continuation of existing authorities. The current rate of interest credited to the superannuation account has been in effect since 1969 but could not have been changed at any time by regulation.
Those who suggest the government use its regulationmaking powers to lower the interest credits are ignoring the fact that lower interest rates would create a requirement for offsetting higher government contributions
which would obviously not be in the government's best interest.
In sum, I think a careful reading of the bill in the presence of the proposed amendment will clearly show that issues which have been raised should not cause any concern to plan members.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to stand in this House today and further elaborate on the question that I posed to the Minister of Finance and to the minister responsible for CMHC regarding the cutback to social housing that this government had put in place with respect to the budget.
While the Conservative government's recent budget offered access to home ownership for Canadians who have savings, it also eliminated the hopes of finding adequate and affordable shelter for thousands of Canadians in need.
The cuts to Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation's social budget will severely curtail the development of new affordable units of housing for this year and the next four years.
In 1990, the funds available for new units were $86 million. The government has reduced these expenditures by more than 50 per cent in three years. There will be some $600 million less in the next five years for social housing.
The CMHC social housing budget currently reaches only 6 per cent of Canadians, but still 15 per cent of the population, over one million Canadians, need affordable and adequate shelter. These Canadians are paying more than 30 per cent of their income for housing. There are over 250,000 home owners and households paying more than 50 per cent of their income toward housing.
The budget also eliminated the co-op housing program, a cost effective federal program that has been in operation since 1973 and has also provided people with affordable housing. There are 164,000 Canadians currently on waiting lists for co-op housing. Yet this government cut the program totally, not just reduced it, but cut it totally.
Co-op housing as we all know is targeted to low income Canadians. It is also designed to meet the needs of natives, the disabled, seniors and single parent families.
May 5, 1992

The government has relegated over one million Canadians to poverty with no hope of buying a home and with no hope of finding adequate shelter.
The Conservatives have implemented positive programs that the Liberal Party has been promoting for over a year, such as the RRSP proposal for home ownership and the 5 per cent down payment. Despite the implications of these long-awaited initiatives, the government has dealt an over-all blow to the housing industry and to people seeking affordable housing.
In 1992 social housing cuts will eliminate 7,615 new units for poor Canadians in need of affordable shelter. By the end of 1993, some 12,000 units will have been eliminated. Cuts to co-op housing will eliminate 4,400 construction jobs and manufacturing jobs in 1992 because of the loss of the program. The loss of over 12,000 social housing units in the next two years, combined with the loss in co-op construction, will further depress the housing construction industry.
The construction gains expected from the RRSP proposal and a 5 per cent down payment plan will be offset by the cutbacks. Yet, as I said before, the government, while we appreciate the moves that it made on home ownership, surely does not give much hope to those who are looking for affordable housing.
In these tough economic times adding to unemployment insurance and welfare expenditures will do nothing to reduce the deficit. What this government has accomplished is the progressive elimination of the federal role in housing through the budgetary process rather than through constitutional discussion and process.
Good housing policy is good economic policy and is good social policy. The bottom line is that it is investing in people and their futures, especially the ones who need our help the most.

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to respond to the concerns that have been expressed in the House recently about social housing expenditures and the cancellation of the co-op index-linked mortgage program.
Social housing expenditures have been growing and were expected to increase by 5.1 per cent over the fiscal
Adjournment
framework. With the recently announced budget, social housing expenditures have been limited to an average growth of 3 per cent for the next five years.
Because of the limited time I am turning pages over. With respect to the termination of the co-op index-linked mortgage program, the program provided assistance for co-operative housing to promote security of tenure for households unable to access home ownership. The moderate income households who are clients of the program have more opportunity to access affordable decent housing in the private market.
Low income Canadians who cannot access decent, affordable and suitable housing in the private market will continue to be assisted through the ongoing social housing program. Co-op projects will continue to be available under the totally targeted non-profit housing program for those Canadians in need.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to pursue questions I asked on February 3 and 14 critical of the government's book publishing policy.
The Minister of Communications, with great pomp and circumstance, acted surprised that anyone, particularly me, should question his new policy for book publishers. He said everyone was happy and quoted newspaper headlines of rave reviews in support of his new financial and policy initiatives.
Three months have passed and the dust has settled. The reviews now read: "Beatty backs down writing off the Canadian publishing and Ottawa just hates to say no to U.S. investors", proving that the industry was not fooled by the attempt of this government to camouflage the impact of the cost of the first ever Canadian tax on reading, the infamous goods and services tax, or cushion the loss of the postal subsidy. They realized that the hidden 10 cent on the dollar settlement was a sugar-coated pill, just a placebo. It was not a good public policy solution and certainly did not stem the number of bankruptcies and lost jobs.
The Association of Canadian Publishers at its annual meeting expressed grave concern about the federal government's retreat from policies aimed at achieving Canadian ownership and control of book publishing in Canada. It went on to declare firm opposition to any policy which would permit foreign takeovers of Canadian owned firms in book publishing and distribution. The

Adjournment
message comes from none other than the wholly owned Canadian publishing sector. It just does not like it.
Currently three out of four books sold in Canada are foreign. That amounts to over $750 million leaving Canada each year. The reason: our markets are dominated by big multinational foreign companies.
In the late 1960s the Canadian government realized that Canadian control of cultural media was the key to our cultural sovereignty, that is why limits were placed on foreign ownership of broadcasting in this country. The 1985 Baie Comeau policy was a start in the right direction of Canadianizing book publishing and there were successes. The major retail chain, W. H. Smith, became Canadian controlled. An important book wholesaler, John Coutts Ltd., returned to Canadian ownership. The Doubleday Book Clubs were brought under Canadian control with a resulting fivefold increase in sales of Canadian authored books, and for the first time Canadian controlled publishers handled an increasing share of the distribution of imported books which account for 70 per cent of book sales in Canada.
However, Baie Comeau had some serious drawbacks. It needed changes to require approval before rather than after investments are completed and to require that real control rests with Canadians.
These changes were never made and as a result the Canadianization process slowly unravelled. Canadians found when they attempted to buy Ginn Canada that real control was not for sale. They could buy 51 per cent of the equity but veto power would remain with the foreigners.
Canadian publishers had great expectations for the government. There had been task forces, studies, and consultation. However, last January 28 the government weakened rather than strengthened its publishing policy. How? Book publishers operating in Canada will no longer be required to divest control to Canadians when the parent company changes hands. Not only will the slow move to Canadianize the industry cease but Canadian owned firms can now be sold, under certain extraordinary circumstances of financial distress to foreign investors.
Last month President George Bush even got into the act. He said: "We will knock down barriers wherever we
find them, to open markets, for instance, for our movies and books. We will fight hard against protectionism both at home and abroad".
If the government is not backing off from its Canadian book publishing policy, if it is not saying yes to whatever the President of the United States says, then why does it not send a clear message by not permitting foreign takeovers of Canadian publishing subsidiaries like Har-per-Collins, Collier-Macmilllan and Grolier which are presently before Investment Canada?
Let us hear from this government. Let us have this government make a real commitment to Canadian cultural industries, not just pretty wrapped empty boxes made in the U.S.A.

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Communications has asked me to thank the hon. member for Mount Royal for the opportunity to confirm this government's strong commitment to ensuring that Canadians control their own publishing industry.
The initiatives the Minister of Communications announced on January 28 will strengthen the Canadian-controlled sector through a better balance between industrial assistance programs and foreign investment policy.
In developing this new package the Department of Communications undertook discussions with the Canadian book publishing industry in order to develop strong and realistic policies.
At the request of representatives of the American publishing industry officials also met with them, giving them the opportunity to express their concerns regarding Canadian policy.
The new foreign investment guidelines have been strengthened through an enhanced capacity to apply the definition of Canadian control under the Investment Canada Act through the introduction of the anti-avoidance clause, and the establishment of a test for indirect acquisitions that will ensure net benefit to Canada and the Canadian owned sector in both cultural and industrial terms. The net benefit test will be strictly applied and monitored.
May 5, 1992

What exactly is meant by net benefit to Canada? Net benefit will be assessed in both cultural and industrial terms; for example undertakings to distribute imported titles through Canadian controlled publisher agents, undertakings to maintain full service distribution operations in Canada, and/or undertakings to partners with Canadian firms to publish, promote and distribute Canadian books both domestically and abroad.
Undertakings made by foreign investors will be closely monitored and enforced. The Investment Canada Act provides sanctions against non-compliance if foreign investors do not respect their commitments and they will be used when necessaiy.
To complement the new foreign investment policy the government will enhance the industrial assistance program by 260 per cent creating an additional $102 million over the next five years. Add to that the money previously committed and the Department of Communications will have a $140 million program in place.
A combination of the new $140 million publishing program and the new foreign investment policy will give Canadian publishers the support they need to prosper in the 1990s.
To conclude, the Minister of Communications said on January 28 when he announced the new publishing initiative, book publishing is vital to Canada's culture and communication infrastructure. A strong national identity requires a healthy Canadian publishing industry. This government is committed to enhancing the prosperity and the competitiveness of Canadian owned publishing houses.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
That this House do now adjourn.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the indulgence of the House with its unanimous consent to request that the member for Windsor-St. Clair speak first in this matter in my place, and that I be allowed to speak later in the normal rotation. Would that be acceptable to the House?

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to thank my colleague from Spadina for having conceded the floor to me so that I might initiate this debate.
I want to thank him as well, and I want to thank the House generally, for having acceded to this adjournment debate tonight to address the response to the violence that occurred in Toronto last night.
I would have to say it is a rather narrow construction, because the violence we saw last night really reflects a number of problems that we as Canadians, parliamentarians and governments must address.
Let me point out to you that I find myself in an extraordinarily sensitive position because I was not elected to this place to be the spokesman on racial matters in this country. I am a parliamentarian who

hoped he could represent all Canadians regardless of race or colour in the same way as other parliamentarians.
I think that is what my constituents expect of me, but I think my constituents share my view that in representing my constituents as all other members of this House must do, I would represent them on an equal basis regardless of their colour, ethnicity, national origin or any of those other secondary characteristics which differentiate Canadian citizens.
I think that is premised on the notion that we are pursuing a goal, a vision in this country in which there will be equality for all Canadians.
As you may or may not know, I joined with others today in saying that the violent outbreak that was experienced in Toronto was not an appropriate or effective way of pursuing any grievances. It is perhaps not sufficiently emphasized that it was not by virtue of the actions of any group within the black community or those who organized the demonstration in Toronto that the violence that resulted was part of any scenario of expression of concern.
I said earlier, in responding to the violence last night, that we must deal with a number of issues. I think we have to understand that what we saw last night was not a rampaging group of black youths. It was a rampaging group of mixed racial origin and ultimately the majority who caused the damage we saw there last night were white.
Because those who were involved in the violence last night that we all condemn were not minority members, it does not mean we should disregard it. You may recall that back in 1985 the New Democratic Party published a report of its task force on youth. This report was constructed on the basis of consultations with youth. A sentence from that report reads as follows: What we heard is that youth had unique problems which possess the potential for crisis. It is this potential that prompted the United Nations to declare International Year of the Youth.
The call for the International Year of the Youth on behalf of the United Nations was worded very strongly in terms of its concern. It said there was a potential for an explosion among youth. We asked the government at that time to adopt a coherent policy that would address the needs of youth in consultation with youth and recognize the unique problems confronting youth today.
We look at those young people who by their actions were hooligans. There are thousands of young people who have gone to Toronto because of their joblessness, their alienation and their sense of powerlessness. They are thrashing around for whatever means they can find to survive. Last night their anger was appended to that of minorities in this country, without being a part of the specific concerns of those minority groups.
Back in 1990 I made a speech in this House in which I pointed out that any diversion from the Canadian ethic of a commitment to social justice, any erosion of our social programs, any adoption of an alien economic and political philosophy, as would be dictated by the free trade agreement, for example, would spell dangers. These dangers would rent the essential fabric of social justice that this country had devoted so much of its history to developing.
I said that crime, violence and racism, violence against women, family dysfunction, family violence, and a whole host of things would follow when people became unemployed, feared for their future, and yet were not responded to.
As I said the other day, Canada has had a notable record of progress toward social justice that has developed over many years. This is not a time to look south for the standards of our social policies, social commitments and economic arrangements. Instead we should ask others who want to join with us in any economic arrangement to live up to our standards of social justice.
We do not want to mimic the United States. The United States has ignored the problems of the cities and it has ignored the problems of poverty. It has ignored the problems of justice and education. It has ignored the problems of youth, blacks and Hispanics. There is a pursuit of wealth for hedonistic gain at the expense of too many people. Racism feeds upon that just as racism is exaggerated by it and just as those who are minorities will suffer most as a result of it. I do not want to see that repeated in Canada.
There is an awful lot of discussion about whether L. A. could happen here. I want to emphasize that Toronto was not L. A., but if we insist in believing that the more we become like the United States the better off we are, we will see our L. A. I plead for this nation, for this
May 5, 1992

government and for our people to understand the importance of what we have accomplished.
I never expected when I was a young man that I would be in this House. I have told the story about the experience of my race in this country over the two centuries and the more we have been here. My family came here in 1828 in the pursuit of freedom from slavery and oppression.
The conditions for my people in this country deteriorated over the years. As a boy I was excluded from jobs, public accommodations and a number of other things. Much has changed since then.
One thing I have always recognized is that minorities, whether they be racial minorities, aboriginal people, women or any other groups, are not going to have their concerns met if there is not a fundamental commitment in a nation to equality, justice and equal opportunity for everybody.
The social democratic evolution of this country over the years since the war has permitted considerable progress, change and advancement in the situation of visible minorities in this country. I was elected to this House irrespective of or perhaps because of my commitment to human rights and my outspokenness with respect to those matters.
It is a testimony to the progress we have made that I was elected to this House. It is sad that the conditions that brought me and others here are now being conceded to a different set of principles, foreign to our nation, that Canadians try to resist. They will continue to resist more because they suffer so much, just as those youth who last night expressed their frustration. Unless there is a fundamental re-establishment of a vision for Canada for all people, there is going to be failure.
It is true that the events in Los Angeles elicited a sense of shared concern and experience from the visible minorities and particularly the Afro-Canadian community of this country. That is why they prepared to have a demonstration before the American embassy even before last Friday night.
Meanwhile a black man was shot again in Toronto by a police officer. To understand the depth of feeling, you have to understand that in the last 14 years, 15 black men and women have been shot by police. In Toronto alone in
the last five years, five have been killed. It is a fact that most of the shootings that have occurred in Toronto have involved black youth.
That scene has been repeated in the capital, this city. Blacks have been accosted by police and no remedy was achieved in respect of these or other complaints about the situation in Montreal, Ottawa or Toronto.
I think any other group that found themselves in that position would begin to be suspicious of those circumstances. The black community has pleaded for an effective response, but it has not just affected blacks.
It has affected Asians and aboriginal peoples. An aboriginal woman who had been raped was punished more than the rapist by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. In Vancouver there was a raid on innocent Asians because there seems to be something out of sync there.
Let me say over and over again that nobody is engaged in the rhetoric that says all police are racist. By no means is that true, any more than all Canadians or even most Canadians are racists. It is that some are and the majority have not found a way to respond effectively to deeply felt concerns of the minorities.
The police are just one element of our society. There are any number of problems in this country affecting visible minorities that have not been responded to. I said this morning that perhaps the reason why there has not been the kind of sensitivity and responsiveness to the concerns of visible minorities in this country is because of a failure of people to put themselves in someone else's shoes.
Just as men have not quite been able to understand women; just as those who are able have not been quite able to understand the disabled; just as those who are heterosexual cannot understand specifically the concerns of homosexuals or those who are differently sexually oriented, so it is that too many of the majority, especially in power and especially of influence have not been able to come to grips with the fact that if you are different in this country, your status is inevitably different.
Perhaps that explains the great insensitivity on the part of the government party, of the Official Opposition, of so many involved in the constitutional process, to what was being said by those who insisted that the charter of rights must be changed so as to recognize that all Canadians are equal, regardless of race, colour or ethnicity.
May 5, 1992

They did not understand when it was pointed out that section 15(1) which specifies that groups with respect to race or national origin or ethnicity, when it is twinned with the notwithstanding clause is, in fact, a specific declaration of difference. It is a specific declaration that there are some Canadians who are better than others or more important and more equal than others.
Thirty-three major ethnocultural and racial minority organizations in this country asked the government, asked the Dobbie-Beaudoin committee as they had been asking all of those involved in the constitutional process for over a year, to consider an amendment that would make it abundantly clear that equality is not contingent in this country and, in particular, it is not contingent on the particular attitudes of the majority at any particular time.
We asked for an amendment to section 27, which is the multiculturalism clause that would have added just these words: "That governments are committed not only to the preservation or enhancement of the multicultural heritage of Canada, but they also must be committed to the preservation and promotion of ethnic and racial equality in this country". My God, Mr. Speaker, I cannot understand how it could be difficult for anyone to understand that position. We get all kinds of excuses.
If the notwithstanding clause is to protect democracy, it must be understood that a democracy ruled exclusively by a majority that is not bound to respect absolutely the rights of minorities, is not a democracy at all.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
It is not enough to say that we will deal with it in the next round. The Canadian public will not tolerate another round very soon and the next round will be too far in the future for those of us who are concerned about our status in this country to be satisfied. It must happen now in the Canada round. It must happen now in the people's round.
If we are going to treat the rights of linguistic and cultural minorities and if we are going to treat, as we must, the status of aboriginal peoples in this country, then surely it is not a big deal to add six words to a Constitution that would ensure that all Canadians of all stripes will understand that Canadians are Canadians are Canadians in this great land. That is not much. Why can
people not stand in our shoes and understand that we are only asking what everybody else assumes they already have.
There is great frustration out there because it is not just policing that concerns us.
Any number of problems are of concern to the visible minorities of this country. We asked the Prime Minister today for a meeting with the leadership of the visible minority community and were very pleased that we will have this opportunity for a direct exchange of views with the Prime Minister. That is a progressive step. It is also a progressive step that the Minister of Justice has agreed that there should be amendments to the fleeing felony rule, if that is what we appropriately call it to examine the conditions under which deadly force is used.
We want more. We want a judicial inquiry into racism in law enforcement, in the judiciary and in the Public Service. Many are concerned about the fact that government imposes a requirement for employment equity upon private enterprise and does not respond itself. We are also concerned that employment equity is not mandatory.
We want a judicial commission not because the facts are not known, because everybody knows the facts. By God, I have here just a few of the reports on discrimination in this country. The problem is where is the response. We feel a judicial inquiry would allow all Canadians to know what the issues are and to put appropriate pressure upon governments to act rather than talk. We do not want a paternalistic response. We want a partnership in looking at these problems.
We want an amendment to the Criminal Code that would make racism in the commission of a criminal offence an aggravating factor. We want the employment equity bill revised to create mandatory affirmative action. We want the Public Service subject to that law. We want the Human Rights Commission strengthened. We want the Court Challenges Program reinstated so minorities will have a chance to use it. We want the Human Relations Institute implemented. We want the Law Reform Commission to complete its work on reform of the law with respect to minority discrimination.
There are going to be others who speak on this issue-
May 5, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today following a night of unrest and violence in the streets of Toronto to lament the tragic events which have taken place.
There is certainly a problem when persons do not feel safe in our city streets. This is why we must continue to apply ourselves most energetically at not only making Canadian communities safer, but also in restoring public confidence in the systems and institutions that are there to protect them.

I believe that the rule of law is one of the pillars of a democratic society. By maintaining the credibility of this rule, we maintain the legitimacy of democracy itself.

As Minister of Justice I have attempted to define my priorities in broad terms so that they would be understood by the public. First there is the protection of society. I am the minister responsible for the criminal law in Canada and a variety of other statutes that relate to general public safety and I am the lead minister for crime prevention.

Second, I want openness and equity to be the standard for relations between citizens and government.

The third priority is the one which I have always articulated as my top priority and it is one I call inclusive justice. An inclusive justice system or the approach to an inclusive justice involves the effort to widen the embrace of the justice system, to widen the scope of the mainstream to be defined to include all who are served by the system of justice. It refers to a system of justice that is capable of doing justice for all citizens. That clearly is the objective, but it is also apparent that the concerns expressed by the black community confirm that this work must continue.
This concept applies to many groups who have felt left out of the justice system. We must do all we can to eradicate this disaffection and dissatisfaction. The starting point for this search for inclusive justice involves understanding that there are different realities experienced even by people who live in close proximity to one another.
Last year I hosted two major national meetings designed to listen to certain Canadians talk about their views of the justice system. In June 1991 I hosted the conference on Women, Law and the Administration of Justice which was an historic event. Similarly in September 1991 I co-hosted with the Minister of Justice from Yukon, the Hon. Margaret Joe, a conference on aboriginal justice. We have reached out to groups who have felt left out and we will continue to do so.

I believe the Canadian justice system should serve all Canadians, not a hypothetical sample that represents only a hypothetical majority.

Inclusive justice is not just an ideal. It is a concept which we must translate into reality. The pain, the hurt and the frustration voiced by black Canadians should pain us all.
It is ironic that exactly a week ago tonight, I was in New York City giving a speech on the concept of inclusive justice to the America Society. At that time I talked about the importance of the credibility of the justice system for the long-term credibility of the democratic system. If people do not have confidence in the institutions of democratic society, whether they be the institutions of the justice system or of government or others, then their confidence in democracy is undermined, and at the end of the day all of society loses as its ability to govern itself in a free and open and participatory way declines.
The history of the world shows that even democratic societies can regress. There is no guarantee that once we have achieved democratic goals they will be maintained. Therefore, the price of democratic society is eternal vigilance. We must never assume that because we have achieved a goal at one stage of our history that it is guaranteed for all stages of our history unless we preserve it.
It was ironic that in discussing inclusive justice on Tbesday night in New York City, Wednesday was the day that the decision on the Rodney King case came down in Los Angeles. It generated the events which have been so shocking and so disturbing to people around the world.

May 5, 1992
Those events were what we might call the QED or the demonstrated proof of the extent to which the institutions of a democratic society can be undermined by people's lack of faith or confidence in a justice system. In that case, whether rightly or wrongly, I am not familiar with the details of the case, but there was clearly a widespread belief that the justice system had not served justice and had, in fact, demonstrated the exclusion of key segments of American society from the purview of the justice system and its protective embrace.
It is my understanding that the verdict in the Rodney King case in the United States motivated black people in Toronto to hold the demonstration yesterday. However, the shooting by police of Mr. Lawrence in Toronto last Saturday served to heighten the tension and arouse feelings of hurt and discontent.
As I mentioned in answer to a question from the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair in Question Period yesterday, my officials have been working on developing a legislative proposal for the amendment of subsection 25(4) of the Criminal Code to amend the so-called fleeing felon rule. It is my hope that a legislative proposal on this issue may be introduced in the House of Commons either before the summer recess or in the early fall.
I want to address in more detail the concept of how we achieve an inclusive justice system, this goal which is so important to the continuing strength of a democratic society.
The first thing we have to do in moving toward inclusive justice is make that intellectual leap to accept the fact that all institutions of society and institutions of the justice system are riddled with value judgments. They do not exist in some kind of pristine Olympian purity, separate from the passions and beliefs and concerns of ordinary human beings or of the views of a particular time and epic in society.
If we cannot accept the fact, and that is often the hardest intellectual emotional leap for people to make, that the institutions we value are based themselves on values, then we can perhaps come to question those values and to assure ourselves that the values which underline the system and which are the basis of the system continue to be valid in current times. We will find that in many ways, institutions which have served us well over the long term continue to be current, continue to be democratic.
In many other ways, the underlying values of the system deserve to be questioned and deserve to be challenged.
The first thing we have to do is make that intellectual leap and accept the fact that often there are arbitrary values which underline the institutions of society and which deserve our scrutiny and questioning.
I think it is important for us to learn to listen and consult. Can we accept the fact, as I said, that in our society people live different realities? I would like to give examples for this with respect to women and their situation in the justice system because it has been a major preoccupation of mine. I have often started out my approach to women and the law by pointing out that the reality of life for women is very different in many respects than the reality of life for men. I think if we want to do justice for all people in society, we have to first of all listen to them describe their reality. We have to consult with people and let them define their problems for us. We must not always assume that we understand how they see their lives and how they see society.
I often think of the American sociologist, Jessie Bernard, who in the 1960s wrote a book called the The Real World of Marriage. She said that in a marriage there are really two marriages. There is the husband's marriage and the wife's marriage. She said that even within this intimate relationship there are two quite different realities. Very often in society we think we understand how everyone lives and yet very often we will find ourselves shocked by the description of how some people see and experience a society that we feel very familiar with.
When I did consultation on the question of the rape shield legislation after the Supreme Court of Canada struck down the old provision of the Criminal Code, I met with a variety of groups. I met with legal academics and I met with representatives of the bar. I also met with representatives of a broad range of women's groups. I think it is important to point out that, even as a woman, my own life experience does not encompass the entire experience of women in Canadian society. I am limited in my ability to understand every woman's experience. Therefore, just being a woman does not give me a complete background or a complete basis on which to
May 5, 1992

reflect the reality of Canadian women in legislation and policy.
This was very much underlined to me when I sat and listened to these women talk about their experiences with the question of sexual assault. A black woman from Toronto said to me: "If you were sexually assaulted and you go the police station, then because of your race, because of your class and because of your position in society you will be treated with respect. You will be listened to. The system will respond to your pain and will do justice for you. However it will not respond to me. I will not get the same kind of respect or service or comfort because my race is a barrier". That is a shocking and disturbing thing for me to hear but it is important to understand it. That is the reality for that woman and for many other women.
When we want to reach our goal of inclusive justice, after we have accepted the fact that we do not all live the same lives and there are arbitrary values that ought to perhaps be questioned, we do have to listen to people. We have to let them describe their reality and experience and not assume that we know what is going on.
In the two conferences I was speaking about, the Conference on Women, Law and the Administration of Justice in Vancouver, it was the first time that many of the participants there had all been at the same meeting. It was the first time that members of the judiciary had sat down with representatives of women's groups. It is a wonderful thing to be Minister of Justice because you can invite members of the judiciary and they will actually come to a conference. Many of the people there were people who had been very active in various areas of the law but they had never been together. For many of those judges it was the first time that they had sat face to face with people who have felt excluded from the protection of the justice system. They heard in their own words how they see the system working. It had a powerful effect.
Shortly after that conference I was in Quebec City and met with the chief judge of the Quebec Provincial Court at another kind of event. He was very excited about the meeting in Vancouver and said he had in fact already begun a program on gender bias in his court, so powerful
were the messages communicated. There was a variety of examples of this.
In Whitehorse, in our Conference on Aboriginal Justice, one of the ways in which we tried to bridge the cultural gap between those of us who came from what we might call "the mainstream" or non-aboriginal community and the 50 per cent of the participants who were aboriginal people was through the use of theatrical productions. This reached deep into the hearts of the people who were there and communicated viscerally the sense of pain, alienation, strangeness and exclusion experienced by aboriginal people in dealing with the broader society of this country and particularly with the justice system.
This question of listening and really hearing the message and allowing people to define their realities is vital. Then, of course, you have to invite people to participate. If you want to resolve problems you have to involve people in the participation. I found that when I invited people to participate in developing the outline of the rape shield legislation that because of their different perspectives and because of their experience and because of their focus on this issue, many excellent ideas came forward.
One of the things we have to do is lift from our own shoulders the burden of feeling that we have to have all the answers. None of us has all the answers. If we feel we have to have all the answers we will be crushed by that burden. If we understand, however, that those who seek the recourse of the parliamentary process, those who seek our assistance and help, have insight into what will help them. If we understand that there is an enormous amount of expertise, advice and considered opinion in society, then it makes our job easier and more enjoyable.
More importantly it gives those people faith in their right to be part of the political and democratic process. They will share support of what we do because they are part of it.
Finally, we have to translate what we have learned into new public policy and legislation such as the amendments to the Criminal Code dealing with sexual assault that I was able to bring forward with the support of so many in this House. That is the ultimate proof of the pudding. It is how we translate this new insight into new

May 5, 1992
ways of doing things, into new ways of thinking and into things like judicial education and the ways of educating our legal and justice personnel.
Similarly I think it is important to broaden that sense of participation as part of our policy response to bring people inside. One of the things we looked at in our Women and the Law conference in Vancouver was the women in the legal professions. There is no point in saying that we must appoint or name more women to the bench if women get educated in the law but are not able to stay in the profession as a result of pressures in society that push them out.
The same thing applies to aboriginal people and other minority people in Canada. If we want them to take their place in the system we have to make sure that the doors are open to those crucial ports of entry that make it possible for them to do so.
The kinds of appointments that we create as a government is also very important. Appointments, whether they are to the bench or to positions in society, send a message of the "mainstreamedness" of people or the inclusion of people in the mainstream.
The whole idea is to broaden the mainstream and to say that being a Canadian means to be all different sizes, shapes, colours, genders and predispositions, but that they are all equally Canadian. The proof of this is in the reflection of all of these people in the institutions of democratic society so that each Canadian can see himself or herself reflected. They can see someone like themselves and therefore they can have confidence that government can respond to them and the justice system can do justice for them.
My main focus on inclusive justice has been women and aboriginals. Those have been my main themes.
I am also concerned about visible minorities and I am very concerned about the situation in large cities where, as part of this problem, there has been a backlash against immigrants. This has contributed to a sense of unrest. I have been meeting, as I have mentioned in this House in Question Period, with the mayors of the large cities to work toward developing some strategies that would address some of those concerns and the situation which led to the very unfortunate events in Toronto. The sense of exclusion is very much part of that and I hope we can develop a process that will involve the same inclusive
process of listening and developing and understanding the issues on that particular area as well.
It is important to have previously excluded voices in the debate. Through an inclusive approach to justice I think we can reduce the fragmenting particulars that we see in interest groups by broadening the mainstream. People will no longer have to press their noses against the glass and feel that they are special pleaders but that they are an automatic, accepted and welcome part of the debate and discussion in democratic society.
Not only will inclusive justice strengthen democracy but I believe that inclusive justice represents itself the truest expression of the democratic ideal which is the equal dignity of all citizens and their equal protection under the law.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Rodney King. The image will be burned in the mind's eye of Americans, Canadians and the world community alike. We saw a man on the ground being beaten systematically and in a way that if you beat a dog that way you would have the SPCA after you.
The question that people asked themselves after the Rodney King verdict was: "Why did justice fail that man? What were the variables that made him different?" Similarly, we looked at Rodney King and said: "That could never happen in Canada because we are a more tolerant, more open and more empowered society".
