Barely 48 hours later there are incidents of violence in Toronto and the death of a young black man. Again, there is legitimate public outcry to shake up an all too complacent Canadian society that says that the Los Angeles problem is strictly that which occurs in the United States.
Clearly that legitimate protest escalated. Violence begetting violence is not justifiable but it is understandable. I think it has to serve as a clarion call, as a cry for help and as a warning bell to those of us smug Canadians who think that that could never happen here in this country.
We pride ourselves on being a tolerant society, open to all cultures and free of bigotry. We are appalled by the history of slavery in other countries. We are concerned by the rise of intolerance and racism in places like Europe and the United States. We are proud of our international reputation for the fight against apartheid.
May 5, 1992

All too often, we forget that Canada, too, has its own shameful history of racism, discrimination and intolerance. The Metis, Inuit and Indians were deprived of traditional lands, languages and cultures in an attempt to "civilize" them or assimilate them into a Christian and European-rooted majority.
Until recently, aboriginal peoples were confined to reserves if they wanted to retain their status and were denied the administration of their financial affairs. That was only put in the hands of the financial officer who was the white man on the reserve.
Registered Indians were not given the right to vote in federal elections in this country until 1960. Indian women on reserves still do not have the same rights as other Canadian women. A great step forward was made when, in 1971, a federal multiculturalism policy was announced. It was a policy that proclaimed the equality of all ethnic groups, respect for Canada's diverse cultures and support for cultural retention and enhancement.
It was a great step forward from a history going back to the 18th centuiy. In 1750, there were 4,000 black slaves in New France and their number increased along with that of the rest of the population, British and French, until abolition in 1833. That is something that young Canadians do not learn about in our history books.
Chinese men were brought into western Canada to provide cheap labour for railway construction but when the economy slumped all Chinese were refused entry into Canada. Does that sound familiar?
In an economic slump it is very easy to characterize last in as first out. Canadians of Japanese, German and Italian origin were stripped of their rights and sent to internment camps. Some Canadians were compelled to pay taxes but were denied the right to vote until 1947. Racial exclusion existed in the Immigration Act as late as 1967. It has only been in the last 25 years that race was no longer grounds for exclusion from this countiy.
We have seen the attack now on the notion of two official languages for this country. Let us go back to the history of bilingualism and what it meant to us.

In the sixties, when francophones in Canada were a minority from every point of view including employment, lack of power and a general feeling of being ignored, a number of specific policies were introduced at the national level to create a system that would give the francophones of this country access to power. It is true that francophones have advanced by leaps and bounds. Unfortunately black people and women in Canada are now in the same situation francophones were facing 25 years ago. We are under-represented in the House of Commons. There is also a lack of access to power despite all the high-sounding statements we hear on all sides.
When we want strategies specifically for women or black people, there are people who want to prevent that, just as there were people who wanted to keep francophones out in the seventies.

We have pushed ahead. In 1960 the Canadian Bill of Rights under John Diefenbaker legislated against racial discrimination. I mentioned earlier the federal multicultural policy which is under attack now by people who say it has nothing to do with race, it has nothing to do with immigration. It has everything to do with race and everything to do with immigration.
We moved ahead with the race relations unit in 1972. In 1982 the Charter of Rights and Freedoms prohibited racial discrimination and permitted compensatory programs.
We see as we speak that the very program to allow minorities access to the courts by way of the Court Challenges Program is under attack. It is under attack because there is an agenda in this country which is not that different from the agenda that put names like Jean-Marie Le Pen and David Duke on the map. That agenda would say that the only way we can make Canada whole again is by going back to the economic power structures of the fifties and the demographic make-up of our country in the 1950s.
In fact the challenge that faces this Parliament and the challenge that faces the people of Canada is making sure that every valuable resource, every valuable human dividend, be paid by every person in this society, whether

May 5, 1992
they be black, white, men, women, and whatever their sexual orientation.
We must stamp out the systemic racism we saw exhibited in the Rodney King case. Unfortunately systemic racism that says that if you are a black person in this country, all other factors being equal, you can expect to earn 30 cents on the dollar less than a white man. Or if you are a woman, you can expect to earn 34 cents less than a white man, factoring out all other issues. It is the same systemic discrimination in this House of Parliament. Looking around the room one sees faces that are not very representative of the reality of Canada in 1992.
Five years ago, the Employment Equity Act was introduced federally to try and redress some of the imbalance that exists at the employment level.
The Canadian Human Rights Commission in its most recent report outlined the fact that unfortunately the federal government is the worst offender when it comes to application of employment equity where it counts. That is in the pay cheques of working people across this country.
Visible minorities make up 6.3 per cent of the population but they represent only 3.5 employees in federal departments and agencies. Moving to senior levels it is even smaller, 2.1 per cent. Over all the private sector is doing better with 7 per cent but employment equity must be pursued and strengthened.
Looking at the recommendations of the Advisory Group on Race Relations established in Halifax following last summer's incidents, it will be known that the key to changing attitudes is education and communication in the workplace, in the media, in Parliament. It particularly stressed the crucial issue of police and visible minority relations.
It is necessary that initiatives be taken. It is not just a police issue, but the police are the most visible example of authority of empowerment that people see on a daily basis. We need intercultural training. We need recruitment and selection and there are strategies being developed.
In my own community of Hamilton we have had a race relations committee for several years. In fact it has been crucial in working with the Hamilton-Wentworth police to ensure an increase in the representation of women and minorities, not only in the typing pool but also out working in the community.
Because women and minorities tend to be last in, they can also be first out in a hiring freeze. They have developed specific strategies to ensure that even when budget crunch time comes that the increase in hiring of women and minority constables will proceed. Last year, among 42 constables hired in the city of Hamilton, the majority-17 women, 8 visible minorities-came from the non-traditional community. That is the way to deal with the problem.
It is not just an issue relating to the police, it relates to this place. The Lortie commission gave us a number of very specific examples of how we could move forward to make the political process more open and more accessible.
You heard the member for Windsor-St. Clair say how surprised he was to be in this place. Well, it is important, not only for the member for Windsor-St. Clair but also for all young Canadians that we have men, we have women, we have role models across the board to ensure that greater and greater penetration of the political process will be achieved by those who are sitting right now on the outside.
Obviously, it goes through the whole system. It was interesting. When Ben Johnson won a gold medal we all watched him and we were proud of him as a proud Canadian. When he ran into problems, he became that young guy from Jamaica.
It is critical that in addressing strategies we break open the barriers that prevent young black women and young black men from considering a career in politics. There is the glass ceiling.
I spoke recently to the Malton Black Development Association and it was formed more than 15 years ago with the objective of keeping young people in the school system. Do you know what the association told us? They shared a phenomenon that is quite apparent also among young women. Young black students in Malton and young white students in the elementary school proceed on a fairly even, equal keel. As soon as they hit adolescence, in the same way as girls, the educational performance starts to drop so you see the same phenomenon of the glass ceiling facing young blacks.
Fifty per cent of the population in Toronto jails is black. Are they more criminal? Are they somehow a greater danger to society or do we pursue, imprison and react to them in a different way? How often do you read in the paper "White man kills his wife"? You read "Man

kills wife", unless it happens to be a person of colour in which case it is "Black man kills wife".
The stereotypes that we face as women, the glass ceiling that young adolescent girls feel when their self-esteem starts to go down and their capacity to dream starts to die are the same road-blocks that provoke the very violent reaction to the Rodney King judgment. Also, there is the fact that unfortunately, like it or not, we are living in a climate in this country where racism and sexism and all of the isms that affect our neighbours to the south are becoming a part of our society.
It would be very easy to treat this as an incident with no social message in the same way that some people said the Marc Lepine massacre had nothing to do with women.

I think it would be a mistake not to worry about what happened in Toronto. What happened in Toronto and Los Angeles is a clear message to Canada. Our country has a chance to prosper with so many different cultures. We must not be afraid to go ahead with this diversity. We are a young country, and we are building our own identity at this very moment.

Let us not be afraid of our differences. Let us understand that to make our country great we do not have to go back to the days when power was the exclusive domain of white Anglo-Saxon men. That cut out a whole generation of women and a whole generation of minorities who have something positive to share and contribute to the process. We do not want to cut anybody out, but this is about empowering people and this is about saying that there are a whole lot of human resources out there that are being wasted.
The sooner we recognize that this is not an isolated incident, that this is a systemic problem which requires a systemic response, the sooner we will be in a position to take advantage of the many talents and the different cultural domains that can make this country a great place.

I talked a lot about despair, but I think that with what happened in Toronto we have started a process that will
enrich a country that needs manpower at all levels. We must work together and be prepared to celebrate our differences together.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to update members of the House on my response to the situation in Toronto.
Members of my staff and I have been in constant contact with leaders of the black community and with the mayor's office which has been keeping me well advised as events have unfolded in Toronto. In my discussion with these people I have made it clear that my office is available to use our various programs in any way that may assist in this situation.
Yes, there are very serious problems. These are real problems. It is equally clear that what would be most helpful is a concerted, co-operative effort with all three levels of government. I will be holding discussions with my counterparts in the provincial and municipal governments of Ontario, as well as with the mayor of Toronto, June Rowlands, to determine the best way to proceed at this time.
As a member of cabinet I have been actively involved in race relations issues. I have been working on these issues virtually every day for the past four years. During this time I have attempted to bring race relations issues and specifically the problem of racism within society to the forefront.
I have worked to build a new Department of Multiculturalism and Citizenship that has redirected resources away from empty ceremonies toward a practical race relations mandate. As a government we have developed new programs and initiatives to bring about real social change.
In so doing I have built a relationship of trust with Canada's cultural communities. Together we have forged many exciting partnerships. Together we have made progress. Yet together we still have much more to achieve.
The decaying influence of racism does exist within too many of our institutions throughout Canadian society. I have seen a willingness to learn, to understand, and to be a part of the process of change. We have seen this

May 5, 1992
willingness in Halifax, in Montreal, and now as the ministry of equality and participation we are ready to move very assertively in Toronto.
As all hon. members of this House and the vast majority of Canadians, I have only regret and sorrow for the events which have occurred in Toronto over the past several days. I have equal sorrow for the death of a young man last Saturday night. Whatever the circumstances of that death, and as we speak here tonight they are still not fully known, we can surely regret that any life be lost through violence in our communities.
The incidents themselves have raised many questions, many of them legitimate and well founded, and it is right we debate them tonight. The incidents have also raised comparisons between Canadian cities and those in the United States, between Canadian attitudes and approaches to minorities and attitudes and approaches to minorities in the United States.

I want to state firmly and categorically, Mr. Speaker, that Toronto is not Los Angeles. When it comes to racism and racial discrimination or the way the federal government reacts to such problems, Canada is not the United States.

Yes, there is racial discrimination in Canada. It occurs in housing. It occurs in employment. It occurs in education. It occurs in our justice system. It occurs in many sectors of our society, government included. Yes, sir, I am sad to say there are Canadians who promote racist doctrines and racial hatred as there are Canadians who seek to benefit from such doctrines for their own advantage.
Does that mean that Canada itself is a racist society, a society irrevocably committed to preventing its ethnic and cultural minorities from access to and integration into the mainstream, from participating in the life of this society as full and equal citizens? The answer to that question is a resounding no.
When this government came into office seven and a half years ago, it did so with a very clear vision of Canadian society, of both the challenges and the opportunities posed by Canada's increasing diversity, and of
the fact within Canadian history there have been traditions of racial discrimination toward aboriginal Canadians, Canadians of Japanese and other Asian origins, black Canadians, Jewish Canadians, and others.

Our objective was and remains to ensure that Canada continues to grow and prosper for the greater benefit of all its citizens. Nevertheless the search for this prosperity demands more than economic measures. It requires eliminating the obstacles that can prevent equal opportunity and even keep some people from participating in society. It demands increased sensitivity and better understanding of the nature of cultural and ethnic differences. If these differences are not to be considered a threat or a source of division in our society, vigorous initiatives to help minorities integrate into our society are required.

In 1986 the Prime Minister proclaimed in the House of Commons Canada's participation in the United Nations second decade to combat racism and racial discrimination. In 1988 federal, provincial and territorial ministers agreed to commemorate the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in all Canadian jurisdictions. In 1989 the federal government launched its first national campaign against racism.
Today the March 21 anti-racism campaign, as members of this House know, has become the largest anti-racism initiative of its kind anywhere in the world, in any society. It has contributed to a deep and growing awareness among Canadians of not only the dangers of racism in our society but of the responsibilities of all citizens of goodwill to fight and eliminate it from our society. When literally hundreds of thousands of Canadians give up their time, energy and money to participate all across Canada in such a campaign, I say no, this is not a racist country.
I have given the particular example of the excellent partnership that has developed with the Canadian Association of Broadcasters that last March 21 contributed over $10 million of free advertising to help us in our understanding of what we are and what we become as a wonderful sharing and caring community.
May 5, 1992

I was at the launch of a New Year's program that is encouraging us now to talk, to get to know each other even better. It was clear in what we had been able to learn through this past year that attitudes have improved, that we have made progress, and that we are more comfortable with each other. Notwithstanding the fact that we still have to know more about each other, we still must more effectively communicate how we all can participate more fully in society. That is one example of what has been done and what we will continue to do.
Canada, as I said, is not a racist society in the way it has embraced the challenge of facing up to the need to examine and change our institutions, to look hard and carefully for discrimination, and to learn to serve an increasingly diverse community. Today in and across Canada the federal government is working in partnership with literally dozens of sectors of our economy and society to eliminate institutional barriers and to increase the participation of minorities.
Those partners include the Canadian Labour Congress, the Canadian Association of Broadcasters, the Federation of Canadian Municipalities, the Canadian Association of University Presidents, and the Canadian Association of Chiefs of Police. I could go on and on because I have now had a four-year experience in helping build these various partnerships.
I can tell hon. members of this House that our programs are making a difference.

Throughout Canada today, more and more municipalities are using models and training techniques that we developed in co-operation with the Federation of Canadian Municipalities to improve services to members of minorities. A growing number of mayors have created advisory boards on race relations to study and monitor hiring and recruiting practices.
We just recently, on March 21, had the pleasure of announcing a very important initiative with the mayor of the city of Montreal, Jean Dore, and with the provincial minister, Madam Gagnon Tremblay, where the three levels of government have agreed to co-operate, to collaborate and co-operate to bring forward a concerted
effort so that 1993 will be truly a year of cross-cultural understanding.
These initiatives have been going on unabated right across the country.

More and more communities are reaching out to minority organizations and associations to encourage them to take part in civic and community activities.

Today, from initial research projects sponsored by the federal government, universities across Canada are confronting racism on campus, and not just the actions of bigoted students who have attracted headlines in the newspapers. They are looking at issues of minority representation, at curriculum and at other areas identified as impediments to the achievement of black and other minority students in post-secondary education.
Similar projects and initiatives are aimed at racism on the shop floor, at encouraging minority participation in the media and in social services, at increasing enrolment of minority students in law schools, at encouraging the development of minority owned businesses, and at improving the hiring and promotion ratios at all levels of government, not least at the federal level.
I would say to this House again that those initiatives are making a difference, not a superficial difference, not a cosmetic difference that is here today and gone tomorrow, but a fundamental difference, one that is going to keep on going in the years ahead.
Nowhere will that difference be more felt than in the institution at the centre of the events in Toronto. The role of the police in our society is pivotal. As I have said on many occasions, the very ability of this or any other free society to police itself depends on a relationship of trust and respect between those to whom we have given the power and authority to enforce the law.
Without that relationship, either the policing does not work or the freedom is diminished. It is as clear and as critical as that. We cannot have two standards of justice, two codes of conduct or two levels of trust. That is why one of my first actions on being appointed minister of multiculturalism four years ago was to undertake a major consultation to develop a national strategy on police race relations in Canada.

As a result of those consultations, a national action plan was agreed to and endorsed by the provinces and territories, by leaders of policing services, and by aboriginal and visible minority communities.
Less than two weeks ago, right here in Ottawa, we officially inaugurated a central part of that plan, a national police race relations centre, most of the funding for which will come from my own department and that of the Solicitor General.
The national centre is already making an impact in helping police departments and services across Canada to train their police officers to the needs of a multicultural society as other aspects of the national action plan are also making an impact.
I do not question that we have much more to do and much further to go, but the fact is the essential elements are already in place and they are working. The commitment of many police services and police commissioners has been outstanding. Initiatives in community policing, minority recruitment, and close police minority community liaison are proving the actions we began taking years ago are starting to produce dividends.
They are producing dividends, because this government has responded to the challenges of racism and discrimination in our society by facing the issues directly and openly as no other Canadian government in our history.
The programs I have outlined this evening are working, not because we went to the CLC and the CACP and the universities, but because we went to the CLC and minority communities themselves, because we went to the Canadian Association of Chiefs of Police and Ha-rambe, the Committee for Racial Justice in Vancouver, the Cultural Awareness Youth Group in Halifax, and CRARR in Montreal. When there were troubles in Halifax last summer we sat down with the city, with the province and with the black community in Halifax to answer not only the immediate problems but the years of discrimination and institutional indifference behind them.
I have seen it suggested that I should be holding high profile meetings with this or that community in the light of the events in Toronto. I am not against such a move, but the fact is that I am meeting every week with
representatives of minority communities and organizations on the same issues at hand here, and not only from Toronto, but right across Canada. We are in constant contact. I would invite my colleagues in the House to review my department's annual report to see the full scope of our collaboration and partnership.
I might also add that the whole purpose of my multicultural advisory committee being constituted as it is and not solely as a duplication of ethnocultural organizations is to give me a body of expert opinion in those areas vital to the objectives of institutional change-educators, media executives, police officers and business people. That is the approach of this government, to realize real change, lasting change, change that will open the doors to equality of opportunity and participation and keep them open.
As I said at the beginning of my statement, this government regrets as much as any of the events in Toronto over the last several days, and they only confirm how much more we have yet to achieve. Those events cannot and must not be allowed to overshadow the progress and the goodwill that has been achieved at many levels in our society; progress, I might add, that is reflected in many of the official appointments made by this government, such as Lieutenant Governors Lincoln Alexander and David Lam, Public Service Commissioner Gilbert Scott, Advisory Council president on the Status of Women Dr. Glenda Simms, deputy chairs of the Immigration Refugee Board Nuijehan Mawani and Emer Robles and many more.
Our challenge, however, is to build on these foundations so that one day no minister or member of this House will have to remark on a person's origin or community.
When the right of every Canadian to participate and to be included in the life of our society can be taken for granted, perhaps we will have arrived at such a day.
Until then we will continue to work to remove the barriers of discrimination, to fight the purveyors of bigotiy and hatred and to build the partnerships with communities and institutions across our country and societies, which are the only true responses to what happened in Toronto.

May 5, 1992

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise with a sense of disappointment, a sense of apprehension and concern. What we witnessed last night in Toronto was something that should never have happened and should never happen again.
All of us in this House must strongly condemn the use of violence to advance any cause, no matter how just it may appear. There is no need for Canadians of any colour to take to the streets with baseball bats and bricks. In Canada we use the ballot box to vent our anger and frustration. It is completely legitimate for police to take direct action to restore peace and safety in the streets of our communities.
Canadians should never accept the use of force as a legitimate means of achieving a political goal. However, we as parliamentarians are responsible for looking at how such an event can occur in this country. We cannot turn our backs on the underlying problem of systemic discrimination. We cannot ignore the fact that our cities have been neglected by the Conservative government.
Canadians demand that this government take action now to ease the causes of racial tension. Canadians say that cities are in economic crisis. Our educational system needs to be revised, and unfortunately members of visible minority communities have been left on the sidelines. This government has to commit to a comprehensive action plan that will actively address the immediate economic and employment needs of visible minorities and all Canadians.

Racism hurts everyone, whatever their country of origin, and the costs are enormous. Our human dignity is diminished and our attitude as a people goes back towards anger instead of moving forward to harmony. It is unacceptable in a country as rich in human potential as Canada.
Our country is in a crisis, but that is not a reason for everything to break down. On the contrary, when times are tough we must stand together. Unfortunately the government seems to have forgotten that it too has a role to play as a leader working for the betterment of its
citizens and ensuring that the economy is moving forward for the greater good of all.

When we read the papers or listen to the news all we seem to hear is that jobs are disappearing, crime is on the rise, education is failing our youth and people are expressing their frustrations through all kinds of behaviour. One example is such as we witnessed last night. Instead of building these institutions that will be able to help Canada deal with a diverse society, this government is shirking its responsibility by delaying the establishment of the Race Relations Foundation indefinitely.
The government is breaking a commitment it entered into with the Japanese community; $12 million of the $24 million cost of the program was allocated as part of the redress for their internment during the World War II. I guess this government did not really learn from the past. Are they waiting for things to get better so the foundation can have a safe academic haven?
I thought the reason for creating the foundation was to cope with, learn from and hopefully prevent events such as the one we witnessed in Toronto last night.

At the root of such conflicts we regularly find the same problem: poverty which too often leads to lack of education and thus to inadequate work. It is a vicious circle that creates tensions which in a time of recession explode.

In Toronto 213,000 men and women are unemployed and nearly the same number are out of work in Montreal. There is no light at the end of the tunnel for many of these people. People without hope look for easy answers and scapegoats. This contributes directly to an increase in intolerance and racism.
What these people need are the same opportunities. Canadians, irrespective of their racial origin, need to have self respect. They need to have jobs so that they too can participate as equals in Canadian society. This government must wake up soon and start working on a national employment strategy or what we saw in Toronto could happen again in different cities in this country.

[Translation}
In Quebec, 19.9 per cent of young people, who are our future, are desperately looking for work. In Ontario, the figure is 18.8 per cent. That is unacceptable. It is high time for those who can help solve the problems to work together, from governments and business people to schools and cultural associations.

It is by working together with members of all communities that we will be better able to understand one another's needs. We must abandon the notion that it is the other person who has a problem with people of different racial backgrounds. We must all accept responsibility for our actions. We must all reach out to one another to help each other. Together we can eliminate, not only the type of behaviour that occurred last night but the very root causes of such violence. This is the result of anger this has brewed in our inner cities for many years. If we do not learn from the events of last week in Los Angeles and last night in Toronto, we are bound to repeat them.

How can a government that says it is concerned about the economic future of this country so easily cut funds for the education of tomorrow's leaders? How can this government, which tells us that it wants the economy to recover and wants everyone to be able to work and have a decent job, take the required funding away from the provinces? Of course it does not happen overnight but rather in a sneaky way, because the public must not be able to denounce the scandal. They must avoid offending those, if there are still any left, who believe in a better future.
Whatever detour the Conservative government takes, the new generation is already handicapped because of the government's indifference and lack of vision.

We must be addressing the needs of our inner cities. When the community turns sour, so do community relations. B'nai Briths 1991 audit of anti-Semitic incidents showed a fourth consecutive year of increase. Such blatant increase in intolerance is something that all of us have a responsibility to combat.
Unfortunately there will always be differences between those who have in our society and those who have not. In the case of Canadian cities, it is the poverty, poor health care and lack of education that are the great equalizers. That is why the rage we saw in our city streets was not only black. People of all racial backgrounds are tired of their dire economic straits and they are lashing out at a system that has let them be marginalized.
How does this government react? As one might expect by now. It has cut education, it has cut health care and it does virtually nothing in terms of urban job creation.
I share the sentiment that no party has the monopoly on virtue on this issue. We must collectively accept responsibility for building a society that has still not accepted all Canadians as equal and deserving members of this society.
Everyone agrees that education is the key. This country is in great need of a government that supports policies for human resource development, training and quality education.
We need to invest in the education of our youth. We must give the tools to all our young people so that they know at the end of the day all doors are open to them. No matter what their colour, no matter what their socioeconomic condition, they have to be able to excel and to become anything they wish to be.
This country certainly does not need this government, which does not see, or does not want to see the needs of young Canadians who have the desire, the energy and the determination to succeed in this country. They have to be given a chance to succeed here in Canada and to be proud to earn a good living from the profession or trade of their choice. They must not build their future on the uncertainties of the current government. This government must seriously think of investing in the long term in order to ensure this country's future labour force.
To do this, not only must we promote education, we must also remove the systemic barriers to participation that are prevalent throughout society. The federal government, for example, still has a great deal to do in terms of making the Public Service accessible to members of visible minority groups.

May 5, 1992

People of colour are also looking for true justice from Canada's legal system. We have a tiny fraction of visible minorities in positions of power in our justice system. So long as this community is not adequately represented at all levels, this justice system will not meet the needs of all Canadians. We need to build a system that is accessible, not only in a physical sense, but in a cultural one as well.

It is time for Canadians to demand that the government keep its promises. I admit that it can be difficult, but Canadians must not become the victims of the bad administrative decisions of the present government.
If we are going to get this country going, we must have the right priorities: a healthy, educated population that accepts racial and cultural diversity.

Many people in Canada are probably wondering why the events of last night occurred. Surely we have mechanisms in place that can help Canada adapt to a racially diverse society. We do but they are not enough. The Department of Multiculturalism is a noble objective, one that the official opposition strongly supports. However, we must question the priorities that this government has set for the policy. It is concerned with the rhetoric of equality while doing everything in its power to ensure that disparity reigns in this country. It cancelled the Court Challenges Program at the very time when visible minorities were finally starting to use this resource to gain the rights they deserve under our charter.
This government must understand that equality under the charter is nothing more than a pipe dream if various minorities do not have the resources to challenge unfair legislation before the courts.
Despite all of our problems, we must recognize that Canada is a fundamentally just society. We do have problems. There is racism in our country. However, we in Canada believe that there is room for all. We are a huge nation with more geography and not enough history, as the saying goes.
We must learn from the events of the past few days. We must understand that our justice system has to be
more responsive to the needs of all of our people. No one in this House says that all players in the justice system are racist, however there are those who are. We must be collectively conscious of this fact and work tirelessly to minimize its horrible effects.
I feel that it is perfectly within our grasp to never again see the type of statistics we have seen in terms of deaths of black men and women.
I want to assure this House that I personally will support any endeavour which will protect the rights of ethnocultural and racial minorities. I believe that expanding the multicultural clause of the charter to include preservation and promotion of racial and ethnic equality is a point that must be looked at. I feel it is perfectly within our grasp that we include the preservation and promotion of racial and ethnic equality.

Yesterday's events in Toronto show us that Canada must not follow the American example of race relations. Canada must continue to build a system that treats everyone with dignity and respect. We must all work for a just and equitable society.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will be sharing the next 20 minutes with my colleague from Rosedale. We both represent constituencies in metropolitan Toronto and both want to say something tonight in this debate.
I would like to focus much more specifically on the situation last night in the city of Toronto. A lot has been said, and generally said very well this evening about the general policies in Canada, the historic evolution that we have made as a pluralistic society and the agenda that still awaits us.
I want to begin by really looking at what happened because the nature of a riot is a truly unusual thing to behold. It is something like an ugly festival of vengeance and revenge.
I think the first riot I ever saw was in my home town of Bracebridge on a Saturday night at a hockey game in the early 1950s. The rivalry between the Bracebridge Bears and the Sunridge Beavers was carried through by the fans and the citizens of both towns. The game disintegrated into fighting in the stands between all kinds of

otherwise respectable people. I remember my own dentist, a respected professional person in the town, down in the penalty box actually brawling with one of the hockey players. The only way it could be stopped was by playing the national anthem over and over again at full blast over the PA system to try and bring some solemnity into the arena.
I remember living in Montreal at the time of the police strike and seeing what almost amounted to the peeling away of that thin veneer of civilization that we sometimes pretend goes so deep, but in fact in the absence of policing in our cities we can see a very thin skin over instincts that otherwise are contained. I remember Dorchester Boulevard and Sherbrooke Street becoming racetracks and whether the lights at the intersections were red or green or amber, cars going by at great speeds. I can remember store windows being broken. I can remember looting. I was also there at the time of the dispute with the Murray Hill limousine service and the burning of the buses and the depot. I saw all of that as a young man in Montreal.
In Toronto in the 1970s I remember the visit by Mr. Kosygin of the former Soviet Union and the mounted police at the Science Centre and whether that constituted a charge by the police whether the police themselves rioted. I remember how Judge Vanini of Sault Ste. Marie conducted a judicial inquiry into that.
In all of this there is a very difficult role for the police authorities. The policing of society is something that, yes, professionally is entrusted to those who take the oath of office of a policeman or policewoman, wear the uniform and carry out those public duties. However beyond that, policing society is something that we all share.
Last night I was impressed that there were people on Yonge Street who were passing from the festive atmosphere. Sean O'Malley, The Globe and Mail reporter who found himself in the midst of the riot and actually being kicked and chased off the scene when he feared for his well-being and when he said that the crowd seemed almost festive until the attacks began.
In the article it is quoted not only about the breaking of the windows and the looting but also of others who were there who urged restraint, others who were there
who insisted that goods that had been stolen and looted from the stores be put back. Many of the young people who were there were working to contain the situation. Bystanders were working to contain the situation, this was something that showed that it was citizens as well as the police who were part of trying to contain what was erupting.
That is another point that must be stressed. There was a planned peaceful demonstration in the city of Toronto last night. What actually happened is that that peaceful demonstration was taken over by a hoodlum element.
The police chief of metro Toronto said: "The results last night came from actions by individuals who were criminally motivated".
In detail, some 100 stores were vandalized. In the case of several they will be boarded up for at least two weeks before they can begin business again. Some 37 police officers were injured. Some 32 people were arrested, mostly charged with breach of peace and assault.
Nobody deserved what happened in Toronto last night. The hidden costs of this riot have yet to be evaluated because they go beyond the cleaning up of broken glass, the restoring of stolen and looted inventory and the itemizing of dollar damage.
I was very impressed earlier this evening listening to the comments by one of the leaders of the black community in Toronto who said that you cannot take snap decisions in a situation like this. We need a lot of consultation.
The speeches by both the Minister of Justice this evening who spoke about inclusive justice and by our Minister of Citizenship and Multiculturalism who spoke about the continuing efforts he has made for four years to bridge the gaps and understand the differences and effect policy response are part of what must be continued.
The member for Windsor-St. Clair said, and I certainly agree with him, that what happened last night was certainly not an appropriate way of pursuing any objective. More important, it was not part of anybody's planned scenario to deal with the issues of legitimate concern.
May 5, 1992

I repeat that the peaceful demonstration was taken over partly by a mob psychology and certainly by some individuals as intent as one was quoted as saying: "Treat us like animals and we are going to act like animals". It was quite accurate to report tonight in the House of Commons, as several MPs did, that it was a mixed group and those who have been charged are of a variety of racial origins. That is why it is perhaps lamentable that the front page picture of the daily English language newspaper in the capital under this headline "Riot rocks Toronto, smash and grab" and everyone shown in the picture is a black youth. That was not representative of what was happening.
I again come back to the point made by the member for Windsor-St. Clair that we must always look at individuals, not at their colour, the racial background.
In 1985 when I chaired the committee on Equality for All we dealt with many of those equality issues. What was set out in that report was an agenda for a decade. Some parts of that are very much before us today.
In concluding, I would like to pick up on one final point that was mentioned tonight, again by the member from Windsor, when he said that the youths of the country need a vision, they need some sense of hope to deal with the alienation, the youth unemployment, the circumstances they find themselves in.
The member for Spadina tonight is calling for some immediate response. I would like to propose that Parliament and the government consider creating a Canadian youth service corps. I recall several years ago when the Katimavik program was cancelled, the minister of the day said that a replacement program would come in its wake.
The time has come to create for young Canadians a program that would operate for a year, voluntary service, where there would be different streams of training that could include, for example, the environmental stream, the social service stream, the reserve military training streams and various other streams.
This is a chance for young Canadians over the course of a year to join a Canadian youth service corps to find a new chance to work with other Canadians of their same
age from across the country to move around the country in the course of that program.
Sharing my time as I am with the member for Rose-dale, I cannot go on any longer to elaborate on the details of this but I will take early occasion to give more details as I have been working on this idea. I think it is one of many. There needs to be many responses to a situation like this. Properly seen, it can also be an opportunity to respond. I hope we will take that in a constructive fashion.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, along with members from all sides of the House, I share with every one of them both the shock and the sadness of the incidents of the last day. They are not out of context with what we have witnessed on a larger scale, as already has been referred to with respect to the events previously in Los Angeles.
It was interesting, if one looks back at last week, that from the time there was an immediate upheaval in Los Angeles, questions were immediately put to leading public people in this country: "Could this kind of incident take place here?" I think, as I believe our friend from Windsor said, naturally what happened last night was not what happened in Los Angeles, but it was certainly a very loud echo.
It was a loud echo from a number of points of view. It is a reminder to all of us that we do live in a single universe, a single world and in a sense in a single community. We know that we have been struggling for a good part of this century to recreate a view of ourselves that extends far beyond our own time. The issue of racism is one that I think is extremely profound for those of us who are alive today.
Some few years ago I had an opportunity to travel to Senegal. I was taken to a little island off the coast of Dakar called the Island of Gore, lies Gore, which was the staging point for African slaves for centuries that were sent off to the rest of the world. Carved in stone at one point in this slave prison there was a series of statements indicating when slavery had been abolished in various countries and the list was not yet completed.
We are not that far removed from a time when people of different race and colour were bought and sold. In fact, we know that under the auspices of the United Nations there is still an anti-slavery commission which is

attempting to end the last vestiges of human slavery on this planet.
I have held the belief for some time that one of the greatest problems in allowing the people of Africa, both those still there and those throughout the world, to achieve their full respect and dignity is to overcome the centuries of human degradation and exploitation.
I know it is a popular Canadian belief to think that we do not have much by way of discrimination or racial intolerance in this country. If we look very deeply we know that is not the case.
In my lifetime, we have actually changed laws federally, provincially, and municipally which have ended the objective kind of racial discrimination. However just changing laws does not change attitudes. It does not change the respect that one person or one group has for another, and perhaps more important, it does not allow for that fulfilment of self-worth which is so critical.
The thing that has struck me about race riots going back over the last 20 years and particularly during that period after the assassination of Martin Luther King was when one looks closely at the victims of race riots it is the very people who are involved in the protest themselves. There is a large amount of self-inflicted pain that cannot be ignored.
When I think of even some of the people who would be shopkeepers, some of the people in places in my constituency who are likely affected by the riot last night, I am sure that many of them were members of the non-white population of Toronto. Therefore there is a horrible irony in what we are examining here this evening.
I would hope that one of the virtues of this debate, this dialogue, this discussion is that we are able to enter into-and the word has already been called for by my colleague from Etobicoke, by the Minister of Justice, and others-a genuine consultation with both the leaders and the members of various non-white communities in Toronto and elsewhere.
There are some deep-seated grievances that have not yet been addressed. While none of us accepts for a moment criminal behaviour that affects innocent victims as we have seen in last night's riot, none of us either can accept the fact that as long as people are living in the
agony of such continuing discrimination and despair that it is acceptable in our society.
I thank the member for Trinity-Spadina who shares with me a good part of downtown Toronto, an area where all this occurred, and hope that by his presenting this matter to the House for debate this evening all of us are allowed the opportunity to recommit ourselves to ensuring there is that full, open and consistent consultation leading to the full acceptance of people of all races in all aspects of our society.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very humbled in participating in this emergency debate, but I would like to take a little different approach.
I would like to share with you what happened in my riding of Parkdale-High Park on Sunday, just blocks away from where the black person was shot by the policeman after pulling a knife on him.
I was invited to participate in the Parkdale focus community to mark the beginning of Drug Awareness Week. We should remind ourselves that this is the week we are marking. Four schools took part in Drug Awareness Week in this Parkdale focus community. There was the secondaiy school, Parkdale Collegiate, the principal being Sheila Hambleton; Parkdale Elementary School, whose principal is Jim Wilkinson; the Holy Family School, a separate school whose principal is Dr. Helen Bochna; and Queen Victoria School, an elementary school under the principalship of John Powell.
Under this program, which was funded provincially under Project 2000, schools were asked to make a mural of what they thought Parkdale society meant to them.
You heard me talk about the problems we have in Parkdale-High Park such as the drug problems, prostitution problems, street safety, et cetera. These elementary and secondary school students wanted to tell the world through art what Parkdale means to them.
Under the direction of a well-known artist, John Leonard, they put together huge murals. One mural is almost the size of the wall behind you, Mr. Speaker. These murals were then put up on a side wall in the Bi-Way Store. The local BIAs were involved and Bi-Way donated a huge wall for the students' art. Of course all levels of government were there, -federal, provincial,
May 5, 1992

metropolitan Toronto, city councillors, trustees and others, and we had the unveiling of these murals.
As the first mural was unveiled, a huge cheer went up from the crowd. In the crowd were Canadians of black origin, Filipino origin, West Indians, East Indians, Poles and Ukrainians. I asked Sheila Hambleton how many different ethnocultural groups she thought were in the Parkdale area.
She said that in her school alone 52 different language groups have been counted. Therefore, a representation of these 52 different ethnocultural groups went out in unison, cheering this huge mural painted by the students of Parkdale Collegiate.
Then they went to the mural of Holy Family and there was the same reaction. There was this unanimous response, cheering the mural of the Holy Family School. Then on to Queen Victoria School and Parkdale Public School.
I went home that night and I heard the news of what was happening on Yonge Street. I could not help but compare the behaviour of the people in my riding, blocks away from where this black person was shot and the behaviour of the people on Yonge Street. Why the difference? It is an important question that we will have to ask ourselves.
I was and still am very proud of the constituents of Parkdale-High Park for their behaviour in not only marking Drug Awareness week but also showing a community spirit.
After the unveiling we had a cake-cutting ceremony. We had hot dogs and T-shirts for the children. There was an extended family feeling there, a real community spirit. I thought: "It would be nice if we could have that community spirit in all of Toronto, in all of Ontario and all of Canada". If it can happen in Parkdale-High Park, it can happen nationally and internationally.
I think we have to end tonight's debate. We should look at the root causes of the violent demonstration on Yonge Street. In order to look at the root causes, I believe we have to analyze some hard facts.
For example, it is fact that in metropolitan Toronto 47.7 per cent of the population was born in a countiy other than Canada. The source is today's article in Toronto's The Globe and Mail.
That means many of those people have never set foot in school. Many of them do not speak either of the
official languages. Many of them do not have employment skills. What are we, as a society, as four levels of government doing to help these people?
In that group will be many visible minorities, many blacks. Are we doing our share to help these people assimilate into our society? It is fact that 34 per cent of Toronto's visible minorities are under 19 years old. These young Canadians are asking: Will there be a job for me when I finish school?
Sixty-eight per cent of Canadians think that problems with racism and prejudice will not solve themselves over time without government intervention. We know the attitude of the present government towards privatization.
I do not think you can privatize racism. I do not think you can eliminate racism by saying: "We will leave it to the private sector". Every work place, every institution and every organization must have a race relations program, but the federal government, the provincial government and municipal governments must set the example.
I was fortunate in working for the Toronto Board of Education for 28 years. It did have a very successful race relations program. If there should be any riots or violence, it should be in the inner schools in Toronto, but there are not. There are not, thanks to affirmative action programs by the Toronto school system. I invite others to have a look at what the Toronto Board of Education has been doing to fight racism.
According to statistics for 1986 it is fact that during that time, the economy in Toronto was booming but even in the booming economy the unemployment rate of visible minorities was approximately 3 to 4 per cent higher than the local average. One must ask why.
According to the statistics of the last census, the average income in Toronto for males was $27,200. For females, it was $15,200. This is taken from Statistics Canada, 1991. This discrepancy between the sexes is bad enough but looking at visible minorities, the average income for men was $20,900 and women, $13,700, from the same source.
For black males and females in Toronto, the statistics are even worse. Black males earn on an average only $19,100 and females, $13,500. A Canadian of black descent earns $8,100 less than the average white Canadian. No wonder there is resentment, mistrust and a tendency to start demonstrating on the streets of Toronto.

Looking at housing, on February 25, 1992 the federal government cut our federally funded co-op housing program. With all the economic factors weighing against visible minorities, access to affordable housing such as this is denied.
In addition, this year the government will be cutting 22 per cent of all social housing and by 1993, the government will make a further cut of 29 per cent. In other words, nearly half the funding for social housing programs will be cut over the next two years. This was well documented in The Globe and Mail in February of this year.
I happened to watch Pamela Wallin interview Wilson Head of the Urban Alliance on Race Relations this morning. Mr. Head said that there is a lot of anger in secondary school students. He went as far as to say that they want to carry rifles. They are asking themselves: "Why should I stay in school? When I get out will there be a job waiting for me?"
I do not share that view with Mr. Head. I do not think our students are at the point that they want to carry rifles. I think that is the difference between American cities and Canadian cities. I have statistics on university graduates, and this is quite shocking. Thirteen per cent of all adults in Canada, or in Toronto here, hold university degrees, but 16 per cent of people in the visible minority group aged 15 and over hold university degrees. Now this sounds like the reverse of what is expected. But if you look at the black population, six per cent hold university degrees as opposed to 16 per cent of the visible minorities. If Canadians of Chinese descent, Pakistani descent, etcetera can go on to higher education, surely we can set the environment to allow the blacks to achieve the same level of education.
Let us look at the visible minorities and the blacks in the police forces. According to this morning's Globe and Mail Clayton Ruby states that "the Toronto Police Force committed itself to change its racial composition to include more minorities, but (because) of a hiring freeze nothing has happened". So it is no good just to say we want to hire more visible minorities if the budget is not
there to follow up. Words are useless unless actions follow.
Lower education for visible minorities and especially for blacks means poorer jobs, poorer incomes, over-representation on the welfare rolls, drug addiction, more arrests and more convictions. I think we have to look at where the blacks are in society, and maybe we will start understanding why there is such anger out there among the blacks in Toronto, Halifax, Montreal and other cities.
I would just like to close by saying that no society is immune from misunderstanding, intolerance, mistrust of religious, ethnocultural or racial minorities. In tonight's debate I hope we will set an example by changing our attitudes, if need be, so that all 27 million Canadians will be more tolerant of each other, more understanding of each other and more trusting of each other. If we can reach that point, we will have demonstrations because our Charter of Rights and Freedoms allows them, but those demonstrations must be peaceful. They must show respect for authority and for other people so no one is hurt in the demonstrations. Those demonstrations must show respect for property so there is no property damage as we saw on Yonge Street.
A business person from my own riding called me just before this debate. He broke out crying because he could not accept what he saw happening on Yonge Street. His business is on Bloor Street and he said that could have been his business. That is not Canada. That is not the way Canadians behave. And so he pleaded, through me to all Canadians, to show that respect for authority, to show that respect for property, to show this respect for others. If we do I think we will eliminate the kinds of demonstrations we saw last night on Yonge Street.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
What happened last night in Toronto was not a race riot. It was hooliganism. This is not the first time Toronto has had such riots. There have been riots at the CNE and previously on Yonge Street, and the Eaton Centre has become a regular target. Store owners must lock up their products and are on the watch for mobs of young people who think it is fun to rip off goods or people. I can remember when Yonge Street used to be a fun place to walk at night. It is not any more and it has not been for
May 5, 1992

quite awhile. It is a place where thugs, prostitutes and violent youth congregate. It is a time bomb.
The black community in Toronto is hurting badly because of the Rodney King affair and the succession of shootings of young black men over the past three years, but the community is not a violent one. I firmly believe that what happened last night was a peaceful democratic community demonstration by people who have substantial faith in the system and are working to improve it. However, it was hijacked by fringe groups and hooligans, some who came with the intent of discrediting the black community. They came equipped with Molotov cocktails, baseball bats, guns and knives. They saw what happened in Los Angeles and thought they could get away with it in Toronto.
Fortunately the police were prepared; not for this scale of incident but certainly the mounted police were brought in very quickly. Of course everybody was greatly in fear that something similar to what occurred in L.A. might happen.
The reasons for the initial demonstration are very valid. I do not know whether the particular killing was preventable, that will be decided, but I do know that the number of killings of young black men in Toronto indicates that there are very serious problems not only with police but also with young black men. There are also very serious race relations problems in general requiring considerable leadership and effort to address.
The problems facing its youth are something of which the community is very much aware. I know many people who are working in many programs to address those problems. There can be little doubt that this is one of the highest risk communities in Canada, along with aboriginal youth.
The community talks of the plague of drug abuse that is attacking and decimating its youth. While those who become criminal are a minority, there can be little doubt that the community is over-represented in the criminal population. It is also over-represented on the unemployment rolls and the poverty statistics and suffers wage discrimination. These points have already been made.
A greater effort to save these young people, a significant group of whom are obviously engaging in self-destructive behaviour comparable to many aboriginal people, must be made. There is no doubt that police
education and education of different people in contact with them in the community-teachers, service providers and the community in general-is greatly needed but I also know that there have been tremendous efforts made in the past.
There are programs in the metro police department that have been in place for a long time. There are race relations task forces. The task force in North York, the mayor's task force on race relations, was the first to get started. Many agencies have been providing programs for a long time.
It is the same with the boards of education. The member for Parkdale-High Park has already spoken about the programs of the Toronto Board of Education. All the boards have programs and all of them are trying.
I participated in some of the North York programs, the Chimo programs in which many different groups were represented, spoke and had opportunities to discuss these issues.
A lot is being done, but clearly more has to be done. It is a monumental job that has to begin very early. A lot must be done to improve educational and job opportunities for visible minorities and other disadvantaged groups, that too is a time bomb. Person after person comes to my constituency office to tell me about how they feel they have been discriminated against.
Very frequently the Chinese, and there are an awful lot of Chinese people in my particular area, are not discriminated against in the initial employment but they simply do not rise into managerial positions. Very frequently they feel that in spite of very excellent qualifications they simply run into this glass ceiling.
I think of African heritage language programs. I participated in a multifest on the weekend at which 3,000 students participate in the heritage language programs and the Woodbine Vanier program. There is an African heritage program there. It is a program in which people are being taught about their own history and in which they are being taught to value themselves. I think that is so important with youth. They need to know themselves well and to know their own history. They also need to have others know about them. Clearly many of the programs or units that are being taught about African heritage are being transferred into regular school programs. Consider more of that kind of thing where people

May 5, 1992
learn to value each other and help them integrate and appreciate others.
Child development initiatives such as those identified in the report on poverty that include strong community participation and self-help initiatives are also very important. We now have half a billion dollars.
I hope that a substantial amount of that will go to combat some of these problems that the young are facing and in particular, this group that is clearly not doing very well at all.
I think that in Toronto, unlike other parts of the world and perhaps much more so than in the United States, there is a willingness and a desire by the general community to do something about these problems.
There was a survey done by metro council which indicated that 90 per cent of Toronto residents would rather be known as a city where there was no poverty or homelessness rather than a world-class city. I think if you surveyed them on racism they would also say that.
I think that most Canadians want to have communities where all people are equal and where all people have equal opportunities to thrive, develop and share in the benefits of Canada.
I urge the black community and the rest of the community in metropolitan Toronto to seize some of the opportunities that will be coming forward in the child development initiatives can work on what is obviously a very serious problem.
I also urge the government to go ahead at this particular time with the Race Relations Foundation that has been approved by this Parliament and is ready for implementation. It was deferred in the budget but I think it is a venture important enough to be brought forward now at this time in light of the particular crisis we find ourselves in.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have an opportunity to participate in this debate tonight.
Last night it was disturbing to turn on the television like so many Canadians in Scarborough, metro Toronto
and all across the countiy, to witness the events that took place in downtown Toronto.
These were scenes that we all felt really could not happen in Canada. We would all like to believe that Canada is a land of compassion and a land of tolerance. Yet, I think of the disbelief and the sadness and the despair that ran through everyone's hearts and minds after seeing those horrible television pictures.
Like most Canadians I believe metropolitan Toronto residents felt both grief and despair when they realized that some individuals right in the heart of Toronto, the largest city in Canada, felt obligated to express their viewpoints, not through debate and peaceful protest, but rather through violence.
We cannot condone this violence. Violence can neither be a response nor a solution to a problem and the destruction of private property cannot be tolerated under any circumstances. We must support the police in their restrained efforts to maintain law and order.
Yet we must all continue to make an effort to make sure that Canada remains a countiy where tolerance and compassion, equality of opportunity remain just not an ideal for a few but for all; a rule rather than an exception.
For example, young people in Canada have access to an open system of education. It is available to all. This system strives to encourage all young people to be then-best. This builds upon the numerous success stories we are all aware of. We can think of examples where people came to this countiy with nothing and managed to create through hard work, diligence, effort and help from their families, successful businesses or services, and in so doing they not only made a living for themselves and their families, but also contributed to the building of our magnificent country as a whole.
For people who need society's assistance we have instituted programs that have targeted assistance for those who need it the most. We all know there is always the need to do more.
No one can deny that the future of Canada rests with the education of our children. The future of our community depends on how well our fellow citizens understand, appreciate and accept each other. As a former teacher in
May 5, 1992

Scarborough, it is clear to me that we need to continue to make sure that the children of Canada in our schools have a broad understanding of human relations while attaining the skills that they need for the future.
Let me give an example. Just a couple of days ago I visited the John Diefenbaker School in Scarborough. It was most representative of the diversity of metro Toronto. Children were there whose parents came from all over the country, all over the world and the fact that the enthusiasm that was instilled in these children by their teachers who themselves represented the diverse, rich and varied population of Canada needs to be replicated and followed by other institutions and by the adult population of our country.
The federal government has responded with a program of action in the areas of race relations and the promotion of equality and tolerance. For example, our government announced a national action for police minority relations. Representatives of governments, police and visible minorities are participating and the resulting special Centre for Police and Race Relations which opened just last week here in Ottawa is an important and indeed timely step in helping police improve their relations with native Canadians and visible minorities.
In fact, the executive director of this centre is Mr. Barry Thomas. He is from Scarborough and deserves to be commended for the work he is doing and the extensive experience that he brings to this project. He previously served as the executive director of Tropicana Community Services, an organization in Scarborough that assists with programs in the black community and especially the youth of the black community.
Barry Thomas spoke about the centre's three broad goals. First is to establish the bias-free standards for selection and recruitment of members of the police forces. The second is to provide training and new training initiatives. The third and most important is community outreach and community programs which bridge the gap between members of the police force and all communities. They bridge that gap between ignorance and awareness. Public education is undoubtedly the key component in solving these problems.
As well, a number of initiatives have been undertaken over the years to help further the goals of tolerance,
equality, opportunity and full participation. To reward the partnerships in community race relations, the government established the Excellence in Race Relations Award. These annual awards honour individuals and organizations whose efforts help in our efforts to pursue greater sensitivity and understanding equality among Canada's diverse society.
As well, I commend the work of the Toronto Urban Alliance on Race Relations. The federal government has supported this organization which is working to promote equality for visible minorities in Toronto. The new Broadcasting Act, passed in the beginning of 1991, makes sure that the Canadian broadcasting system serves the needs of all members of our society.
Too often we take for granted the privilege of living in our magnificent country of Canada. All Canadians must understand that each and every one of us pays the cost of racism, economically, emotionally or both. By not using the diverse skills and talents of Canadians of all origins, we lose important human resources and creative potential. We should never forget that through the build up of tensions and hostility in our communities, Canadians lose their solidarity as a people.
We all need to continue to speak to each other. Whether it is at our kitchen tables, in our churches, in our synagogues, in our mosques with our families and with our friends. Understanding is required to foster unity between the many different groups of people that make up Canada and especially the large cities such as metro Toronto.
Aggressive changes and appropriate responses to combat the systemic intolerance in our institutions will enable us to continue to strive for harmony and dignity for all Canadian citizens.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am grateful to the members of this House for agreeing to hold this debate on the causes of last night's riot in Toronto and possible remedies.
It is properly called a riot even though there was a difference between those who planned a peaceful demonstration and those who engaged in the acts of violence against property or against people. They are part of a much larger situation which we could describe as racial tension. I am grateful to the members who have given

May 5, 1992
5. 0. 52
specific suggestions which I hope will be heard around the country.
For example, the member for Windsor-St. Clair, the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore, the member for Vancouver East who will be speaking later on this matter, the member for Parkdale-High Park and the member for Don Valley North made very specific comments.
In my 10 minutes, and I will be followed by the member for Vancouver East, I would like to dig a little bit deeper into what I think are the underlying causes of the tension.
The question is whether we hear what the demonstrators and the rioters are saying because they are not two different species of creatures. They are both human beings and they both, in different ways and perhaps from different stations in society and different states of concern or discouragement, are sending some kind of message. We have to try and hear it.
One story that was phoned to me today by one of the organizers of the demonstration who heard and observed what was happening on Yonge Street said that a young black man was trying to persuade a young white man that seemed to come from the suburbs to stop trying to kick a window in. He told him not to break the window because he would be blamed for it.
Of course as we have heard that other people tried peacefully to restrain the violence. I was also told by the same person who observed, that in his opinion it could have been worse than it was if it were not for the growing amount of mixed housing in Toronto in the housing co-operatives where people are very deliberately treated as equals and an atmosphere of trust grows in the community.
The situation could also have been better. Perhaps it could even have been avoided if $100 million had not been cut out of the training allowances this year and another $100 million last year from the Canadian Jobs Strategy, which has cut many young people off from the possibility of advancing themselves by training.
The basic reality underlying both the demonstration and the violence, what I would call the riot, was poverty: poverty among whites and poverty among blacks.
I agree with the member for Windsor-St. Clair that if we allow the U.S.-style economy of every man for himself and devil take the hindmost, then we allow impoverishment and demoralization of a growing part of our population which breeds desperate violence. I see racism as very often and in this case the trigger to violence.
I want to ask why. Why is racism so often the trigger and indeed why does racism exist? I do not believe it is inborn into human beings to dislike somebody who looks different. It is not natural. I see children playing without such discrimination until they learn bad habits from their elders and betters.
In Canada, as well as the United States and Europe, we are changing the immigration rules currently and I think changing in a rather dangerous way. We are reducing the rate of acceptance of refugees while the number of refugees in the world is growing, being produced often by the governments of our trading partners.
We are reducing family reunification as a share of immigration. What that amounts to, however unintentionally, is reducing the acceptance of persons of colour as immigrants to Canada. This helps to remind Canada's visible minorities and our first nations that they belong ethnically to the oppressed majority of the world's peoples. In other words, it is part of racism in the world.
I think the source of that racism is not completely mysterious. It has a great deal to do with five centuries of white empire, empire run by the people of Europe, violent conquest of the other continents, massacres, looting of the wealth, and enslavement of the people who were not massacred and the violent continuing oppression even in the present years as in Central America and in the Persian Gulf.
There is a UN report on development which points out that the richest fifth of the world's population has 82.7 per cent of the world's goods and services to enjoy, 81 per cent of the world's trade, 94 per cent of commercial lending, 80 per cent of domestic savings, 80 per cent of domestic investment, and of course it means a miserable fraction is left for the four-fifths of the world's population to starve on.
In other words, the people of my race and my origin in the British Isles are causing a great deal of misery in the world by our use of those people for our wealth.
May 5, 1992
