Another way of describing it is that about $50 billion, give or take a few billion, comes every year net from south to north in our world to the northern countries in the debts that we claim they owe us after we have taken their gold, silver, timber, crops, and their slave labour. We write the accounts in such a way that they owe us about $1 trillion and we take net revenue from them after all the aid and all the investment that goes to their countries. They pay us about $50 billion and their children starve or grow up malnourished if they grow up at all, as a result of the debt we have laid on them.
In the last four decades most of the world's wars have been fought in the south: Asia, Africa, South America. Millions of people have been killed with weapons sent to them by the white countries. Those people are the world's majority whom we exploit. Those are the ones now recognized by the visible minorities and the first nations of Canada as their kin; kin not only in an ethnic sense but in the sense of being treated as oppressed people by the white races of the world. My point is that we must struggle against racism in Canada. Everybody who has spoken agrees with this. Those who did not have a chance to speak this night would agree as well. Everyone in this House agrees that we must struggle against racism. But we must also agree to struggle against poverty in Canada which breeds racism as a symptom.
We must also agree that there will be no success in this struggle except as we struggle to end the white empire, European and North American principally, throughout the world. We must end the impoverishment and oppression of the world's majority people who are the people of colour. These are the people who are being used for our wealth. Some of these people would like to come and share the wealth we have taken from their countries. These are the people against whom Europe and North America are raising immigration barriers year by year. We must understand the connection between what we do abroad and what happens in Toronto.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canadians have been awakened by events of the past week in Los Angeles and yesterday in Toronto. I am sure
people right across this country have a new sense of awareness about how much racism is a part of our lives.
We have been awakened to the tragedy of violent riots precipitated by feelings of racism which, undoubtedly, were an expression of the frustration and anger of young people, in particular, who have little hope.
Violence such as we saw in Toronto must not be condoned. As many speakers have said, we must support actions to deal with it. It must be seen by all of us as a symptom of deeper ills, of poverty, of lack of education and of unemployment. It certainly reflects the frustration of young people of colour, in particular, who feel they are in a society where systemic discrimination and racism are a fact of life and that they have little or no opportunity for the future.
It happened in Toronto and Los Angeles but let us not kid ourselves in other parts of Canada. It could also happen in our communities.
It started in Toronto with the shooting of a black man by police who possibly had no alternative. There have been too many examples of shootings of blacks in Toronto and a great racism against black citizens in Halifax.
Our justice system has a double standard for aboriginals and people of colour. The government must act now to stop racism. Minorities are frustrated and angered by the inequalities they see and experience in their daily lives. We must not tolerate criminal responses but we must understand the causes of the anger and violence that we saw expressed yesterday and last week.
We must deal with unemployment and poverty and not just talk about statistics. We must deal with economic and social programs that will open opportunities for young people and, in particular, create jobs.
We must feed hungry children in inner city schools but their parents must have opportunities to work with pride, dignity and respect.
As Canadians we must not be complacent. We take too much pride in thinking that we are very accepting and that we do not discriminate. We should be outraged at events in our history, past and present, that discriminated against our neighbours and against fellow citizens across Canada.

The Manitoba Native Justice Commission documented deeply embedded and institutionalized racism against aboriginal persons as did the Donald Marshall
case in Nova Scotia.
In my province of British Columbia, we have a history of overt racism starting with the Komagata Mam incident, the denial of the right to vote for Asians and the discriminatory, racist Chinese head tax and exclusion act. Japanese Canadian citizens were interned in my riding at the PNE grounds.
Now we have neo-Nazis and skinheads preaching hate, burning crosses and operating hate hot lines. Of course, these are a few people who are instigating such racist activities. In the past it was racist legislation but citizens no longer will tolerate that on the whole. We cannot be complacent and we cannot say that we are an accepting, non-racist society that treats all people equally and with respect.
Let us hope that yesterday's events, like last year's tragic events at Oka, will bring a new public awareness that racism is a sickness that can and must be stamped out.
I call on parliamentarians on all sides of the House to work together to support a proactive plan of action to eliminate racism. We must all support the government in acting now to implement a plan of action which could include the following eight points.
We must establish a judicial inquiry into racism and into police minority relations and the justice system. We must amend the Criminal Code, particularly the fleeing felon rule, and amend the parts of the Criminal Code that would criminalize racism and also deal with hate propaganda.
We must strengthen the Canadian Human Rights Commission to effectively deal with complaints and systemic discrimination and racism. They must have more resources to do this.
We must proclaim Bill C-63 which we passed in the last House and establish the Canadian Race Relations Foundation with a strong mandate to eliminate racism. I appeal to the minister, in recognition of the events of this week, to press his cabinet to do this without delay and at least begin a start on the Race Relations Foundation which is to be located in Toronto.
We must reinstate and expand the Court Challenges Program so that minorities can clarify their rights under
the charter. We must protect minority rights under the Constitution, as my colleague has said over and over again, by shielding section 15 of the charter from the notwithstanding clause and including racial and ethnic equality rights in changes to section 27.
We must increase cross-cultural training. It should undoubtedly be for all public servants to set an example for other governments. Mandatory employment equity should be implemented, not just in agencies doing business with the government, but in federal public departments of governments themselves. We need realistic targets to employ visible minority staff based on availability rates.
Finally, we must immediately acknowledge the past racism in our Canadian history. I think we should do this, first of all, by redressing the racist Chinese head tax and exclusion act which discriminated against people because of their race. We must learn from the past.
I appeal to the government, to the minister and to other members of the House to take a proactive position now. Let us not wait for the next election. Canadians who believe in justice and fairness demand concrete action by their members of Parliament and by their government.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to comment on a subject that is fundamental to Canada's future.
Canadians do not see themselves as belonging to a racist society. In fact our ideal is to respect one another and provide equal opportunities for everyone. However, much remains to be done before this is actually the case in everyday life. Perhaps we will never achieve this ideal situation, since ideals are, by definition, impossible to realize. However we must always go the extra mile, and that is what we are all trying to do.
Some members of our society feel left out. They feel they have no place in our society and have the impression they are a target for injustice. The state of the economy has brought about changes that are a real challenge to each and every one of us.
In fact, these difficult times increase tension and can lead to family violence, violence against women and intolerance. Those who are already victims of discrimina-
May 5, 1992

tion are doubly disadvantaged, but please understand that no situation is an excuse for resorting to violence.
Consequently, as a government, as individuals and as communities, we must try very hard to eliminate social and economic barriers that inevitably lead to despair, and sometimes even to riots.
More than ever before we must pool our skills and experience to find creative solutions to our problems.
The federal government must above all listen to what Canadians have to say, especially the groups most often subject to discrimination and exclusion. We are constantly in touch with representatives of ethno-cultural groups and visible minorities, to look for long-term solutions and deal with crisis situations.
We invited these groups to join in the consultation process on the Canadian Constitution. The Department of Employment and Immigration consults regularly with ethnocultural groups on immigration levels and the federal strategy for immigrant integration. Through these programs, Health and Welfare Canada is also alerted to the specific needs of cultural communities. Recently the department was advised by these groups on the accessibility of social services.
Last year during the gulf war, Multiculturalism and Citizenship Canada made a point of ensuring that Canadians with roots in the Middle East were not treated unfairly. We appealed to eminent members of the Arab, Islamic and Jewish communities in Canada to let us know their needs and discuss what should be done. We also got in touch with our provincial colleagues and municipal authorities, religious leaders, police authorities, colleges and universities and asked them to help maintain the climate of respect we needed.
Thanks to the parliamentary day of the Canadian Ethnocultural Council, the government and opposition parties had a chance to listen to the concerns of ethnocultural groups. Each department was asked to respond to the questions that were raised and to discuss possible solutions.
In every part of the country there are regular meetings with ethnocultural communities and visible minorities in order to remain aware of needs and priorities. However, Mr. Speaker, actions speak even louder than words.
After the events in Halifax in the summer of 1991 the government launched a tripartite federal-provincial-municipal committee which, with the representatives of the black community, made specific recommendations on education, the media, justice, the police, tourism, arts and culture. Thirty days later each level of government submitted its response for each of the areas targeted. In the weeks to come we will report on what has been done so far and decide what must be done in the near future.
Similarly the federal government, together with its partners in all sectors, has implemented action plans to eliminate discrimination and help all citizens take a full and active part in Canadian society.
Last week the Canadian Centre for Police Race Relations opened its doors in Ottawa. The centre provides practical information, resource materials and expert advice on issues such as cross-cultural awareness training, police recruitment, police/community liaison and research.
The centre was established as part of our efforts to improve relations between the police and minorities across Canada. This is a government priority. In 1989 we consulted representatives of the provinces, territories, police, visible minority communities and native people in order to develop a national action plan on the police and these various groups.
Five essential points came out of it: intercultural training, recruiting, community involvement, information and the establishment of a committee of deputy ministers on police and relations with minorities. Our efforts in the past three years have dealt with each of these five points.
The government also encourages community groups throughout Canada to fight racism and to promote intercultural understanding.
Nationally, 10 organizations representing visible minorities received financial assistance to discuss their concerns and help the community fight discrimination. Much is being done and of course a great deal still remains to be done.
If Canadians are asked we see that all Canadians support the government's efforts to raise public awareness. A nation-wide poll conducted in July 1991 by the Angus Reid group shows the following facts: 89 per cent of Canadians support activities to eliminate racial dis-

crimination by informing the public; 85 per cent are in favour of helping immigrants acquire the knowledge and skills they need to fit into Canadian society; 83 per cent are for helping all Canadians adapt to ethnic, cultural and racial diversity.
We will agree that the federal government's activities that were mentioned previously are in line with the concerns that Canadians expressed in the poll. According to the Angus Reid survey most Canadians think that multiculturalism is an advantage for Canadian society. Indeed 77 per cent feel that multiculturalism enriches Canadian culture; and 65 per cent believe that a society made up of varied ethnic and cultural groups is better able to face new problems as they arise. However, to realize the potential benefits of multiculturalism, we must find a way to create an open society. We cannot afford not to fight racism and discrimination.
Most Canadians recognize that there is a problem in Canada. Unfortunately recent events seem to show that they are right. Racism is everyone's business. It is up to each one of us to end it. The federal government recognizes this reality. Through its actions, the government has shown that it is ready to do its part, but it cannot work in isolation. It needs partners in all quarters: education, health, social services, justice and police services, all other levels of government and of course all Canadians.
In this spirit the government has shown its leadership. It is ready to continue to work with its partners in the same direction. The consequences of doing nothing would be enormous. Who could want to run such a risk? An open, just and equitable society will bring us considerable benefits of inestimable value. We must work together on building it.
Once we have said all that, Canadians must also be able to treat human values with the respect that these values demand and require. Too often the media and the environment react to advertising and social pressure and see these values in economic terms that downgrade these basic values. Every one of us must be able to return to these values, our scale of values, and, as with our traditions or our forests and trees, deal with the roots much more than with the leaves.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext: Is there unanimous consent to give all members who want to speak on the motion an opportunity to make a speech?

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext: Agreed.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to participate in this evening's emergency debate. We have all been around the events that manifested themselves yesterday evening in Toronto. I should say at the beginning that the events that glued many Canadians to their television sets in Toronto last night was not Los Angeles. The question that should be asked is if there was not the situation in L.A. would we have seen what we saw last night in Toronto? The answer to that question is probably not.
At the same time, as other members have said, perhaps it was a tiny echo of what transpired to the south of us. We should not pretend that no tensions exist or that no frustrations exist among Canadians of various ethnocultural and racial persuasions because there are shattered dreams and aspirations and a clear lack of hope and confidence among Canadians in various communities.
We see that from time to time. Yesterday was another example, but it is certainly not new.
May 5, 1992

In fact almost a year ago in Halifax we saw very serious, divisive, and emotional feelings come to the fore in the black Canadian community of that city and province.
It should also be said, in so far as it involves the police, that police officers are also not in an easy predicament. In today's society in major urban centres that particular responsibility is a very risky one and a very dangerous one. It is often a very thankless job. It has nothing to do with the racial component at all. It simply has to do with a job that is becoming tougher because of the wave of crime that seems to be washing ashore day in and day out.
Equally it is also not easy to be a minority in this country or anywhere in the world. That is doubly so when that minority happens to be a visible minority. For instance, studies done over the last 15 years consistently show that a core of 12 to 16 per cent of Canadians are intolerant of those who are different from them.
A 1984 study by the Urban Alliance on Race Relations and the Social Planning Council of Metro Toronto showed that white job applicants receive three job offers to every one for black Canadians who had similar qualifications. A 1988 study by the Quebec Human Rights Commission found that more than twice as many blacks as whites were turned down when looking for rental accommodation.
A 1988 Canadian recruiters guide survey found that all job agency recruiters and 80 per cent of corporate head hunters received requests to specifically discriminate against minorities of all kinds. A total of 94 per cent say they rejected job seekers simply on the basis of the colour of the applicants.
Perhaps as a contradiction the Angus Reid poll recently found with respect to our multicultural-multiracial policy of this government and preceding governments since 1971 that 91 per cent of all respondents found that a true and vibrant multicultural-multiracial policy was important in binding our country and its people together, and 63 per cent supported the continuation of that policy.
I suppose it speaks to who we are as a people. Canadians have their roots in all corners of this globe. Those Canadians were asked to help in the building of this country. Those Canadians are prepared, willing and able to put their shoulders with other Canadians to ensure that we build that type of Canadian society.
5. Q 52
When Rodney King suffered some 50 blows in 80 seconds I am sure that the vast majority of Canadians felt a sense of sorrow and repugnance at what was being brought to bear on a fellow human being. I would vouch that most Americans felt that way, but a jury did not. I suppose that triggered what we have been witnessing and experiencing for the last number of days.
In terms of what happened in Toronto, we should be cognizant of the fact that we are talking about a series of complex but nonetheless realistic root causes. When the various forces are brought together the negative impact is quite clear for everyone to see.
In the last number of years we have seen an increase in violent crime of over 40 per cent. Drug abuse and drug trafficking is at an all-time high. The UN report suggested that we have the highest rate of drug related crime of any industrialized country.
I see it myself in my own riding, in the various neighbourhoods where we seem to be losing the battle against drugs. Those youths are black, brown, and yellow. They are English and they are Italian. When 14-year-olds in various parts of my riding, in broad daylight, are doing the running for crack and cocaine there is something terribly wrong with the basis of our society.
Officially, Toronto has 13,000 unemployed people. Montreal has basically the same number. In Ontario we have close to 20 per cent youth unemployment and in Quebec it is 19.9 per cent. The Economic Council of Canada told us last week in a report on education that almost 30 per cent of our youth do not finish secondary school.
The various forces that come together create that weight on the shoulders of Canadians. Unfortunately, when we add the powerful dimension of colour and visibility, those numbers and statistics become aggravated. It is unfortunate that the whole question of colour and visibility has the effect that it does. It is not by intention, but we have to recognize that it is there.
I do not want to sound alarmist because this country is still a country that has managed to resolve its differences on the whole very well. There are millions of potential Canadians who would give their left arm to be in the Chamber where I presently have the honour of speaking. We know that. We must recognize that. We must not exaggerate but at the same time, if we continue to be a country that seeks new immigrants, and we are, then we

May 5, 1992
also have to be prepared to try to resolve the challenges and problems that are within our borders in a better way.
I do not think we are looking for Herculean tasks or solutions. Essentially we have to know in a very pragmatic way that whether white or black, whether English or French, whether Ukrainian or Italian, we all strive for the same basic fundamental qualities that we seek in our lives, a family, a home, a job, a lifestyle that is somewhat comfortable and enjoyable, and a future.
When we leave this Chamber we return to that world. In fact that world gives us comfort from the political battles that take place here. What does the construction worker who starts at six in the morning, finishes at six o'clock at night, and works six days a week and sometimes works for cash on Sunday look forward to the most? It is going home, opening the door and seeing his wife and kids.
Colour has nothing to do with those aspirations. Being human does. Therefore the challenge for us is not to have another Royal commission. The member for Windsor-St. Clair spoke very eloquently and very passionately. One of the suggestions he made was for a Royal commission or an inquiry.
We have had reports. We have had the report Equality Now\ and the report on employment equity. We have the report Equality for All. We have been studied upside-down and across this country already, both on unity and on ethnicity.
We should not be looking for more commissions to be travelling across the country which also lend themselves to false expectations, emotional outbursts and probably a community that says: "Hold on a second. I was asked to make this report three years ago. I made that submission two years ago. I made a recommendation one year ago. I wrote a letter to the minister a month ago".
There has been enough input into the system. We are cognizant of sometimes what is wrong with the system and more important what is needed in order to correct it. I put 12 ideas that do not require a commission of inquiry but 12 things I think we can do and do quickly, easily, and in a united way.
We need to restore the study begun but not completed by the Law Reform Commission on minorities, the justice system and our policing system. The unfortunate part is that we eliminated the Law Reform Commission in the last federal budget.
Let us strengthen employment equity that is at the root cause in terms of lack of jobs and lack of proper remuneration in comparison to one another both on gender and ethnicity.
Let us restore the Canadian Race Relations Foundation. I salute the minister of multiculturalism and Citizenship for his efforts in terms of redress to Japanese Canadians. It was to be concerned with the national fabric and not just one particular ethnocultural group.
Let us restore the Court Challenges Program that allowed minorities an opportunity without worrying about finances to defend their rights before our court system and our judiciary.
Let us amend the Canadian Human Rights Act allowing for reasonable accommodation of the rights and interests again of minorities.
Let us promote and defend the concept of multiculturalism. Let us not only give in to the economic downturns which tend to place the blame all on the doorstep of that policy. I think that policy while it scares some certainly does much good which sometimes does not get reported. I wonder where this country would be without the day in and day out tolerance that policy tries to teach and educate. Would our race relations rapport not be worse off if we did not have a policy supported by the federal, provincial and even municipal governments?
Let us be more aggressive in terms of youth employment and training programs in the face of youth unemployment statistics. When we look at our television sets we do not see senior citizens protesting. We see the faces of young people who are also wondering about the dead end facing them.
Why not bring together the federal and provincial Solicitors General to talk about the immediate, practical action that can come.
May 5, 1992

Perhaps it is time that the Constitution recognize the multicultural and multi-racial nature of Canadian society in a strong way, in the same way and in the same place when we talk about the other three pillars of society: the French fact, the English fact, and the aboriginal fact. Would that be placing everybody at the front of the constitutional bus and not relegating some to the back or on the next bus altogether?
Let us pay attention to the inner cities, the urban centres with respect to our social and economic spheres of programs. This is not to exclude the rural areas but to recognize the particular problems that give rise to yesterday's events are also in large measure an urban phenomenon in which more and more Canadians with each passing year are living.
Let us amend the Narcotics Control Act with respect to the proceeds of drug seizures, millions of dollars each year that go into the general revenues of the federal government. Let us have a formula that shares those revenues with the federal government and with the leading frontline organizations from the community and the police forces that do the battling of that drug war in the alleyways while we sleep at night. They are losing the war because they are out gunned, out equipped and out-financed.
Now that we are getting into an election footing, why do the three national parties not recommit themselves and encourage candidates of all walks of life to seek positions in ridings that those respective parties can win. Then when people come to the gallery to watch the proceedings of the House of Commons they will not get the picture that the Canada of 1992 is made up of a white Anglo-Saxon male dominated population. This place too has to be more reflective of a Canada of 1992 rather than 1492. That is a political challenge that each of our parties should take upon itself.
In conclusion, we have the makings of a solution already within our system. We do not need another study. We do not need a travelling committee. We also do not need another report that is going to collect further dust and further alienate the already dampened
expectations of a Canadian population that anticipates and expects a future for all.
I salute the efforts of trying to have a constructive and productive dialogue with the leadership of the black Canadian community and the federal and provincial governments as took place the other day.
There also needs to take place a dialogue outside of that visible community, because the problem is not only necessarily with the converted, but the problem is also with a country that has to manifest and indicate the latitude, the flexibility and the tolerance to allow all Canadians to participate in the opportunities that have been granted to the majority of Canadians.
We will only be as good as we are in the human rapport that ties this country from one coast to the other.
This is not really a new challenge. In general it has challenged societies in the world for decades. We, thank God, have managed quite nicely, but we also have to recognize that the opportunities and greatness of Canada have not always worked for all Canadians. It will cost us nothing to share the fruits of this country with all of our neighbours, be they black or be they white. If we do, we will have a better and greater country.
I know in that type of society my children will fare better and easier than if we were to play the politics of exclusion. The more we include, the greater this country will be.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to join in this debate tonight, ashamed, embarrassed and offended. I am ashamed and embarrassed that the incidents which took place in Toronto last night took place in my country. I am more ashamed and embarrassed that the racism that lies at the root of such reactions as last night exists. It exists in an all-pervasive mode in the city I love and I represent, in the province I love and I represent, and in the country I love and I represent.
I am more offended at the reaction of the Government of Canada in this debate. I am offended with the Minister of Justice. I am offended with the minister of multiculturalism and citizenship. I am offended with the number of ministers on the government side of the House who stood in this debate and made pious mouth-ings when our streets are going up in flames.

I am offended that I heard all of the good things that we are supposed to talk about, when we talk about equality between the races and between the cultures, from a government that cancelled the Law Reform Commission. It cancelled it, I might say, before it had time to finish a study on minorities and the justice system. However Conservatives are all in favour of good relations between the races and the cultures. I do not believe it and I doubt that my constituents and the people of Canada believe it either.
I am offended because this same government with those same ministers stood there tonight and made all those wonderful statements about how we must learn to live together and how we must make this a better place. This is the same government that has not given us the Canadian Race Relations Foundation.
I am offended to hear from those ministers and to hear from those members about how important this is to the future of Canada, the future of our children and the future of the human race from a government that cancelled the Court Challenges Program. It cancelled it. It is gone. The program that was supposed to give that extra special lift and assistance to disadvantaged groups, to black Canadians, to visible minority Canadians other than blacks, to women, and that is the government that we have. No matter what it says in this debate, these are the things that it has done.
The people of Canada know that these are the things that the government has done. I hope that the people of Canada will rise up and say: "Enough, enough".
I represent a province that has had a problem with racism since before it was a province, since before Canada was a country. Blacks first came to Nova Scotia as slaves, to New France in 1750. Abolition did not take place until 1833, but they stayed. They stayed and their ranks were augmented because Nova Scotia was the last stop on the underground railroad when courageous slaves broke away from their bonds in the southern U.S. and made it to Canada. They stayed and they were augmented as well by members of the United Empire Loyalist blacks who came after the American Revolution. They were United Empire Loyalists. They were given some grants, not as much as white people were given, of course not. They were not given the good land that white people were given. We have in Nova Scotia the descendants of United Empire Loyalists who are
proud of that heritage and proud of their land. They live in counties like Halifax County and Halifax city, Digby County, Guysborough County, Cape Breton County, all over the province of Nova Scotia.
Black Nova Scotians are part and parcel of the history and heritage of Nova Scotia. They have suffered and they have been discriminated against and enough is enough.
I am ashamed to hear a friend of mine who left my city, our city, 20 years ago and when she came back she said to me: "You know my people are still invisible in the city of Halifax". I am equally ashamed that another friend of mine, a black community activist in Halifax, when she browses through an expensive store in the city of Halifax, is closely monitored by the sales clerks because she is black and what is she doing in an expensive store. I am ashamed that this happens in my country and I want it to stop.
It will not stop if we just sit around and say that we must be better behaved. We must love each other. We must understand that people are equal. Equality does not grow in an arid atmosphere. This government has created an arid atmosphere by cancelling the very programs, the only programs, that could make equality bloom in Canada.
I am ashamed and I am embarrassed and I want it to stop. I do not want what happened in Toronto to happen again. I do not want it to happen in Montreal.
I sure do not want it to happen in the streets of the cities of Halifax and Dartmouth. Members of the black community do not want it to happen, but when the frustration level, particularly the frustration level with young blacks, rises as it must rise in the face of this kind of racism, what can we expect?
There are young blacks in Nova Scotia who cannot expect to get any kind of a job, let alone a job that might be commensurate with their training and talent, young blacks in Nova Scotia are discriminated against as a matter of course, young blacks in Nova Scotia, and this is the greatest tragedy of all, see the only way to earn a living is to get involved with the drug trade.
I know my time is running out, but I will close with one story that is very tragic. There are many tragic stories in Nova Scotia that are based on racism. I remember one young man who had a promising career as an athlete. It is
May 5, 1992

fortunate that one of the areas where racism is not so rampant is the area of athletics.
As he started his promising career, something happened to him that can happen to anybody regardless of race, colour or creed. He was injured and his athletic career was cut off. He had two choices. He could go to work for minimum wage as a cleaner, and there is nothing wrong with that job but that was all that was available to him, or he could get involved in the drug trade and make a whole lot of money.
That was what he did. Before he was 35 years old, he was gunned down on a Halifax street. This is happening more and more and more. In my city, my beautiful city, people should be able to live in harmony and in peace, there should be jobs, training and a future for us and for our children regardless of background, colour, religion or any of those things that do not matter. My city is becoming one of the worst drug infested cities on the North American continent.
Although I am offended at the government, I do not necessarily blame it all on it. If we do not get those institutions back, if we do not get the kind of compassionate and sensible government that does something for people so that they can live decent lives then we the majority of Canadians are going to deserve every single thing we get.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I first of all want to say to my colleague from Halifax, as a seatmate of mine across that great harbour of Halifax, I do not know of any people who have worked as hard as she has for minority groups, not just blacks and the disempowered.
She has worked on women's issues. She has always been there to be the voice of those who have been dispossessed and have had their voice silenced. I count myself very lucky to have her as a seatmate, but I count myself even luckier to have her as a friend and as a very, very wise counsel.
The words that she has just expressed are heartfelt. She does not have to contrive them, she does not have to write notes on it. She has fought most of her life against the scourge of racism.
It is easy for us to talk about racism when we are white and when we belong to the majority of society. It is a lot
more difficult to try to understand the sting of racism. It is a lot more difficult to understand when we are in our jobs why in the name of God we do not do something about it.
Racism is perhaps the greatest sin that we can perpetrate on our fellow human beings. We do not judge people by what is in here, by their skills, by their abilities or by their character. Racism is that awful, awful, devastating, damaging, evil through which we judge people by the colour of their skin, by the religion that they practice or by the language that they speak. Away back in beautiful pristine Nova Scotia, back in Dartmouth, the other side of the harbour we see the scourge of racism on a daily basis. Some of my constituents do not like me to remind them of that.
I said in this House before and I will say it as long as I have a breath in my body, that every time racism is seen it has to be confronted and it has to be snuffed out. It is not an easy subject to talk about because people get kind of queasy. Nobody really wants to be part of the problem and they do not want to be reminded over and over again that by their inaction and by their acquiescence they are a part of the problem.
I count myself extremely lucky. I represent a wonderful part of Canada in Dartmouth. I have said it before, it is on the record, that one of the things I am most proud of is that I represent the communities of Preston and North Preston, and Cherrybrook which are the oldest indigenous black communities in Canada. They are six miles from the border of the largest metropolitan area in Atlantic Canada. Have they shared in the greatness of that area? No, they have not.
They have been in this country longer than my people have been here, yet I am accepted as a Nova Scotian. I am accepted as a Nova Scotian whose heritage matters in that province. My people have been in this country for less than 100 years. Nobody questions my place of origin or whether or not I belong. That is not a part of it.
However, in the communities of Nova Scotia, Halifax, in North Preston and East Preston, as my colleague said, it has been over 200 years since those blacks came to Nova Scotia. Their heritage is rich. It is just as damned important as my heritage is as a Scot and it is just as important as the Acadian heritage in Nova Scotia and just as important as the British heritage. However we still have lessons to learn.

S. ft 52
We have a black cultural centre which, albeit was built by government money, cannot get a plugged nickel from Parks Canada to get somebody to come in and help put up the displays properly. They do not get any money from Parks Canada to preserve their history, but be damned if you go over and look at the Halifax Citadel, there are plenty of federal dollars in there to preserve that part of our heritage. There is plenty of money down in Annapolis Royal and plenty of money in Louisbourg and plenty of money at the Citadel in Quebec. There is damned plenty of money here in Ottawa but there is no money available for that type of thing from Parks Canada.
We deal with those communities. The Prestons are true communities. They have been there so long that everybody is related to everybody. When you walk into that community and if you know five people, you know 500. They have suffered under the scourge of racism for so long, my God some of them have even come to accept it and they do not even challenge it any more.
When did the community of North Preston, about 3,500 people, six miles away from the largest metropolitan area in Atlantic Canada, get its sewer and water? It got it two and a half years ago. The last community of its size in the province of Nova Scotia to get centralized sewer and water was the community of North Preston, and only after the water became a health issue.
The community of North Preston is now fighting a battle and the Minister of State for Multiculturalism has been a great help in this one. They are fighting a battle today to stop a dump from going on historic black lands.
Last summer my colleague from Halifax indicated there was a problem. There was a riot in Halifax. As a result of that riot, community groups and three levels of government got together and came up with over a 90 point set of proposals on how to deal with racism.
Proposal No. 10 said: "In recognition of the fact that it is historically founded in fact that black communities in Nova Scotia have historically been the recipient of the white garbage dumps". It has happened down in Afric-ville in the north end of Halifax. It is happening in Crichton Park in Dartmouth. You cannot go to a black community in the province of Nova Scotia that has not been the recipient of somebody else's garbage. When the white communities did not want it they gave it to the
black community. For some reason the black communities were not as worthy and were not as "clean" as the non-black communities.
Recommendation 10 of that committee report said that there would be no more dumpsites on black township sites. Less than one year later the municipality of the county of Halifax selected an area outside of North Preston, on historic black lands, for the site of the new metropolitan area dump.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext: Shame.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Absolute shame. We wonder why blacks say that even in 1992 we are still not listening. White Canada is still not listening. How much louder do they have to say it. Blacks say: "You still are not listening. You have not understood".
It grieves me greatly when I hear comments from people saying: "Well you know those blacks. They are always complaining anyway" or "those blacks, they are always so lazy and they really do not want to work".
Those blacks are my friends. I resent those statements coming from any individual as I would resent the statement of somebody unduly criticizing a member of my family. It is time. It must stop.
The Minister of State for Multiculturalism and Citizenship is here and I want to publicly thank him. He has provided support for the Preston community when support was desperately needed. I know that sometimes it is not always easy to convince some of your colleagues of the appropriateness of your actions.
Time after time when I have had some difficulties the minister has come forward and he has always had an ear to listen. If there was something that he could do, if it was nothing other than moral support, he did it. That is important.
The black community is not ruled by people of the same colour. It is ruled by people who look like me. We are white. We have to go that extra distance to show that we do understand and that we do care.
I have worked in my community in Preston. I certainly would never condone violent response to the situation that minority groups find themselves in, never. That is not the way to do it.
May 5, 1992

Think of it. A young black living in my area of Dartmouth-and I know this because I did a survey, it cost $15,000 two and a half years ago-can reasonably expect to make 42 per cent less than a young white man of the same age. A young black will probably be forced out of school earlier because racism is systemic down there. It hurts like hell. It takes away your self-pride and it must be erased. We have to get by this, by God.
We are destroying peoples' lives solely because of the colour of their skin. These are people who could contribute to society if they felt at home in school. God knows, maybe they would find a cure for cancer. However the school system is systemically driving them out.
They do not want special treatment, they just want equal treatment. They do not want more than anybody, they only seek to be included. If we were all blinded tomorrow we would not have a problem with the colour of somebody's skin. We would judge them by the quality of their life, their character, and the giving and caring in their soul.
In conclusion I want to urge this House at every opportunity to face racism head on, to snuff it out and to allow every Canadian, regardless of the colour of their skin, to fully participate in society to the extent of their abilities.
I want to urge everybody in this House to join hands across this aisle, where there is all too often combat, and for once say: "We can and we must get rid of racism in Canadian society".

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to start my speech this evening by telling you that I do not believe for a moment that the Canadian society is a racist society. I know that after what has happened in the United States and last night in Toronto, we may be tempted to say: "We are like the Americans, we too are having racial problems". In a way I am an American. I have relinquished my American citizenship to become a Canadian citizen and because I saw in Canada a different place to be. Tonight is not the night I will tell you that we are like them. It is not true. Not so in the sense that Canada, with its francophone and anglophone peoples, is a tolerant nation which understands
the requirements that come with several races, even those of what we call multiculturalism.
Multiculturalism is impossible in the United States. It has even been said that the American melting pot had melted down. It is true in the sense that in the United States, instead of trying to get citizens involved, or to favour their integration, the Americans have systematically shoved them aside. They have systematically created several classes of citizens. If there were only one or two classes that would be nothing new, but there are a second, a third and a fourth, depending on which class of immigrants one belongs to.
We must first understand that Canada is not the United States. As my colleague from Windsor mentioned earlier, Los Angeles is not Toronto; our problems are different.
As a former American, an American who worked with associates of Martin Luther King, who spent three years in a college for black Americans, who fought for the recognition of the rights of Black people in the United States, I remember well attending Bowie State College in the State of Maryland. I have seen the awful face of institutionalized racism which manifested itself first by refusing to recognize the right to vote of individuals; second, racism which constantly attempted to intimidate black people so that they would not vote, that is those who were able to prove that they could vote; and, third, racism that took the form of murders. For example, those who killed Martin Luther King did so in a very calculated way.
In Canada the situation is not the same. As a Canadian who is also a former American, I did some research in preparation for this debate, in order to find out what differentiates us. We show our discontent-and this was demonstrated in Toronto-but I ask myself what provoked all this. After watching and listening when I was a member of the Beaudoin-Dobbie Committee on the renewal of our Constitution, I told myself that the Canadian society is not racist. However there are some institutions created by pieces of legislation that go back a long time which are racists. I stress the word racism because I do not like the way this word is used at the drop of a hat. It is a little like the word holocaust. These words tend to lose their impact when they are used so often and not always at the appropriate time.

Mr. Speaker, I am sure you will agree and I see I have your attention. I read the legislation we refer to as the Indian Act. I never saw a piece of legislation that was so paternalistic and arrogant, anti-native and quite frankly totalitarian and inhuman. I asked myself how people could survive and even prosper with this kind of legislation.
This is something that must change immediately. Although it may have reflected Canadian reality 100 years ago, today the Canadians across this country will not agree with this legislation. We cannot treat a people like slaves, if we can still use that word-
I remember in the United States we had the benign neglect theory. I think it applies to natives in this country. It may seem rather bizarre to hear a member from Quebec defending native people. That may be so, but the fact is that as members from Quebec or Ontario we must tell the truth. Let us face it, the way natives have been treated in this country by our institutions is racist.
That being said, as far as racism towards blacks in Canada is concerned, I think we do have a problem in Toronto. We certainly do. There is a problem with the Ontario police which seems to want to shoot point blank at anyone who appears to have committed a criminal offence. We know that in 15 years they killed fifteen Blacks. But I do not think we can extrapolate the situation in Toronto and say that there is a problem with blacks across Canada. As far as Toronto is concerned, yes, there is a serious problem. Elsewhere in Canada, and I can talk about Quebec where I come from this is not a joke, but it is rather funny. For instance in Montreal the police tend to kill quite a few whites. Only this year 25 people were killed by police in Montreal and out of those 25, only three were blacks.
Let us keep things in perspective. First of all this is not happening everywhere in Canada. Second, whether the person is black, white, Chinese or Vietnamese, it is unacceptable that members of the police force would first shoot and then say "stop". Some policemen will tell you that they had no choice but to kill someone who had a knife, an offensive weapon, compare that to a revolver. It is not acceptable to say that they were forced to kill someone. Most people who are listening to us will say: "Listen, you can shoot in the leg or in the arm.
Policemen are well trained and they know how to use adequate force to protect their lives".
I am not prepared to accept the fact that Canada behaves like a racist society with coloured people. I am not telling you this with great pride, but it is my finding. We as members of Parliament, must provide you with our findings and we must do so clearly without too many nuances.
When white people walk on a sidewalk and see a black person approaching, say a young well built man full of confidence, who may have a Ph.D., a doctor, a philosopher, a New Democrat or even a Liberal, I am convinced, that many have a certain degree of apprehension: He is coming closer to me. Will he try to do something? Am I in danger? That is problem with steorotyping minority groups.
* However it is not only white people who look at black people with some apprehension in an urban environment. Because of previous experience, and with reason, black people have started to look at the police force in a different way from that of white people. How do we perceive policemen? We feel free to ask them where is the nearest Mac's Milk or Petro-Canada station. For us, a policeman is our friend.
Put yourself in the shoes of a black person around midnight or at one in the morning. As a black person, would you approach a policeman to ask him where is the nearest Mac's Milk? The policeman might give you directions to get there, but he will also ask you what you want to do, and that is a problem. We as a society steorotype people.
As a white person, listening to us, may think it is terrible. White people do not do that; they do not steorotype black people. This is utterly false because it does exist and it is troublesome. We must understand that the same mistrust exist. It is a deeply rooted mistrust of two societies.
But I suggest that this mistrust does not permeate our society, our institutions. It may be the case in the United States where the Black people did not have the right to vote. Fortunately in the 1800s, up until the year 1900, Canada was a terminus on what used to be called the underground railroad for American black slaves who wanted to flee the U.S. and institutionalized racism.
May 5, 1992

I can see in Canada today a countiy looking for direction, looking to do the right thing like welcoming immigrants. At the same time the country wants to rid itself a load we have been carrying since the 1800s, a load of racism toward the natives and a load of wanting to stereotype people of other racial background because we had such a poor understanding of these people.
This may surprise you, Mr. Speaker, but there are a lot of myths about the other ethnic groups in our society. It is only by living with, accepting and welcoming these people that we can destroy these myths. I am proud that Canada, like all western countries, welcomes immigrants. At the same time this welcome is somewhat schizophrenic. We do not mind letting them in, but at the same time we make it so difficult for them with all the administrative hurdles that in the end it turns into something of an administrative nightmare that deters quite a few potential immigrants.
In closing, we have had a good debate tonight, a debate dealing with what distinguishes us from the United States as well as with the extent to which we can change our legislation and the way we look at other groups. As a Quebecer and a proud Quebecer, especially having been the right of native peoples to self-determination recognized in Quebec since 1985,1 find that we are not doing too good in Canada. But things are not as bad as in the States yet. We could set an example by applying ourselves to accepting ethnic and native groups the way they are. They are Canadians.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first of all let me congratulate the hon. member for Trinity- Spadina on his initiative. It offers us an opportunity to put forward some thoughts on the demonstration in Toronto.
My intervention will not be long. I would like to explore the root causes leading to the demonstrations and to outline possible remedial action.
Let me first start with the root causes as I see them. We have to go back. To understand the situation we must look at last Saturday and remember why and how the demonstration was triggered. The root of all that developed over the weekend and can be traced to a back alley in west Toronto as a result of a chase of drug dealers whose existence is only made possible because there are drug addicted people who consume drugs and who therefore require the services of drug dealers.
I submit that without users, without consumers, drug dealers would not survive very long. There would be no shootings taking place in the back alleys of Toronto without this phenomenon of drug consumption. Therefore it seems to me that the problem is not really the dealer. The dealer is just a link. The problem is that we are not adequately addressing the real problem, namely the consumer. What I am saying is that inadequate attention is being paid to ways of reducing the consumption. It is the consumption of drugs that must be addressed.
Two American presidents, back to back, so to speak, both President Reagan and President Bush announced that they would eradicate drugs in North America. They announced substantial sums behind this policy; but the failure of the policy so far, it seems to me, is that they invested most of the effort and the resources into pursuing the producers and the dealers. They put very little resources, effort and energy into tackling the problem from the perspective of the consumer, the perspective of the addict.
Mr. Speaker, I am sure you will agree that should we be successful in dealing with the consumer, should we be successful in reducing consumption and eradicating consumption, in the long term the producers would have no market and the dealers would have no existence.
Starting from this premise, I would like to go further into the root causes of consumption. From observation and from the reports made by community workers in the field the answers are manyfold as to what the root causes are. They are related to unemployment, poor housing, lack of education and employable skills. They are related to all those elements, the presence of which would give the individual a sense of dignity, a sense of purpose and a sense of direction. The root causes are related to the lack of access to adequate rehabilitation and to adequate community services.

May 5, 1992
It is very important that we focus our attention on the importance of prevention through all means available, mainly those of education. At the present time we are in a phase where we are chasing the producer and the trafficker. As a result, as I mentioned earlier, we are paying infinitesimal attention, a fraction of our resources on anticipating, on preventing this phenomenon. Even when we pay attention to the curing of those who are addicted, the resources are lacking.
There is also a strong indication that the drug addiction phenomenon is linked to family situations. It is the result of youth finding themselves without a real home. It is the result of a vacuum that seems to exist in certain families where the home is just a physical shelter but where there is no warmth, no sense of mutual support, understanding and direction.
So far I have explored the root causes that lead to the present situation, to the increasing consumption of drugs and the concomitant results. We have to ask ourselves why are we at this stage, facing this phenomenon of chasing the drug traffickers in the middle of the night, of police authorities finding themselves unable to cope with the phenomenon because the human resources are not there. I cannot help concluding that much can be traced to the inadequacy of our social programs.
Under the best of circumstances our social programs would have to be intensified no doubt, but we find ourselves at the present time facing the consequences of cuts in federal spending in the social field. I am referring to housing, particularly social and co-op housing, I am referring to child care, I am referring to apprenticeship, I am referring to youth training, job creation and the like.
In other words, opportunities are being reduced with respect to access to employment, with respect to improved incomes, with respect to relief from the burdens of taxation, you name it. As a result, it seems to me that the urban environment is screaming for more and more attention because in Canadian cities the situation is deteriorating. From a human perspective the urban environment is increasingly polluted. We must address the situation in terms of a human ecology which requires attention. Therefore the question is: What are the remedies?
I will conclude in a few moments by examining the remedies which flow from the examination of the root causes which actually are the flip side of the same coin.
It seems to me that we must concentrate our efforts on educating the population, and particularly the young population, intensively on the consequences of drug use.
We must prevent addiction and rehabilitate the addicted person. The efforts presently out there in the various communities are obviously not adequate. There are beautiful initiatives. There are even some heroic initiatives of very dedicated men and women who are active in the communities across the nation who are attempting to provide rehabilitation to those who are addicted and who have fallen into this trap.
In Toronto we have an organization called Caritas. It is attempting to do just that. It has adopted the name Caritas from Latin which means charity. It is an attempt to bring the affected youth a message of hope and the tangible assistance through dedicated community workers who offer a ray of hope through constructive activities in an environment and a new home. This has been made possible through the substantial support of the community itself which has come somehow to the conclusion that efforts of this kind not only deserve support but demand very generous endorsement and funding.
We need probably hundreds of Caritas initiatives throughout urban Canada. At the present time they are very few and far between. Why is that so? Probably the answer is that our priorities are wrong because in difficult times it is the social services which get the axe so to speak.
Instead of being the last to be affected, social services are the first. Therefore, one must conclude that if the words human resources are to mean anything we must revisit our priorities. We must conclude that if we do not pay attention to the human being, particularly in the early stages of life, and if we do not make adequate investments in that person by way of education, information and community care, then human resources become empty words.
This debate, if it is to have any meaning tonight has to conclude with some specific recommendations of the government. Obviously we cannot indulge ourselves in
May 5, 1992

an abstract analysis of the problem without concluding also in a constructive manner.
It seems to me that in this Chamber we have here the duty at least to call on the government and to tell it to restore the social programs that have been reduced. It should rebuild the social programs that are required in order to strengthen the fabric of human life in the cities.
We call on the government to reintroduce the social housing programs, to implement its promises on child care programs, to fund again apprenticeship programs, to increase the training activities particularly for youth, to reinvent the job creating activities that have so well served this country, and to facilitate the access to opportunities for the young people who are anxious and desirous to enter the labour force.
There is nothing more debilitating and depressing which eventually leads to drifting than the fact that as a young person one cannot find a job, one cannot have the means to earn a living, one cannot have access to the beginning of a career by way of finding one's first employment. This is what is probably polluting the urban environment mostly.
This is why the human ecology which I mentioned earlier needs attention.

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52   TORONTO VIOLENT DEMONSTRATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have been listening to some very thoughtful and considered remarks tonight which have been brought forth in the course of this extraordinary exchange. This is not a debate. The member for Trinity-Spadina is to be thanked for having suggested that we undertake this discussion. I do not know if my colleague for Chambly was the seconder of the motion. If he were I thank him. If he were not, he got an accolade on this occasion.
I know it is late. It is after the midnight hour. I do not know that many people are listening to us in the House. Notwithstanding, there are some very serious issues we have to think about.
The riot that took place last night brought to mind a number of things that have gone on. I would like to do a little retrospect of what has happened in my own life in the last couple of weeks to put this whole question into focus.
The riot last night was in a sense mob violence. It was a group of young vandals taking advantage of what was and
what seemed to be a peaceful demonstration that turned into a rampage in downtown Toronto. Some of us can remember back to a night on that same Yonge Street when the windows were bashed and cracked after an Argos game. A group came out of the stadium, all very excited, and mob violence took over.
There are parallels that have nothing to do with the colour of one's skin but have to do with the nature of an incident that takes place. It may well relate to exuberance. It may well relate to violence based on just cause. However, violence of any nature is never very productive in a society.
Last Sunday-I can hardly believe that was just two days ago-I visited a small, beautiful Lutheran church in the NDG riding where a Holocaust remembrance service was being undertaken. A very interesting Finnish priest gave the lecture after we lit the candles of the menorah, recalling Hasoha, recalling injustice, recalling genocide based on who you were, not what you were; based on a Nazi ideology that just swept with fury like a sickness, an illness, a disease of the mind. Nazis and collaborators destroyed millions of people. The priest who was speaking talked about the need to love thy neighbour, "Love thy neighbour as thyself; do unto thy neighbour as you would have done unto you". These are fundamental, Judeo-Christian values that stand for any one of the religions of the world, the way people are to be decent human beings. It is not the colour of one's skin, not the country of origin, not the background, culture or language, but just who you are, that you are on this earth, that you have been born, that you live and you have the right to respect dignity and fair treatment.
The priest went on to say that you do not have to like your neighbour, you do not have to agree with everything he does, but you do have to love him in the fullest sense of how one should love one's self.
I thought that it was a wonderful message in this era of racism, of xenophobia, of hatred, of differences. I thought how fitting, as I listened to this priest, and I wished I had thought of those words the week before when I had gone to participate in the day of commemoration of the Vietnamese community. They were, in one sense, thanking their good fortune as they were the boat people who came to Canada in 1979 and with whom I had worked, and at the same time they were recalling then-dead heroes, the unsung heroes of the battles of Vietnam, of the millions who had been maimed, who had

May 5, 1992
been orphaned, who had suffered from bombs and the defoliation of their country.
I thought of the Armenian remembrance day that I attended the same afternoon; 1,000 Armenians in the church remembering the death and slaughter of 1.5 million of their brothers and sisters, aunts, uncles and cousins in 1915, the hundreds of thousands who had fled across mountains, of the breaking up of families. I thought, here we were, remembering the Armenian holocaust, the Jewish Shoah, the Vietnamese boat people, and at the same time we have other things that we must remember that go on right here in this country. There is no country that is without blame and there is no country that is without sin. There is no country that has always treated its people well.
There are different reasons why these kinds of things happen. On Saturday night I had the privilege of attending the black businessmen council's dinner at the Delta Hotel in Montreal. They were presenting the Jackie Robinson award for excellence. I was seated with a group of extraordinary men and women who are wonderful role models for the black community. Seated among us were some people who I recognized. There was a very well known owner of hotels and motels, a land developer of renown, an insurance broker who was well known, a very well respected immigration lawyer, an entrepreneur for whom I have a great deal of respect; businessmen and business women, an economist with H.F.C., a professor from the University of Quebec. We were talking about the need for role models in today's society, particularly for the young visible minority people.
In my riding, where we had a level of unemployment which I will come to in a moment, this was a very important opportunity for me to examine with these men and women of colour what they felt we could do and how we could, in a way, use the wonderful achievements that they had realized to enable their young people to have a sense of tomorrow, to have a sense of hope, to know that there are ways in which they can come out of the unfortunate ghetto that they feel they are trapped in. We talked about Jackie Robinson, the man whose trophy was being awarded to an outstanding Haitian who owned the Lasalle Taxi company in Montreal. I believe his name was M. Raymond. We talked about the role that Branch
Rickey had played on the Dodgers when he brought Jackie Robinson to Montreal, a man who had shown incredible integrity, honesty, a wonderful ball player, and someone who broke the racial stereotypes, the racial barriers, and changed the world of baseball forever.
Yes, Canada, Quebec, Montreal, have had a very important role in changing the place that marks the visible minorities in our community. You could not help but think about today the systemic and the systematic degrees of unbelievable intolerance that is out there with many people. It comes from ignorance. It comes from setting stereotypes in one's mind.
My colleague earlier tonight talked about the Indian people, the aboriginals of Canada. I did the Indian Act and I can tell you that the discrimination against women, the discrimination against those people, the discrimination against their children, the removal of their children from their homes, the whole attitude toward aboriginal peoples in our society was sick. It was founded on false premise, a lack of understanding of culture, of language, of lifestyle. That is what is wrong with many of the things that we do.
We develop a sense of hatred out of fear. Racism flows from fear. It is a hatred of difference.
I say to you when I hear us talk about Canada being a tolerant country that is not a word that turns me on. It is a word that turns me off. I think it is a very poor word. It is a very condescending word. Tolerance is not what it is all about. It is respect for difference. It is respect for diversity because Canada is a land of diversity. Canadian culture is the beauty of respect for the cultural differences be they linguistic, culture, geography, regional, whatever they may be, and particularly in the large cities which have become melting pots in many ways. Yet we want to be able to maintain a respect for one's roots and a pride in one's roots.
There is something fundamentally wrong with our immigration system and our integration system. It is our immigration and integration both as the receivers of new people. We do not know them. We do not understand them and we have not been exposed to the kind of
May 5, 1992

information which we should have as an education and learning procedure.
Our television sets do not show us the real stories. We do not feel comfortable in telling our stories. Multicul-turalism one is not supposed to talk about. We are not supposed to be hyphenated Canadians. We are all hyphenated something-or-others, and there is nothing wrong with that. One loves a mother and father, one is the child of that marriage, one can certainly share that sense of love and belonging to the land of birth, the land of history, the city of living and the people who surround us. I see nothing wrong with being hyphenated in many ways.
I suggest we are all Canadians and as Canadians we must learn, we must teach, and we must develop a sense of belonging, a sense of respect and of joy in our differences. The sooner we do that the better off we will be.
Los Angeles and the Rodney King story is a different story from the riot in Toronto in my view. Yet there is a similarity that could happen.
We have a problem in the making if we are not careful; if we do not realize that economic policy alone, resolving debt and deficit, is a poor policy without examining the social debt and deficit that we build; if we build on an insecure family, poorly housed, poorly fed, not well nourished in terms of books and learning and respect and love for life.
If you are left with a sense of desperation because you do not have the food to feed your family properly, the clothes to dress your family properly, you will lose your sense of self-worth. How are you supposed to drag yourself out of that to get into the marketplace? No one is helping you into that marketplace, either.
We have talked about setting up, particularly for new immigrants in this country, incubators to allow new immigrants to learn how we market, how we merchandise, how we buy, how we sell, the Canadian way of doing business. That is a variety of ways and a variety of products. However, we do not do that. We have not put into place the kinds of programs that would have helped us to address what has happened with the new free trade arrangements.
We have put into place the kinds of programs that are not meeting the needs of a country in a serious recession. I cannot recall any time in the past, except over these last few years, when people were standing at bus stops and in front of restaurants with their hands out begging. I was
taught that if someone approaches you and says: "Give me a dime for a cup of coffee", that you do not lecture, you give the dime. You lecture your Red Cross, your fundraising, your Red Feather, or Combined Jewish Appeal.
They are not asking for a dime or a quarter because you cannot buy anything for a dime or a quarter anymore. They are asking for $1 or $2.
Mr. Speaker, do you remember food banks where you lived? TTiere was never a food bank where I lived. Now there are food banks in my riding. There is a lack of social policy and vision to change this country, particularly in its urban centres, into a proper area in which to live through social housing, co-op housing, food, clothing, and education; to change this country into a place in which the child who goes to school has pride in going to school and someone is at home or there is a child care or day care program where he can go so he is not left alone with a latch key around his neck and they are made to feel like needed human beings. Everybody is needed, no matter the colour of their skin.
There was a lesson to be learned from Los Angeles and there was a lesson to be learned from the riot last night. That lesson is that it could happen here. All these things come with poverty and the growing gap between the rich and poor. Racism is a symptom and the outcome is violence and xenophobia. The outcome is a trigger to a destabilized community. We cannot have a good economy if we do not have a good society. Do not forget that. Money does not buy safety on the streets.
We have to think about how to prevent this loss of hope, this loss of a sense of well-being. What can we do to strengthen the social fabric of our society other than by addressing the issues I have just mentioned? How are we going to fill that breach between the haves and the have nots and create a fairer balance and the basic decency which one would hope to find in Canada?
The statistics show that in Quebec there is 19.8 to 20 per cent unemployment amongst our youth in general. A study done in my riding shows that there is 60 to 65 per cent unemployment among visible minorities. Does that not say something about a poor structure? Something is wrong somewhere when mothers come to my office and tell me that they are terrified that their children travel on the metro system and they do not know if they are going to be harassed by the police. If they happen to get together in gangs and happen to belong to a visible minority group they know they are going to be hassled. Is there not something wrong?

May 5, 1992
I know the police are trying hard and I know they are doing training. I know they are doing recruiting, but it is not enough and it is not quick enough.
I will tell you that we must do something about the violence which has increased by 40 per cent. We have to do something about drugs when we hear that Canada has the highest rate of drug related crimes in the industrialized world. We know that gang wars are taking place on the streets in my riding, that crack houses exist, that prostitution is the answer for many of the foster children.
There is racial tension between groups because we did not integrate well through immigration programs and poverty problems because we have not set up the proper vision of where balance belongs in our society. I say to you that we must find some of the answers.
I know that many of my colleagues gave a list of the things that could be done so that justice will not only be
perceived to be done but shall be accomplished. We need action now. We need to return that sense of worth, that sense of dignity regardless of colour, regardless of language, regardless of creed, regardless of country of origin. That is what we have to do and that is the message from last night.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole

speechtext: Pursuant to Standing Order 52(12) I am satisfied that the debate has now been concluded. I therefore declare the motion carried.
Motion agreed to.
